https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/183436,2017,Organizing Sports and Public Values,Dutch,"Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,"['dr. M.G. van Slobbe', 'S. van den Hombergh, MSc']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Na afronding van deze cursus heeft de student:

column2: • inzicht verworven in de kenmerken van sportorganisaties als organisaties met een publieke functie en de manier waarop zij in wisselwerking staan met hun maatschappelijke en bestuurlijke omgeving;

• geleerd de veranderende rol van overheid en publieke organisaties voor het aanpakken van maatschappelijke issues via sport te karakteriseren in termen van ‘institutionele context’, ‘governance', ‘multi-actor en multi-level netwerken’ en ‘interorganisatorische samenwerking’;
• inzicht in de alledaagse en lokale complexiteit van het organiseren en besturen van sport door vrijwilligers en professionals;
• geleerd wetenschappelijke artikelen kritisch te bespreken en schriftelijk te verwoorden;
• vaardigheden ontwikkeld om op basis van theorie en empirie stellingen te formuleren en te beargumenteren.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In deze inleidende cursus van de master Sportbeleid en Sportmanagement staat de relatie tussen het ‘publieke’ sportbeleid en het organiseren en managen van sport centraal. De sport is vanuit een bestuurs- en organisatiewetenschappelijk perspectief een bijzondere sector. Zo wordt sport overwegend georganiseerd door relatief autonome not-for-profit civil society organisaties. Deze organisaties hebben veelal het karakter van een vereniging, die gebaseerd is op een ‘van, voor en door elkaar’ cultuur en sterk leunt op vrijwilligerswerk.

Daarnaast wordt sport in toenemende mate (h)erkend als een maatschappelijk relevante sector met een publieke waarde. Met name overheden richten zich steeds meer op het benutten van die waarde. In plaats van sportstimulering op zichzelf wordt sport tegenwoordig dan ook instrumenteel ingezet in dienst van bredere maatschappelijke ontwikkelingen. De overheid kan die beoogde maatschappelijke benutting van sport niet afdwingen, maar gebruikt allerlei beleidsmiddelen (zoals subsidies) en semi-overheidsorganisaties om dit te realiseren en kan daarin niet om de relatief autonome sportorganisaties heen. Dit leidt tot ‘governance’ vraagstukken en doorkruising van de publieke en private wereld die ook in andere sectoren is te vinden.

Er is één belangrijk verschil: de overheid heeft zich in de afgelopen decennia niet uit de sport teruggetrokken, maar haar sportbeleid juist sterk geïntensiveerd. Tegelijkertijd is het sportbeleid van richting veranderd, met nieuwe partners en nieuwe doelstellingen. Het organiseren en managen van sport in deze institutionele omgeving omvat dynamische en complexe processen en vraagt om externe en interne aanpassingen door bestuurders, managers, professionals en vrijwilligers. Sportorganisaties kunnen zich, ondanks hun eigen karakter, niet autonoom ontwikkelen door de sterke relatie met en afhankelijkheid van de institutionele omgeving waarin zij zijn ingebed. Gestuurde aanpassing c.q. organisatieverandering is dan gebaat bij een analyse van de huidige situatie, ondanks dat iedere verandering vanwege de sterke interne en externe dynamiek een grote mate van onvoorspelbaarheid impliceert.

Voor inzicht in dit multi-actor en multi-level karakter van de sport wordt in deze cursus gebruik gemaakt van concepten als government-governance, beleidsimplementatie, de verhouding tussen overheidslagen (rijk-gemeente), interorganisatorische samenwerking, actor-netwerk, organisatieprincipes (verenigingsleven), organisatieverandering, ambiguïteit, enactment en negotiated order. In de cursus maak je kennis met institutionele en organisatietheorie om de lokale en alledaagse complexiteit van sportbeleid en sportmanagement te begrijpen, te bediscussiëren en daarmee ook nieuwe ideeën over het organiseren van sport te ontwikkelen.
Interactieve colleges worden in deze cursus afgewisseld met gastsprekers, individuele en groepsopdrachten, presentaties en debat.</body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/178730,2017,Publishing: From Manuscript to Bestseller,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. F.D.G. de Glas', 'dr. J.L. Salman']",,"Course goals

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: In this course, students will be introduced to the world of book publishing in the digital age, and will gain thorough knowledge  both with regard to the material as well as the ‘symbolic’ production of texts.  Since the 80s, economies of scale have lead to the emergence of large media conglomerates and internationally strengthened the position of book distribution chains. At the same time, the role of literary agents became more dominant. This has influenced the publication of literary texts. Traditional functions of publishers have been text acquisition, financial risk-taking, text assessment and quality control, sales and marketing. In the course we will step by step follow the process of book publishing and distributing from the viewpoint of the individual publishing house against the backdrop of its legal and economic context.</body>

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: The arrival of the digital text, of electronic ways of distribution and of shifts in the public’s media preferences have overthrown traditional business models in the book publishing world. At the same time, traditional ways of taste-making by qualified and respected literary judges are being challenged by the advent of social media, self-publishing and the ‘cult of the amateur’. In this course, the consequences of these trends will be illustrated and discussed. A number of guest speakers from the world of publishing will be invited to comment on current trends, such as the rise of small-scale publishing initiatives and new approaches in the marketing of texts.

Through the course materials and the lectures by guests with a background in various sections of the book publishing world, students will get an insight of the daily practices and dilemmas in publishing and of the rapid changes which take place in this field  over the past few years.</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/179845,2017,Qualitative Innovation Analytics,English,Faculty of Geosciences,,['dr. A.M. Herrmann'],,Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: The major aims of the course are twofold: One, to introduce students to a systematic approach of starting, pursuing and completing a research project; two, to offer thorough guidelines for completing qualitative research projects of both an inductive and a deductive nature.
More concretely, students completing this course will have learned:

column5: to clearly identify the epistemological foundations underlying their research approach;
to identify a relevant research question;
to embed this question in the appropriate literature;
to define the most important concepts of their research project;
to select the most insightful cases;
to discern the most appropriate empirical material to collect;
to choose appropriate - inductive or deductive - analytical methods
to assess the quality of qualitative research
to design consistent questionnaires for inductive and deductive qualitative research projects;
to interpret the results in the light of the existing literature

column3: in sum: to consistently pursue inductive and deductive qualitative approaches.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Most real-world innovation problems require a systematic analytical approach in order to arrive at efficient solutions. Seeking to provide students with such approaches from a qualitative perspective, the course is divided into three parts:

The first part provides an overview of the epistemological basis underlying inductive and deductive research approaches. It furthermore advises students on how to write a (qualitative) research proposal: When beginning their MSc research project, students often come to a point where they feel ‘lost in the literature jungle’ because they find it hard to identify an appropriate research question and a useful research design. It is therefore the first major objective of this course to show the participants how to avoid such situations of deadlock by introducing them to a systematic approach of starting, pursuing and completing a qualitative research project.

The second part of the course focuses on inductive qualitative research in general and on grounded theory in particular. Students will become familiar with the acquisition and interpretation of qualitative data whenever open-ended research question are asked that require the formulation of propositions rather than clear-cut hypothesis testing. In particular, the quality criteria of inductive qualitative research will be discussed.

The third part of the course focuses on deductive qualitative research, in particular on the selection and assessment of comparative case studies. The various approaches to case selection discussed will illustrate how systematic case comparisons enable the identification of causalities through systematic controls of potential rival explanations.

Consequently, it is the second overarching objective of this course to offer thorough guidelines for completing qualitative research projects of both an inductive and a deductive nature. Using real-world examples, it will be illustrated how such research projects can be translated into theoretical contributions, as well as practical recommendations for managers and policy-makers.
Academic skills: Academic writing; appropriate citation of literature sources; critical assessments of scientific texts; peer-feedback
This course is an entry requirement for: Master’s Thesis IS (GEO4-2239X).</body>
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/182435,2017,Qualitative Inquiry in Everyday Life,English,University College Utrecht,,['dr. L. Balachandran Nair, PhD']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <tbody>

column4: <td>After completing this course, students will be able to:

column5: • Understand and explain the principles of qualitative research methods;
• (a) Outline and (b) apply a qualitative social research strategy;
• Critically evaluate the suitability of a range of qualitative data collection methods for use with different research questions;
• Understand and apply the key elements of quality assessment in qualitative social research methods;
• Select and employ appropriate forms of analysis of different kinds of qualitative data;
• (a) Design and (b) conduct a small-scale qualitative research project;
• Report research findings in a formal format.

column2: </tbody>
<tbody>

column4: <td>In this course, students are assessed 6 times:

column5: • Assignment 1: this tests the ability to write a research proposal (course goals 2(a), 3, and 6(a)).
• Assignment 2: this tests the ability to apply theoretical knowledge in practice by going out into the field (course goals 2(b) and 6(b)).
• Assignment 3: this tests the ability to analyze qualitative data and write a formal research report (course goals 4, 5, 6(b), and 7).
• Written in-class quiz 1: this tests the knowledge and the understanding of qualitative research terminology covered in the first half of the course (course goals 1, 2(a), 2(b), and 3).
• Written in-class quiz 1: this tests the knowledge and the understanding of qualitative research terminology covered in the second half of the course (course goals 1, 4, 5, and 7).
• Presentations: this tests the ability to interpret qualitative research findings and present them to others (course goals 4 and 7).

column2: </tbody>
<head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column4: This methods course fulfils methodology requirements for tracks in ANT, LAW or POL.

The purpose of this course is to equip students to critically design, conduct, report, read, and evaluate qualitative research projects and methodologies, e.g., ethnography, grounded theory and discourse analysis. The course has the dual aim of equipping students with conceptual understandings of different methods and the practical skills to put those methods into practice. This course presents the fundamentals of qualitative research methods. It covers the classic sources of qualitative data, such as interviews, focus groups, and participant observation, and deals with modern sources of data, such as visual materials, internet, and social media. It also discusses data analysis methods, in particular thematic analysis and the integrative procedures that support qualitative data-analysis. The course will train students in understanding the life cycle of a qualitative research project, from design to data collection, analysis, reporting and dissemination.

The course consists of three parts. Each part contains theoretical and practical elements and is finished with an assessment. In the first part qualitative research methods and its backgrounds are introduced. In the second part, the focus will be on the ins and outs of computer-assisted qualitative data-analysis. In the third part the quality of qualitative research is explored as well as the reporting of the outcomes.

column2: </body>

column1:
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/193080,2017,Qualitative Methods,English,University College Roosevelt,,[],,
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/179362,2017,Qualitative Research Methods,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,[],,"Content

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course covers fundamental concepts in qualitative research design, sampling strategies, data generation, data analysis, and evaluation. Course content includes qualitative research methods used in social science research, especially in the management field. Topics include (1) research objectives and contexts appropriate to the use of qualitative methods; (2) theoretical traditions in qualitative research; (3) sampling strategies; (4) intent and techniques for qualitative research methods; and (5) preliminary analysis of qualitative data, selection and use of supporting qualitative and/or quantitative methods, analysis of data and presentation of research results. A set of field-based experiences will be designed to give students opportunities to become familiar with specific forms of qualitative data gathering such as in-depth interviews, focus groups, and ethnography.

This course combines hands-on work on qualitative research projects that will be performed in small groups with background classes on the merits and limitations of qualitative, case based research vis-a-vis other research methods.The aim of the qualitative research project is to design a case study. The problem definition and design of your case study will be made in consultation with the organization at which you will then perform pilot interviews. These interviews will be analyzed to give you experience with qualitative methods of data-analysis. The end purpose is to not only show the merits of qualitative data analysis, but also to learn you to think what method of analysis is fit for what kind of question.
At the end of this course, the student:

column2: • Knows how to distinguish the merits of qualitative research methods from other research methods;
• Is able to write and present a qualitative research for an academic journal;
• Is able to gather qualitative data by means of interview and observation techniques;
• Acquired the ability to use elementary techniques to analyze qualitative data;
• Acquired the ability to evaluate the quality of qualitative research.

column1: This course focuses on the following academic skills:

column2: • Communication skills
<ul>

column3: • ​Being able to present the content of an article or the results of an (instructed) research.
• Being able to write a compact and instructed paper on a specific subject, both individually and in groups.

column2: • Information processing
<ul>

column3: • ​Knowledge of potential sources for literature and data and the skills to explore these independently for a small research project.

column2: • Academic reasoning
<ul>

column3: • ​Being able to design a proper problem definition within the scope and instruction of the course.
• Being able to execute the instructed research design.
• Being able to search and select (additional) sources for the research.
• Being able to execute an instructed empirical research.
• Being able to apply theoretical concepts in research.
• Being able to use correct references (e.g. APA style).
• Being able to draw clear and correct conclusions.

column2: • Social responsibility
<ul>

column3: • ​Being able to work effectively in teams for a specific project with limited intervention or instruction.

column2: • Active participation in class: 10%
• In-class presentations, quality of the debate: 20%
• Late midterm exam - Questions mainly from PeerWise (multiple choice): 20%
• Final written assignment (consisting of 3 parts) and effective teamwork: 50%
• 80% attendance of all tutorials;
• Active participation in the tutorials and project group;
• Preparation for tutorials and project group;
• Timely handing in of research project assignments.

Courses that build on Qualitative Research Methods
The course is a good preparation for writing a qualitative BSc thesis and the masters programmes. </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column5: A qualitative research design is often used when the research focus is on exploration, description, and understanding of a social phenomenon from the perspectives of those being studied. In using qualitative research, we are able to answer the question `Why do certain phenomena happen?’ instead of the question ''Does or doesn’t it happen?'. Qualitative research originated in cultural anthropology is now used in very different areas, such as health care, psychology, criminology, sociology, political sciences, nursing, and educational sciences.

This course is an introduction to qualitative research with a ‘how-to’, practical focus. The structure of the course reflects the research process starting with the generation of a research question, the design, data collection, data-analysis and the writing of a report. In this course you will have the opportunity to dive into the experiences and perspectives of people in a scientific fashion.

column4: This course is taught during the last five weeks of the semester. It uses the same timeslot as the UCACCMET23 group did during the first ten weeks.

column2: </body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177538,2017,Qualitative research methodology,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. J.G. de Kruijf', 'prof. dr. A.C.G.M. Robben']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Advanced understanding of all major aspects of ethnographic fieldwork:
Self-reflection on the fieldwork status during empirical research.
Close understanding of the relation between epistemology and         methodology.
In-depth acquaintance with ethical dilemmas in the field.
Development of oral presentation skills and the chairing of seminar         discussion.

Development of academic writing and research skills through two         critical         essays         on         the         readings         and         one         major         final         essay.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course examines the unique research methodology of ethnographic     fieldwork.     Among     the     key     questions     this     course     tackles     is     the     methodological     progression     from     the     description     and     interpretation     of     everyday     social     semiotics     and     social     relations,     both     from     the     observers'     viewpoint     as     well     as     the     claims     of     those     being     observed,     to     the     identification     of     key     patterns     that     underlie     and     organize     the     meanings     and     social     relations     that     are     observed     or     reported     by     those     being     observed.     Based     on     these     patterns,     ethnographers     make     general     interpretations     or     arguments     about     social     life.     The     intent     is     to     build     a     thorough     foundation     for     understanding     basic     epistemological,     methodological     and     ethical     questions     regarding     the     nature     of     observation,     evidence     and     explanation     through     an     in-depth     reflection     on     the     complex     relation     between     anthropologist     and     informant,     ethical     dilemmas,     epistemological     approaches     and     writing     styles.
An effort is made to schedule seminars on Fridays. For a week-by-week class schedule, please consult the course manual.
Utrecht University has an official course commitment policy. This policy consists of:
80% attendance in seminars (only a maximum of 20% absence is accepted,         irrespective         of         the         reasons).
Handing in papers and assignments on time; and

Overdue papers are downgraded with a one point per day penalty. There     exists     no     collective     possibility     to     resubmit     rewritten     papers.     Only     students     who     have     complied     with     all     commitment     policy     requirements     will     be     given     one     additional     chance     to     submit     a     rewritten     paper     within     three     weeks     after     the     course     ended.     Resubmission     is     not     a     right     of     students     but     a     privilege     given     by     the     course     coordinator     on     a     case-to-case     basis,     and     therefore     require     his     permission.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/180268,2017,Qualitative research methodsMethods of Applied Qualitative Research,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. F. Peeters-Van Wesel'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The aim of the course is to get students acquainted with qualitative research methods in the context of policy, evaluation and effect studies. The focus will be on gaining practical knowledge and skills.. The student will develop hands-on experience with collecting and analyzing data using qualitative research methods. At the end of the course the student:
1.      Can describe the common features of qualitative  research methods and use the right terminology;
2.      Can collect qualitative data using one of the data collecting methods;
3.      Can analyze qualitative data following one of data analysis approaches;
4.      Can conduct a small-scale research project;

In this course students work on assignments throughout the course to acquire skills in conducting a qualitative research project. In the assignments students have to show awareness of the choices to be made in a qualitative research designs and decide what methods can best be used with respect to a specific research question.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course is aimed at students who have no or little experience with qualitative research and who are interested in its practical applications within policy, evaluation and/or effect studies. The course covers:

column2: • The basics of qualitative research: When is this type of research appropriate? How is it different from quantitative research? What are appropriate research questions? How are samples drawn? Etc.
• The introduction of several interactive and non-interactive data collection methods, such as: interviews, focus groups, participant observation, documents, visual materials, etc.
• An introduction to qualitative data-analysis.
• Reporting on qualitative research.

column1: In the seminars several experts in qualitative research, policy, evaluation and/or effect studies will discuss the theory behind the above mentioned aspects of qualitative research methods. Whereas the small-group session will be devotes to gaining the actual hands-on skills. During these meetings students will work on a small-scale qualitative research project within the context of answering policy, evaluation, or effect related research questions.

column3: The aim of the course is to provide students with the ability to understand statistical results presented in the current literature and to have a basic knowledge of how to apply some of the widely used quantitative methods in economic historical research. Overall, the topics covered in the course comprise of:

column5: General introduction to Quantitative Methods in Statistics
Data management
Basic rules on estimation and testing
Regression analysis (univariate and multivariate regression; continuous and categorical covariates)

column3: The students will also be trained in the disciplined use of the command-line interface to SPSS.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: This is an introductory course on quantitative statistics specifically designed for master students of the Posthumus Research Master.

Focusing on aspects of both economic history and social sciences this course will give the students an introduction to using statistics in their own research. The course starts with a general introduction to the basic concepts of quantitative statistics, getting to know historical datasets and how to use historical data to answer research questions. This also includes an introduction to a widely used statistic software (SPSS) to conduct quantitative analyses. The course takes a hands-on-approach: There will be a lecture every week followed by lab hours in which the students can practice what they learned in the lecture, using SPSS. Students will work on (mainly practical) assignments – both assisted during the lab hours and at home.

column2: </body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/179766,2017,Quantitative Urban & Economic Analytics,English,Faculty of Geosciences,,['dr. G.S. Bolt', 'dr. J.S. Crespo Cepas', 'dr. M. Helbich', 'dr. P.M.A. Balland', 'prof. dr. ir. D.F. Ettema']",,"Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column5: Students will be familiarized with a series of quantitative techniques that allow them to do quantitative data analyses such that these analyses may serve as a base for scientific publication. Students will learn about the theoretical backgrounds of these methods as well as learn how to carry out the analyses on existing data using state-of-the-art software packages.
Students will learn how to apply advanced quantitative methods as part of a study design, with the broader aim of answering a specific research question.

column2: </body>

column3: The course will consist of a series of lectures on specific techniques, followed a few days later by a computer practical where the techniques are practiced on a given data set. The techniques addressed in this course include:

column5: Linear regression
Logistic regression and ordered logit models
Multi-level analysis
Factor analysis
Cluster analysis
Network analysis

column3: The last two weeks of the course, students will  work on a loosely structured assignment, in which they answer a research question based on a given data set. The assignment includes choice of the appropriate technique(s), the appropriate variables, interpretation of the results and reporting all this in a working paper. Results will be presented  in a seminar, where feedback is given by peers and supervisor.</body>

<body>

column3: At the end of the course the student will be able to:

column5: present an overview of quantitative regional and local water management issues, with focus on drainage (Dutch topic) and design and management of reservoirs (international topic);
perform calculations that promote understanding c.q. proper application of current theory and practice in the above mentioned fields;
appreciate different visions and occasional conflicts between the theory and practice of regional and local water management;
reflect on current and future developments in quantitative water management in the context of global change.

<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column5: Groundwater drainage: Donnan, Hooghoudt and beyond.
Groundwater drainage practice in The Netherlands: agricultural vs. urban areas.
Urban stormwater drainage and the urban water assignment: pluvial flooding and sewer management, flooding from regional surface waters, and governance issues.
Side effects of drainage: downstream flooding, land subsidence, salinization and operational water resources management, ecohydrological drought, and foundation damage.
Reservoir management and irrigation: basics of irrigation scheduling, hydrological change and sustainable reservoir planning and management.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/183771,2017,Quantum Nano wereld,Dutch,Faculty of Science,,['dr. F.T. Rabouw', 'prof. dr. C. de Morais Smith']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Na afloop van de cursus is de student
1. vertrouwd met de basisprincipes van de kwantummechanica, zoals golf–deeltjesdualiteit (de Broglie) en de onzekerheidsrelatie (Heisenberg)
2. in staat uit te leggen hoe golf–deeltjesdualiteit zich manifesteert aan de hand van fenomenen als warmtestraling (Planck), diffractie en het foto-elektrisch effect.
3. bekend met de Schrödingervergelijking en in staat hieruit golffuncties op te lossen voor simpele geometrieën, waaronder het deeltje-in-een-doosje en de eindige energiebarrière.
4. in staat uit te leggen hoe kwantummechanische verschijnselen, zoals discrete energiespectra, de eigenschappen bepalen van materialen op de nanoschaal.
5. in staat uit te leggen hoe kwantummechanische verschijnselen, zoals golf–deeltjesdualiteit en tunneling, worden gebruikt om materie op de nanoschaal te onderzoeken en karakterizeren.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
In dit vak worden de basisprincipes van de kwantummechanica behandeld en hoe deze van belang zijn voor de eigenschappen en karakterisering van nanomaterialen.
Aan bod komen de manifestaties van golf–deeltjesdualiteit die aan de basis hebben gestaan van de ontwikkeling van de kwantummechanica.
De Schrödingervergelijking voor kwantummechanische golffuncties wordt geïntroduceerd en opgelost voor een aantal modelsystemen.
Besproken wordt hoe kwantummechanica en golf–deeltjesdualiteit essentieel is voor de eigenschappen van materie op de nanoschaal.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column4: Quantum field theories emerged from the confluence of quantum mechanics and special relativity, and provide an amazingly accurate theoretical framework for describing the behaviour of subatomic particles and forces. This course will give an introduction into quantum field theory, both conceptually and technically. Canonical and covariant quantization methods will be discussed, with an emphasis on the path integral formulation, which finds manifold applications in both particle physics and condensed matter systems. Topics covered include the quantum-mechanical path integral, the quantization of bosonic and fermionic fields, functional techniques involving generating functionals and correlators, and perturbation theory in terms of Feynman diagrams.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>To give students an overview and understanding of:

column2: • Climate changes that occurred during the Quaternary across a range of timescales, with the focus on the period since the last interglacial,
• The most important records and methods used in reconstructing the climate of the Quaternary,
• Dating methods for Quaternary records,
• Forcing factors of the climate - both natural and anthropogenic,
• Mechanisms and internal controls of Quaternary climate, with focus on glacial, coastal and terrestrial environments,
• Sea level: glacial-interglacial changes, Holocene rise and future levels,
• Recent climate change: natural and anthropogenic causes,
• Scenarios of future climate change.

column1: Futhermore, students will be able to read and analyse scientific datasets in the field of climate change, and perform recombination exercises with this.</body>

column1: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/184772,2017,RF in MRI TU/Eindhoven,English,Faculty of Medicine,,[],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After completing the course the student will have profound understanding of:

column2: • RF circuit technology (e.g. transmission lines, Smith Chart, impedance matching)
• RF coils and antennas in MRI (e.g. birdcage coils, loop coils and dipole antennas)
• RF fields in MRI (B1+ field, B1- field, E-field and the forthcoming SAR distribution)
• How these fields translate into MRI performance metrics (e.g. SNR, noise correlation, optimal reconstruction, g-factor distribution)

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
PLEASE NOTE THAT THIS COURSE IS TAUGHT IN EINDHOVEN
The course will cover all aspects of RF in MRI. The course can be divided in four parts:

To generate RF fields with a RF coil or antenna, the coil or antenna needs to be driven with high power (~kw) RF signals. In the receive phase of the MRI sequence, the spins in the tissue will emit signals that will be detected by the RF coil. The coil will transform these signals into electrical RF signals and sent them to the ADC. The course will give an in-depth treatment of the generation and transportation of these signals. For this purpose, the following concepts will be covered: impedance calculations, RF amplifier classes, transmission lines, Smith Chart, scatter matrices, transmit-receive switches. (2 lectures)
The second part focuses at the coil or antenna. The most-often used types will be covered (loop coil, birdcage coil, dipole antenna and arrays). (1 lecture)

The third part will focus at the fields that are generated by the coil or antenna. The B1 field consists of B1+ en B1-, one only useful for the transmit phase, the other only useful for the receive phase of the MRI sequence. In addition, every coil or antenna also generates (or is sensitive for) electrical fields. These are responsible for energy deposition (SAR) and, in receive, noise. (2 lectures)

The third and last part will cover how relevant metrics of MRI performance can be calculated from (for example simulated) field distributions of RF antenna arrays, such as SNR, noise correlation, optimal reconstructions and g-factor distributions. (2 lectures)
Please register at TU/e, course code 8DM30, at least 2 weeks before start of the course. Osiris registration will be done retroactively when results from the TU/e are received.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: Writing your research master thesis can be a lonely process, therefore the thesis lab aims to bring together students during the full development process of their RMA thesis to discuss any problems they might be having (or successes they’ve had) in an informal setting. The aims of the thesis lab are to
• Stimulate exchange and intervision among students;
• Provide feedback and advice on general issues;
• Help students plan ahead (although completion of the thesis on time remains the students sole responsibility).
The thesis lab does not replace individual supervision by the thesis supervisor, but complements it. </body>

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: Six meetings will be scheduled every three weeks, starting in February 2015.  The first half of each meeting is devoted to exchange and intervision in groups of three to four students. Students will briefly present the texts they have sent round and receive comments in the form of a discussion between the author and the group. During the second hour, general issues arising from the discussions in the first hour will be discussed.
At the latest three days in advance students hand in the text they wish to discuss. For this there are two options, you can send in a section of your thesis or a summary in which they present:
• A report on their progress regarding the part of the thesis to be discussed. Main question: is it finished (i.e. the first version) and if not, why not?
• An abstract of this part of the thesis (ca. 300 words). The aim is to inform the other students and teachers briefly on the essence, not to give all the details.
• One or more question or issues students are struggling with, rising from the work that has been done.

The documents are important to have something to discuss and give concrete feedback on but they should not prove a hurdle to participation. If you are struggling all the more reason to send something so we can discuss it even if it’s not complete.

column2: </body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/178887,2017,RMA Thesis Media, Art and Performance Studies",English,Faculty of Humanities,,"['dr. M.J. Kattenbelt', 'dr. N. Verhoeff', 'dr. S. Werning', 'prof. dr. F.E. Kessler', 'prof. dr. M.A. Bleeker']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After completion of the thesis trajectory, the student is capable to
A) demonstrate the necessary analytical and writing skills to conduct independent scholarly research and present a theoretically sound and developed argument in Media, Art & Performance Studies;
B) give a clear description and justification of, and to present and use in practice a methodological and theoretical framework relevant for the central research questions;
C) formulate clearly the central research question(s) or problem(s) of the thesis and present a convincing answer to it in the thesis;
D) critically position oneself in the scholarly debate and to contribute to this debate by producing new scholarly knowledge, presented to fellow researchers in the required academic form.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The individual thesis trajectory is supervised by a staff member of the program. The thesis will be evealuated by the supervisor and a second assessor appointed by the the programme coordinator.

An  RMA thesis is a scholarly developed research project in which the student is expected to contribute, on the basis of independent research, to a debate within the discipline. It should be structured around a central research question (set out in the introductory sections) to which it provides a response and thereby offers a contribution to existing scholarship (made explicit and reflected upon in the individual chapters and conclusion).

The central research question must be clearly formulated in the thesis and its relevance to scholarly discussions within the discipline has to be shown. The body of the text should give a clear description and justification of the methodological and theoretical framework that is used to develop the response(s) to the research question. In the conclusion, you should evaluate your findings in the light of the research questions and the broader implications of these conclusions.
The thesis should be written in correct and clear English; it has a length of about 30.000 words  and should not exceed 40.000 words (including notes and bibliography).
The individual thesis trajectory is supervised by a staff member of the program. The thesis will be evaluated by the supervisor and a second assessor appointed by the the programme coordinator.
For more information and guidelines see the program book and student webpages at https://students.uu.nl/en/hum/maps/</body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/178265,2017,Racism in the Western World: A Cultural History,Dutch, English",Faculty of Humanities,,"['dr. J. Verheul', 'J.W. van der Jagt', 'T. Lobbes']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course offers an intensive introduction to the historical development of ideas about ethnicity, race and racism in the Western world. Students will gain insight into the cultural processes that feed into constructions of race and ethnicity and learn to turn a critical lens on scientific concepts such as racism, racial boundaries, multiculturalism, discrimination, othering and whiteness.

Course participants will also be instructed in the techniques of the historian's craft: finding and selecting literature, assessing texts, critically analysing sources and working with historical concepts such as ethnicity, racism and discrimination.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Though racism is mainly associated with the colonial slave experience and genocide in the Second World War, it has a much longer history that also ripples through to our own world today. This course studies the history of racism in the West from the Enlightenment to the present day. Our main focus is on the way in which ideas about race and ethnicity have evolved as categories of differentiation, hierarchy and exclusion. Students will research the complex interactions between these cultural constructs and the historical dimensions of nationalism, colonialism, imperialism and globalisation in Western history. The development of racism in Europe will be considered from an international and comparative perspective, in part through the study of colonial and transatlantic experiences of slavery and migration, as well as by researching the worldwide spread of ideals of equality, human rights and civil rights. In addition, we will look at how scientific and pseudoscientific constructs of racism, social Darwinism and eugenics were modelled from the nineteenth century onwards to legitimise differentiation and selection on the basis of racial characteristics. Finally, this course will investigate how knowledge of this controversial past can offer a framework for understanding current discussions about race and ethnicity.
Please note: The lectures of this course are in English. If there is only one seminar group, discussions will also be entirely in English.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
PLEASE NOTE THAT THIS COURSE IS TAUGHT IN EINDHOVEN

In this course the basic notions from atom and nuclear physics are treated. From atomic physics we will discuss: waves and particles, atom models of Rutherford and Bohr, the Schrödinger equation, quantum numbers, x-rays and x-ray tubes. From nuclear physics we will discuss: structure and elementary properties of the nucleus, chart of nuclides, binding energies, atom masse, Q-values, radioactivity with alpha beta and gamma decay.
Material for study and exercises are available during lectures; Modern physics by Kenneth Krane, 3<sup>rd</sup> edition (recommended)

W.F. Wiersma, PhD, head of the training centre/tutor in Utrecht, NCSV
This course can be followed in English and in Dutch. Go to  the website for detailed information.
The radiation safety course 5B level is open to MSc students who need it for their research project. You must have permission from your supervisor and your programme coordinator.

Please note: Because this course is expensive, you need to fill the rest of your elective component with modules which are free of extra costs. The costs of the radiation safety course at level 4B will not be reimbursed.

The course Health Physics expert level 5B is meant for radiation experts in situations where radioactive sources with a low risk of exposure are used. The course offers a useful introduction in working with ionizing radiation for all kinds of radiation workers, such as laboratory personnel, technical staff, medical personnel and workers in industry. Because of the diversity in work environment of the participants, the course will not focus on one specific radioisotope.

A Virtual Learning Environment (VLE) is used for this course. Participants will have to study before the start of the training. This can be done independently and all students are fee to choose their own study moments.
The course level 5B is open to MSc students who will have to work with radioactive material during their research project. You must have permission from your supervisor and your program coordinator.
The exam consists of 50 multiple choice questions. After passing this exam, you will receive the certificate Health Physics expert level 5B and are allowed to work independently with radioisotopes.
The courses will be taught at the Ornstein Laboratory, Princetonplein 1, De Uithof, Utrecht.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After completing the course the student understands:

column2: • the basics concepts of the linear accelerator and the generation of  X-ray’s
• the photon and electron interactions with matter important for radiotherapy
• the physical aspects of photon beams
• the principles of dosimetry
• the concepts of clinically applied dose calculations algorithms and optimization algorithms
• the concepts of IMRT and  VMAT
• the origin of geometrical uncertainties on various time scales
• the various types of adaptive radiotherapy (offline, online and real time)
• the effect of the magnetic field on the dose distribution
• the effect of the magnetic field on the measurement
• the need for MRI-only planning and fast dose calculation
• the workflow needed for online MRI guided radiotherapy

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Dr C.P.J. Raaijmakers, UMC Utrecht/Imaging Division, lecturer
Dr B. van Asselen, UMC Utrecht/Imaging Division, lecturer
This course covers practical and theoretical aspects on medical physics in the field of radiotherapy.
First the basic radiation physics will be discussed: e.g.
production of radiation, radioactive decay, characteristics of ionizing radiation, interaction with matter and measurement of absorbed dose.
The next part covers the essentials of dose calculation using various algorithms and dose optimization such as Intensity modulated therapy (IMRT) and volumetric arc therapy (VMAT).

Third topic is image guided radiotherapy (IGRT): e.g. inter- and intrafraction motion, position verification devices (electronic portal imaging device, cone-beam CT and MRI), real time imaging and various methods to deal with motion.
Finally topics in the field of MRI guided treatment will be discussed: e.g. dose delivery in magnetic fields, MRI linac design, workflow and plan adaptation.

column2: • Written exam: 65%; attendance to the practical work is obligatory to qualify for examination
• Oral presentation and discussion: 35%

column1: The weights indicated above are applied to calculate the final mark. To pass the course the grade for each component must be a 5.0 or higher and the final mark must be an unrounded 5.5 or higher. (Anglo-Saxon grade mark D)

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/179603,2017,Reactive transport in the hydrosphere,English,Faculty of Geosciences,,['dr. L. Polerecky'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course introduces and applies the concepts and methods needed to quantitatively describe the coupling of (bio)geochemical reactions to transport processes in the various compartments of the hydrosphere.
By the end of the course, students will

column2: • have a general understanding of concepts and methods needed to quantitatively describe (bio)geochemical reactions and transport processes in various compartments of the hydrosphere;
• be able to formulate models (conceptually and with mathematical equations) to describe transport and reactions in Earth's surface environments;
• be able to solve simple models analytically and more complex models numerically using appropriate modeling software (R, with relevant packages such as ReacTran, deSolve);
• be able to fit data with a model, and interpret the results of the models in the relevant context (e.g., geochemical processes in rivers, lakes, aquifers, sediments, oceans);
• be able to report the results in written and oral form.

column1: The course will also help develop the following transferable skills:

column2: • Ability to work in a team: Practical exercises and final projects will be done in teams of two students. Students will need to distribute the tasks, organize and execute the workflow, share responsibility for presentation of the results.
• Written communication skills: Assignments and final projects will be presented as reports. Feedback will be given after each report, allowing students to improve.
• Verbal communication skills: Results of the final projects will also be presented orally. Students will receive feedback on the quality of their presentations.

• Analytical/quantitative skills: Throughout the course students will solve quantitative tasks using analytical and numerical methods. They will also interpret their results in the wider context of environmental biogeochemistry.
• Strong work ethic: students will be required to follow fixed deadlines for delivering assignments and results of their final projects.

• Technical skills: students will write their own code to solve models. This will develop their programming skills in the programming language R. Preparation of written reports and oral presentation will help them develop skills in programs used for word processing and slide shows.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Basics of model formulation (from conceptual diagrams to differential equations)
• Introduction to R (focus on deSolve and ReacTran packages)
• Spatial components and parameterization
• Model solution (analytical vs. numerical methods)
• Stability and feedback analysis
• Regression analysis (fitting of data by a model)

• be able to report the results in written and oral form.

column1: The course will also help develop the following transferable skills:

column2: • Ability to work in a team: Practical exercises and final projects will be done in teams of two students. Students will need to distribute the tasks, organize and execute the workflow, share responsibility for presentation of the results.
• Written communication skills: Assignments and final projects will be presented as reports. Feedback will be given after each report, allowing students to improve.
• Verbal communication skills: Results of the final projects will also be presented orally. Students will receive feedback on the quality of their presentations.

• Analytical/quantitative skills: Throughout the course students will solve quantitative tasks using analytical and numerical methods. They will also interpret their results in the wider context of environmental biogeochemistry.
• Strong work ethic: students will be required to follow fixed deadlines for delivering assignments and results of their final projects.

column1: Technical skills: students will write their own code to solve models. This will develop their programming skills in the programming language R. Preparation of written reports and oral presentation will help them develop skills in programs used for word processing and slide shows.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After completing this course, students are able to:

column2: • discuss the interaction between actors, institutions and markets in general and applied to real estate in particular;
• distinguish and summarise different types of real estate markets and their geographical dimensions;
• evaluate the way government interventions (such as urban planning) affect the working of real estate markets;
• analyse specific markets in their geographical setting by using the acquired knowledge;
• assess and evaluate actual real estate market outcomes such as prices, affordability and vacancies

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Most human activities such as living, working, learning and relaxing take place in ‘real estate’ such as homes, schools, offices and shops. Real estate provision therefore follows the preferences and needs of these human activities. However, the users of real estate are not the only ones who determine where, when and how much real estate is provided, and at what price. Real estate developers, (institutional) investors, banks, housing associations and local authorities play a very important and often dominant role in such decisions. They play the game of real estate along different and sometimes conflicting formal and informal rules (i.e. institutions). For us, academics concerned with the spatial distribution of human activities, it is crucial to understand how real estate provision takes place. Or to put it plainly: how does something that gets built get built? This central question is addressed and reflected upon in the module. We particularly look at the interaction between different actors and institutions within different markets and market segments.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: Wie tegenwoordig als informaticus gaat werken, wordt haast onvermijdelijk met juridische vragen geconfronteerd. Automatiseringsprojekten worden vastgelegd in kontrakten, en als er iets misgaat, rijst de vraag wie aansprakelijk is. Het internet maakt nieuwe vormen van zakendoen (e-commerce) mogelijk, die om nieuwe vormen van juridische bescherming vragen. Ook maakt het internet grootschalige vormen van misbruik en criminaliteit mogelijk: denk aan het uitwisselen van software en digitale muziek, maar ook van kinderporno of racistisch materiaal. Tenslotte laten internetgebruikers vele digitale sporen na, wat vragen oproept omtrent de privacybeschermning.

Daarnaast wordt de ICT steeds vaker en grootschaliger ingezet in het recht en het openbaar bestuur. Zo wordt het kontakt tussen burger en overheid steeds meer digitaal (e-democracy, e-government), en wordt ICT steeds vaker ingezet bij de ondersteuning van rechtspraak, wetsuitvoering en advocatuur, in de vorm van bijvoorbeeld databanken, kennissystemen, en 'case management' systemen. Juridische geschillen over e-commerce kunnen tegenwoordig soms zelfs on-line uitgevochten worden. Tenslotte kan ICT zorgen voor technische bescherming van juridische rechten, zoals bij 'digital rights management'.

In het eerste (en grootste) deel van dit vak zullen juridische aspecten van informatica behandeld worden, zoals aansprakelijkheid bij automatiseringsprojekten en van internetproviders, digitale kontrakten, intellectuele eigendom van software en digitale informatie, computercriminaliteit, en privacybescherming. Dit deel heeft tot doel om de student bewust te maken van de juridische kwesties waarmee een informaticus in de beroepspraktijk geconfronteerd kan worden.

In het tweede (kleinere) deel maakt de student kennis met de voornaamste informaticatoepassingen in het recht en het openbaar bestuur. Doel van dit deel is om te laten zien hoe de informatica ingezet kan worden bij het reguleren van de samenleving, inclusief het bevorderen van democratie en goed bestuur.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
In deze cursus staan een aantal centrale thema’s uit de rechtsfilosofie centraal

De hoorcolleges bieden een chronologisch overzicht van een aantal klassieke theorieën van ‘grote’ denkers over recht en rechtvaardigheid. De stof van de hoorcolleges wordt getoetst door middel van een schriftelijk tentamen dat vóór de kerst zal worden afgenomen.

In de werkcolleges worden oorspronkelijke teksten gelezen. Studenten krijgen zo de gelegenheid om uit de eerste hand kennis te nemen van het denken van één filosoof. Door middel van een paper wordt getoetst of studenten zich het denken van de bestudeerde filosoof voldoende eigen hebben gemaakt. De paper moet op een nader bekend te maken tijdstip in januari worden ingeleverd.

- C.W. Maris, F.CL.M. Jacobs (red.), Recht, Orde en Vrijheid, 3e druk, Deventer 2011, waaruit nader aan te geven delen bestudeerd dienen te worden, eventueel in samenhang met op Blackboard aan te kondigen teksten.
- De voorgeschreven tekst(en) van de te behandelen filosoof.
- Ian Curry-Sumner e.a. Onderzoeksvaardigheden. Instructie voor juristen, 1e druk, Ars Aequi Libri 2010.
De te behandelen filosofen zullen vóór de openstelling van de inschrijving bekend gemaakt worden. Informatie hierover wordt te zijner tijd op Blackboard geplaatst.
Filosofen die in 2016-2017 zijn behandeld: Aristoteles (Ethica Nicomachea), Hugo de Groot (Recht van Oorlog en Vrede), Mill (On Liberty en hoofdstuk uit Utilitarianism)
Voor het volgen van de cursus Rechtsfilosofie gelden de regels die zijn neergelegd in het document Cursusinformatie Rechtsfilosofie 2017-2018 dat op Blackboard te vinden zal zijn.
Niet in het examenprogramma in te brengen naast RGBOR0400 Rechtsfilosofie.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • heeft de student overzicht van het Romeinse vermogensrecht als belangrijke oorsprong van het hedendaagse recht.
• heeft de student kennis van en inzicht in verschillende tradities binnen het Europese Ius Commune.
• heeft de student kennis van en inzicht in een aantal belangrijke ontwikkelingen in inhoud en methodologie van de voornaamste vermogensrechtelijke leerstukken.

• heeft de student zich geoefend in bronnen, methoden en de inhoud van jurisdicties uit de civiele traditie, de common law traditie en enige van gemengde aard. Daarbij komen vaardigheden voor het hedendaagse recht zoals het oplossen van casus, argumenteren aan de hand van de verschillende rechtsbronnen (als jurisprudentie), aan de orde.
• kan de student zijn kennis van de tradities en de veranderingen toepassen in de vergelijkende analyse van het hedendaagse vermogensrecht.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

De cursus biedt reflectie op de ontwikkeling van de voornaamste leerstukken uit het hedendaagse vermogensrecht. Na introductie van rechtsbronnen en rechtspraktijk in de Romeinse samenleving worden beginselen van het Romeinse vermogensrecht behandeld. Van daaruit worden aspecten uit de rechtsontwikkeling sedertdien betrokken. Zo wordt ons vermogensrecht in het temporele perspectief van de Romeinsrechtelijke – civiele – traditie geplaatst. Daarbij komen andere rechtsstelsels (als Frankrijk, Duitsland, Engeland, Schotland en Zuid-Afrika) nadrukkelijk aan de orde. De ontwikkelingsgeschiedenis is zeer relevant voor het hedendaagse vergelijkende vermogensrecht. Uit het algemene vermogensrecht, zakenrecht, verbintenissenrecht, en het erfrecht worden een aantal onderwerpen gekozen.

Een overzicht van het Romeinse recht als oorsprong van onze regels geeft systematisch houvast bij de vergelijkende analyse van het Nederlandse vermogensrecht. Veel andere nationale stelsels – zelfs het Engelse – maken veel meer expliciet gebruik van concepten of maximes ontleend aan het Romeinse recht. Hedendaagse rechtsvergelijkende studies – met name die vragen naar Europese juridische uniformiteit centraal stellen, maken daarvan eveneens gebruik – zie bijvoorbeeld de publicaties van Zimmermann.

De ontwikkelingsgeschiedenis van vermogensrechtelijke leerstukken laat de grote verscheidenheid van de tradities in het recht zien. Het laat zien dat het Romeinse recht door de eeuwen heen telkens meer of minder aanwending vond, naast lokale rechten, geschreven of ongeschreven, canoniek recht en natuurrecht. Het laat ook zien dat de praktijk - de sociale, politieke, economisch context - vaak de grote aanjager is van bij het oude blijven, ontwikkeling (evolutie) of zelf omwenteling (revolutie), ook in het recht.

De ontwikkelingsgeschiedenis van het vermogensrecht geeft inzicht in de veranderingen in de formele juridische bronnen, in de gebruikte rechtsvindingsmethoden, geeft inzicht in de veranderingen in concepten, systematiek, argumenten en oordelen, en de achterliggende redenen.

In de gang naar het heden wordt stilgestaan bij een aantal belangrijke scholen in de rechtsbeoefening. Het Rooms-Hollandse recht zal aandacht krijgen, want dat recht heeft grote invloed gehad in de wording van het Europese commune privaatrecht en is geëxporteerd naar Zuid-Afrika en andere jurisdicties. Evenzeer aandacht krijgt de Duitse historische school en de pandektistiek waarbij Romeins recht voor het negentiende eeuwse Duitse landen werd gesystematiseerd en toegepast. De civiele traditie heeft zich op het Europese continent vertaald in codificaties – aandacht krijgen de Franse, Duitse en de Nederlandse, terwijl diezelfde civiele traditie zonder codificatie maar met een op Romeins recht geënt paradigma voorwaarts gaat in de Schotse jurisdictie.

In het hier en nu moeten we constateren dat – terecht of ten onrechte – het privaatrecht in meer of mindere mate onderworpen wordt aan normen van constitutionele en mensenrechtelijke aard. Dat is met name in Zuid Afrika opmerkelijk. Nu we een indruk hebben waar we vandaan komen, kunnen we beter onderlegd vragen: quo vadis?
Niet in het examenprogramma in te brengen naast RGBOR0500 Rechtsgeschiedenis.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

De cursus Rechtspraktijk strafrecht is erop gericht studenten vertrouwd te maken met een aantal vaardigheden die voor de in de praktijk werkzame strafrechtjurist belangrijk zijn. De bedoeling van de cursus is om de bij de eerder gevolgde strafrecht cursussen opgedane juridische kennis te verdiepen en te leren toepassen in een praktijksituatie. Primair wordt daartoe een eenvoudig strafdossier uitgereikt waaraan schriftelijke opdrachten zijn verbonden. Voorts vormt het strafdossier het aanknopingspunt voor het requisitoir/pleidooi dat ter afsluiting van de cursus door iedere student wordt gehouden ten overstaan van een praktijkjurist. Daarnaast dient nog een aantal subopdrachten te worden gemaakt ter voorbereiding op de casus. Gedurende de hele cursus wordt intensief samengewerkt met een medestudent.
Deelname aan de eerste werkgroep is verplicht; bij afwezigheid volgt uitsluiting van de cursus.
Niet in het examenprogramma in te brengen naast RGBOR0551 Rechtspraktijk strafrecht.
