<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Students may choose to do a research internship instead of study abroad in periods 1 and 2 of year 2. They may choose between a research internship of 15 ECTS (420 hours) or 20 ECTS (560 hours). The aim of this internship is to learn how to apply research skills in practice, to develop organizational and communication skills, and to get to know organizations like research institutes, museums or governmental agencies.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The internship assignment can be manifold, but needs to have the academic level belonging to a Research Master’s degree. Importantly, this implies that the student will have to independent, individual research. The supervisor from the UU will check whether the internship plan fits with the aims of the Master’s programme.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/178623,2017,Research Internship New Media & Digital Culture,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. I.M. Hoofd', 'dr. I.O. de Vries', 'dr. J.F. van Vught', 'dr. J.F.F. Raessens', 'dr. K.F. van Es', 'dr. M.A.J. Glas', 'dr. M.L. de Lange', 'dr. M.T. Schaefer', 'dr. S. Werning', 'drs. L. Tax', 'N. Kerssens']",,"Course goals

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: After completing this course, students will have acquired knowledge and skills to employ and critically assess practices in the field of new media against a theoretical background. The internship enables students to integrate theoretical knowledge with actual practices in the professional field and develop knowledge and skills necessary to successfully enter that field after graduation.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Various (PhD) researchers are invited into the course, which adds to insight and knowledge of current developments in the workfield.

The MA internship gives you the opportunity to test actual new media practices against new media theory. During a period of three months you will work within a company, a governmental, educational, cultural organization, an NGO or any other place where new media play a significant role, and you will be asked to reflect upon your activities by producing an internship research report, based on a carefully designed research proposal. This report should be the result of a critical analysis of the working experience from an academic perspective.

The research internship provides you with opportunities par excellence to get acquainted with the processes and discourses of the working field of new media; it is where you test your academic and professional skills, and where you build networks that help you find a job after you have graduated.</body>
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/178936,2017,Research Internship in Philosophy,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['Docent(en) van de opleiding (GW)'],,Course goals

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: The goals of a research internship are:
• to become familiar with possible research professions and to participate in the process of doing philosophical research within an organization or research project;
• to gain experience applying the knowledge and/or skills learned during your studies in a practical context;
• to expand your mastery of methods and knowledge employed in the context of the research.

column2: </body>
<head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: In a research internship, you either carry out research on behalf of an organization or active participation in research project, typically at Utrecht University.  Typically, this involves doing archival research, assisting in the preparation of a grant application, helping to prepare a manuscript, book or special issue for publication,

or surveying philosophical literature as part of a research project. Other activities are possible.  The area of the research should broadly philosophical and a clear research component, as assessed by the supervising instructor. The specific tasks are specified, before the start of the course, in a workplan.

Internships always involve two supervisors: the “internship supervisor” (in the case of research internships, the person which whose research you are assisting) and the “supervising lecturer” (another staff member in the RMA Philosophy programme), who is responsible for (1) ensuring that the internship activities meet the objectives of an academic internship and (2) determining the final grade, in consultation with the internship supervisor.  You will work closely with the internship supervisor throughout the internship and check in periodically with the supervising lecture regarding your progress. A concluding meeting of you, the supervising instructor, and the internship instructor to discuss the final report is recommended by not required.

More information can be found in the RMA Philosophy Handbook and in the “Internship Regulations: Guidebook for Students” (see http://students.uu.nl/sites/default/files/hum_general_internship_regulations.pdf )</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/178646,2017,Research Lab 1: Situating Research,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. M.L. de Lange', 'T. de Winkel']",,"Course goals

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: At the end of this module, students will have learned which method may serve which types of research questions, and will be able to assess the ethical and practical viability of each such method. They will also have grasped which methods (and their implied epistemological traditions and theoretical underpinnings) will be appropriate for pursuing their own individual research interest. Students will have learned how to express all these aspects of the methodology trajectory in oral and written form, by way of participating in in-class debate, of a group presentation, and of a written methodology assignment.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This module will re-introduce students to the methods and methodologies that are viable in the field of new media studies in the humanities at Utrecht University. On top of this, students wil engage in meta-reflection about the conceptual underpinnings these methods; ie. they will learn about the traditions, assumptions and the explicit or implicit connections with certain new media theories in the humanities that are taught in the concomitant New Media Theories module. In connection with learning to identify the assumptions and traditions behind these methods, students will learn to assess the possible ethical issues involved in the application of each individual method and the justification in light of research ethics when formulating a methodology or research question.
This module aims to teach students advanced academic professionalisation skills, and therefore will incorporate many key examples and case studies from the academic working field.</body>
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/178649,2017,Research Lab 2: Designing Research,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. I.O. de Vries', 'T. de Winkel']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

At the end of this module, students will have learned how to write a full-fledged research proposal. They will also have learned how to assess, critique, and edit academic work by their peers, as well as how to provide and process constructive feedback in a classroom, workshop or conference setting. Students will also have acquired at least one of the skills related to the organisational aspects of facilitating a workshop or conference.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This module will focus on the development of academic competencies related to achieving a level of professionalisation that is indicative for any starting academic researcher. In this module, students will learn how to write an individual research proposal which can serve as the foundation for their internship and/or thesis research. The module will teach students to formulate appropriate research questions, methods and methodologies; combine such methods with the appropriate theoretical framework, as well as think through the ethical implications of such methods. It will also incorporate various forms of academic professionalisation like acting as a graduate journal editorial board, pitching an abstract for a journal CfP, and setting up a conference or workshop in the field of new media studies.
This module aims to teach students advanced academic professionalisation skills, and therefore will incorporate many key examples and case studies from the academic working field.</body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/178624,2017,Research Lab FTV 1,Dutch,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. A.W.T. van der Velden', 'dr. H.B. Surma', 'dr. K.F. van Es', 'dr. L.T. Copier', 'dr. W. Sanders']",,"Course goals

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: Kennis van en inzicht in de onderzoekscyclus van mediawetenschappelijk onderzoek; kennis van en inzicht in verschillende methodes om data voor mediawetenschappelijk onderzoek te verzamelen; kennis van en inzicht in verschillende methodes om bronnen te analyseren; vaardigheden om verschillende soorten bronnen te verzamelen, te analyseren en hierop kritisch te reflecteren.</body>

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: In deze cursus leren studenten verschillende methodes gebruiken om bronnen voor een mediawetenschappelijk onderzoek te verzamelen, te analyseren, en op deze kritisch te reflecteren.    </body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/178642,2017,Research Lab FTV 2,Dutch,Faculty of Humanities,,['D.A. Hassler-Forest', 'dr. A.W.T. van der Velden', 'dr. H.B. Surma', 'dr. L.T. Copier', 'dr. N. Verhoeff', 'J. Keilbach']",,"Course goals

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: Doel van deze cursus is het ontwikkelen van een mediawetenschappelijke onderzoeksvraag t.a.v. een zelfgekozen onderwerp en het uitwerken van een onderzoeksopzet. Studenten doen hiervoor zelfstandig onderzoek naar relevante academische literatuur en geschikt bronnenmateriaal. Studenten doen kennis op van, en verkrijgen inzicht in het academisch debat omtrent dit onderwerp, en kunnen deze helder samenvatten.   </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Studenten doen literatuuronderzoek over een zelf gekozen onderwerp. Er wordt een mediawetenschappelijk onderzoeksvraag geformuleerd en een onderzoeksopzet uitgewerkt die in een vervolgstap tot een onderzoekspaper uitgewerkt zou kunnen worden.

In deze cursus verdiepen studenten hun professionele onderzoeksvaardigheden en versterken zij hun communicatieve vaardigheden om bevindingen mondeling en schriftelijk helder samen te vatten en duidelijk en ondubbelzinnig aan een publiek van specialisten en niet-specialisten over te brengen.</body>
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/178632,2017,Research Lab I: Doing Gender,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. E. Midden'],,Course goals

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: After completion of this course, the student has learned to:
A) work with the imprtortant aspects of genderstudies, such as critical reading, collecting and analysing data
B) practice with doing fieldwork/empirical research
C) to start up a research and use the library

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course starts with the yearly NOISE Summerschool (a small contribution to the NOI♀SE programme will have to be paid). After the thematically focused introduction to the course via the summerschool the course continues to train students in the basic building blocks of doing interdisciplinary feminist research: critical reading, collecting data/ building a corpus of texts, objects or phenomena, analyzing and writing. The course offers students the opportunity to map their fields of interest and makes them acquainted with empirical research/fieldwork. The course focusses on ‘doing gender’, which means that students learn to encounter Gender studies in practice. In this context, the students will write an academic paper related to the summerschool topics, and get acquainted with the requirements for academic papers in this master programme. Furthermore, the students will be given instructions about academic English and the library.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/178630,2017,Research Lab II: Designing GR,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. E. Midden'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After completion of this course, the student has te following skills/competences:
B) Ability to set up academic research in various formats
C) Ability to reflect critically upon the work of peers and established scholars
D) Ability to critically reflect on the use of certain methodologies and theories in relation to a specific research project</body>

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: The Research Lab II prepares the students to build a foundation for two main tasks they will have to complete in following semester - internship report and MA thesis - while continuing to polish their academic skills in writing course papers. Consecutive sessions will be consecrated to issues like methodology; research question; research plan; and setting working agenda, while gradually designing and elaborating on the proper content of the research.</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/178889,2017,Research Lab Media, Art and Performance Studies",English,Faculty of Humanities,,"['dr. S. van der Meulen', 'prof. dr. M.A. Bleeker']",,"Course goals

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: This course aims to develop advanced research skills and reflection on relevant research methods and methodologies central to Media, Art and Performance Studies.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The Research Lab introduces a series of key concerns regarding working with methods and methodologies relevant for doing research within the field of Media, Art and Performance Studies. In collaborative working formats we will: 1) analyse the steps and components of academic research design; 2) reflect on the status of our research objects and the concepts with which we analyse them, and practice making selections and delineating our own research objects; 3) examine the role of different analytical approaches and experiment with this in relation to our own research objects to further explore the relationship between research objects and phenomena, theoretical approaches and analytical concepts.

Developing practical research skills based on current developments within academic debates in relation to changing technologies, artistic practices and cultural dynamics within and in relation to the (professional) fields of media, art and performance.</body>
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/178872,2017,Research Lab: Tools, Methods, Design",English,Faculty of Humanities,,"['C. Aaftink, PhD', 'dr. A.L. Poletti']",,"Course goals

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: This course will prepare students for writing their thesis proposal based on the theories, topics, and repertoire they encountered and researched over the course of the first year. Students will learn how to turn an interest for a particular topic into a research question and how to move from that question to formulating a problem or working hypothesis. They will learn how to find sources and engage with them, and how to organize their notes and materials efficiently and productively. They will practice writing an abstract, arguing from evidence, and offering and receiving peer-review.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course focuses on developing the methodological and practical skills relating to the conduct of research. Students will be introduced to various key methodologies for the comparative literature study, including close reading, discourse analysis, reception analysis, and archival research. Students will learn to think critically about their own methods and to match the appropriate methodologies to the kinds of questions that their research interests generate.

The research lab prepares students to become skilled and efficient researchers. It prepares students for a PhD program, but also for alternative career paths, by focusing on the following transferable skills: conducting research, organizing and managing material, familiarity with different methods, reflecting critically on methods, close reading, discourse analysis, reception analysis, archival research, peer review, advanced language skills.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/178841,2017,Research Master Thesis Dutch Literature and Culture,Dutch,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. E. Stronks', 'dr. S.A. Pieterse']",,"Course goals

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: Via de scriptie tonen studenten dat zij het beoogde eindniveau van het RMA-opleiding bereikt hebben.</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/178965,2017,Research MA Thesis Art History,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. L.S. Veneman-Boersma', 'dr. S. van der Meulen', 'dr. V.M. Schmidt', 'prof. dr. M.A. Weststeijn', 'prof. dr. S.G.M. Dupré']",,"Course goals
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Conduct scholarly research     and     report     about     findings     in     an     academically     accepted     form.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

A RMA thesis is a scholarly text in which you are expected to contribute, on the basis of independent research, to a debate within your discipline. It should be structured around a central research question (set out in the introductory sections) to which it provides an answer (set out in the conclusion).

The central research question should be clearly formulated at the beginning and its relevance to scholarly discussions within the discipline set out. The body of the text should show how you went about trying to answer this question, why you proceeded the way you did, and what your findings were. In your conclusion you should analyse your findings in the light of your original question and explain the broader implications of your conclusions.
The thesis should be written in correct and clear English; it will normally be around 30.000 words long and may be no longer than 40.000 words (including notes and bibliography).
Students who enrolled in 2016-2017 or later are expected to have followed the course Kun-Research Design (GKRMV16053) in their first year.
For more information and guidelines, go to the Research MA Office website: www.hum.uu.nl/ogc/rma
See for more information the relevant chapter on the Thesis in the programme book.</body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/178839,2017,Research MA Thesis Comparative Literary Studies and Thesis Lab,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. A.L. Poletti', 'dr. B.M. Kaiser', 'dr. F.P.C. Brandsma', 'dr. M.M. Jansen', 'dr. P.A.L. Bijl', 'dr. S.C. Knittel', 'prof. dr. A. Rigney', 'prof. dr. D.A. Pascoe']",,"Course goals

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: Students conduct an individual scholarly research project and report about findings in the form of a research thesis;
present and discuss work in progress in the Thesis Lab, at which they offer and receive feedback;
write a thesis proposal, plan and structure their project, write the introduction and first chapter(s) under the supervision of a faculty member and with the help of peer feedback;
present results of research in a graduate student symposium held annually in the last week of June.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The RMA thesis is a scholarly text in which you contribute, on the basis of independent research, to a debate within the discipline. It should be structured around a central research question (set out in the introduction) to which it provides an answer (set out in the conclusion).

The central research question as well as its relevance to scholarly discussions should be clearly formulated at the beginning. The main body of the thesis should show how you went about answering this question, why you proceeded the way you did, and what your findings were. In your conclusion you should analyze your findings in the light of your original question and explain the broader implications of your conclusions.
The thesis should be written in correct and clear English.
The thesis will normally be around 30,000 words long and may be no longer than 40, 000 words (including notes and bibliography).

Students are expected to attend the Thesis Lab in preparation for writing their thesis, which focus on the mechanics of academic writing from planning, formulating, and framing an argument to positioning oneself within an existing discourse or debate. Participation in the final conference is also mandatory.
The MA thesis is crucial in preparing students for a PhD program, but also for alternative career paths, by training students in the following transferable skills:
Conducting research, academic and critical thinking and writing, discourse analysis, project management, communication skills, presentations, peer review, advanced language skills.

Thiele', 'dr. M. Borren', 'dr. M.A. Górska', 'dr. R. Dolphijn', 'G. Colpani', 'J. Mascat', 'L. Ftouni', 'prof. dr. M.L. Waaldijk', 'prof. dr. R.L. Buikema']",,"Course goals

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: After completion of the thesis trajectory, the student is capable
A) to demonstrate the necessary analytical and writing skillls to conduct indepentent scholarly research and present a theoretically sound and intersectionally developed argument in Gender Studies;
B) to give a clear description and justification of, and to present and use in practice a feminist methodological and theoretical framework;
C) to formulate clearly the central research question or problem of the thesis and present a convincing answer to it in the thesis;
D) to critically position oneself in the scholarly debate and to contribute to this debate by producing new scholarly knowledge, presented to fellow researchers in the required academic form.</body>

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: An RMA thesis is a scholarly developed research project in which the student is expected to contribute, on the basis of independent research, to a debate within the discipline. It should be structured around a central research question (set out in the introductory sections) to which it provides a response and thereby offers a contribution to existing scholarship (explicated in the individual chapters and in the conclusion).

The central research question must be clearly formulated in the thesis and its relevance to scholarly discussions within the discipline has to be shown. The body of the text should give a clear description and justification of the methodological and theoretical framework that is used to develop the response(s) to the research question, and employ a case study relevant to the research question or problem and its sociopolitical relevance.

The thesis is to be written in correct and clear English; it has a length of 30.000-35.000 words, and shall not exceed 40.000 words (including notes and bibliography). The individual thesis trajectory will be supervised by a staff member of the Graduate Gender Programme. The thesis will be evaluated by both the supervisor and a second reader of the thesis, the latter will be chosen and/or assigned in the process of the thesis trajectory.</body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/179900,2017,Research Methodology in Spatial Planning,English,Faculty of Geosciences,,"['S. Schramm', 'Teaching staff Human Geography&Planning']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Students following the course acquire the ability to apply advanced research methodology and and research methods to spatial planning problems.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course entails a mix of advanced qualitative and quantitative research methods and techniques. It does not solely focus on analytical methods, but also explores conceptual methods of spatial planning. Traditional empirical research methods and techniques are combined with contemporary case study and situational analysis.

Students also learn to use different methods anticipating on their own master research projects. This includes various exercises and peer-feedback and feed forward exercises. One assignment involves preparing a research proposal, using a mix of different research methods.</body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/181301,2017,Research Methods and SkillsResearch Skills,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. A. van Leeuwen', 'dr. J.E. van de Pol', 'dr. T.E. Hornstra']",,"Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: • Opzetten, uitvoeren en presenteren van onderwijswetenschappelijk onderzoek op bachelorniveau.
• Zelfstandig en in samenwerking opzetten, uitvoeren en presenteren van onderwijswetenschappelijk onderzoek op bachelorniveau.</body>

column1: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In de cursus staan onderzoeksvaardigheden centraal die van belang zijn bij     de     toepassing     van     instrumenten     die     frequent     worden     toegepast     in     onderwijswetenschappelijk     onderzoek     (interviews,     observaties,     vragenlijsten).
• operationaliseren van de theoretische begrippen uit een probleemstelling;
• het ontwerpen en uitvoeren van dataverzameling;
• het maken van een analyseplan en uitvoeren van (kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve) data-analyse;
• rapportage (volgens de APA 6 Publication Manual) van de gebruikte methode, de resultaten, en discussie.

In de cursus wordt methodologische en statistische kennis uit de cursus Methoden en Statistiek van Sociaal Wetenschappelijk onderzoek toegepast op onderzoek op het gebied van de onderwijskundige domeinen die in de inhoudelijke cursussen aan bod komen (leren & instructie, ontwikkeling & design, assessment & evaluatie, advisering & consultancy). In de cursus komen ook kwalitatieve onderzoeksmethoden aan de orde.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/182875,2017,Research Methods in Science Education and Communication 1,English,Faculty of Science,,[],,Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Upon completion of the course, students are able to:
• describe the main research approaches to educational research with an emphasis on qualitative approaches (experiments, design-based research, survey, action research, case studies).
• explain the most important research methods (interviews, survey, observation) and their relative merits.
• analyze qualitative data using a labeling system and simple quantitative data from questionnaires with SPSS.
• reason methodologically, using key concepts such as reliability, validity and generalizability.
• analyze critically the methods used in research papers.</body>

column1: This course provides a general introduction into research methods in Science Education and Communication. Students will get to know the different steps of the research process and learn how to guarantee good quality in research projects. Information on research techniques and quality criteria is complemented with the individual planning of certain steps in a research projects in order to be actively involved in the procedures that have to be considered to produce high quality research. Reasoning methodologically is a central part of the course, which is reflected in the methodological analyses students will conduct during the course. Data analysis of quantitative and qualitative data is performed in class and students get the opportunity to attend two additional SPSS workshops to be prepared for their assignments and future research endeavors. Moreover, emphasis is placed on reporting results from data analyses in a scientifically appropriate way.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/182928,2017,Research Methods in Science Education and Communication 2,English,Faculty of Science,,['dr. A. Bakker'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Students are able to write, in a clear and scientific style, a coherent research proposal that addresses a relevant question anchored in science or mathematics education and proposes a functional methodological approach to answer this question.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

1. Methodological quality of a research proposal and article. You use the quality criteria of Heinze Oost to judge the quality of proposals and articles: anchored in the domain, practical and theoretical relevance, preciseness, functionality and consistency.
2. How to write a research proposal (structure of introduction, theoretical background and methods section). You use the move-step model to write an introduction to your research proposal.
3. Coherence and chain of reasoning of proposals and articles
4. Types of literature reviews. You also learn to structure your theoretical background section
5. Design-based research compared to other research strategies
6. Quality of research questions. You learn to structure the methods section of your research proposal.
7. Scientific integrity (e.g., fraud, plagiarism, ethics, informed consent, data storage, anonymous report)
8. Presentations of research proposals focusing on the skeleton: title, goal, main concepts, research question, methods.9. Peer feedback on students' own research proposals.
Time 18 hours sessions (9*2), 3 hours discussion with research proposal supervisor, 45 hours homework (9*5), 39 hours for finishing the assignment (research proposal in English)</body>
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177136,2017,Research Practicum 2,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. B. Martinovic', 'dr. V. Di Stasio']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The aim of the course is to integrate theories with statistical methods and to write a coherent paper within a short time span. Students integrate theories of MERM05 (Acculturation) and MERM06 (Immigrant Integration) with the advanced methods and statistics of MERM7 (structural equation modelling or multilevel analyses). This will be done by writing a theory-driven empirical paper that focuses on a topic discussed in MERM05 or MERM06. Students also learn to reflect critically on each other’s work (at a level higher than in Research Practical 1), and to present their research in a confident and professional way in class. Compared to Research Practical 1, where they worked in pairs, here they work individually.

There are in total 2 tests: final paper (80%) and class participation (20%). The final paper tests the knowledge of theories and formulation of hypotheses, the preparation of the data and variables, the application of advanced quantitative methods of analysis (in Mplus) to test the hypotheses, and the ability to write a clear conclusion. All in all, the final paper evaluates the ability to write a coherent, accessible and professional research paper that has the format of a journal article. In addition, students get graded for active and constructive class participation, which includes presentations of their paper and oral and written feedback on the work of their classmates.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Students choose a specific research question – based on their interest and availability of data. In the first week they read the literature, develop a conceptual model and explore the data, while writing a theoretical introduction. In the second week, students complete the theory and hypotheses section, and work on their data and methods section. In week 3, students start the actual analyses and present the first results. Finally, in week 4 the analyses are being completed and conclusions and discussion are written. In week 5 students present their research and the final paper is handed in. Detailed instructions on the paper and the course proceedings will be given at the beginning of the course.</body>

R. Pierik', 'prof. dr. R.A.H. Adan', 'prof. dr. R.J. de Boer', 'prof. dr. R.J.M. Klein Gebbink', 'prof. dr. T. Roeckmann', 'prof. dr. E.J. Breukink']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
1. to translate a Life Sciences problem into a relevant research question;
2. to design a suitable research plan to investigate the formulated research question, according to international methodological and scientific standards;
3. to perform research under limited supervision;
4. to apply experimental techniques relevant to the research question;
5. to handle, analyse, interpret and evaluate empirically derived data in a correct manner;
6. to discuss the outcomes of empirical research and link these with scientific theories;
7. to critically reflect on his/her research in Life Sciences;
8. to indicate the relevance of his/her research for the field of Life Sciences and for society in general;
9. to work effectively in a multidisciplinary team;
10. to comprehensibly report research results orally and in writing, to an international audience of specialists and people from outside the field.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The master research project       is       an       important       part       of       the       science       component       of       their       master¿s       programme.       The       student       should       be       able       to       design       and       conduct       a       research       project       in       a       structural       and       scientific       manner,       accompanied       by       adequate       oral       and       written       communication.       Cooperation       within       the       research       group       is       of       importance       as       well.       It       is       a       36-week       research       project       with       one       of       the       participating       research       groups       from       the       Utrecht       Science       Faculty       or       other       groups       from       within       the       Graduate       School       of       Life       Sciences.       If       approved       by       the       programme       coordinator,       it       is       also       possible       to       conduct       the       research       project       outside       Utrecht       University       under       the       supervision       of       one       of       the       research       groups.       It       is       possible       to       decrease       the       research       component       with       9       ECTS       to       42       ECTS       in       case       of       deficiencies       and       do       more       research       related       theoretical       courses.

The research project has to       have       an       'applied'       signature.       This       means       that       you       have       to       choose       a       project       that       generates       knowledge       that       may       be       used       by       third       parties       (companies,       governmental       organisations,       patients,       customers,       and       others)       in       the       near       future.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/183494,2017,Research Project,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,[],,"Content

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The research project for the master program Business Development and Entrepreneurship deals with the core principles of entrepreneurship and (new) business development. Entrepreneurship is of key importance with respect to the discovery, evaluation and exploitation of opportunities for (disruptive) innovation. In practice this process often takes shape in a new venture or startup, but it can relate to any size organisation that is designed to create new products and services under conditions of extreme uncertainty. There are many unanswered questions in this process −for instance who are our customers?; what should our product or service look like?− which answers lie out in the real world.

Building on the Lean Startup principles and scientifically rigorous business research methods, this course offers a systematic approach to test each element of the business model (formulate hypotheses, design research experiments, and measure progress). The main objective of this course is to provide students with a toolbox of relevant and actionable research methods, designed to achieve validated learning quickly, and to build repeatable and scalable business models without running out of resources.
After finishing this course, the student should be able to:

column2: • understand the Lean Startup methodology and how it relates to the scientific method;
• apply the Lean Startup method to a business model;
• apply appropriate research methods and design appropriate experiments;
• analyse data to support the decision making process in a business development context;
• evaluate the decision to pivot or persevere;
• set milestones and measure progress.

column1: Weekly tutorials on specific topics and methods; three additional sessions for coaching and feedback.

column2: • report on the development of the research project (methods and analysis of research results) (65%)
• presentation of the report (25%)
• (preparation of) assignments and participation during meetings, coaching and feedback sessions (10%)

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/183487,2017,Research Project,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,[],,"Content

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Nowadays, knowledge of analysing (big) data sets is a very important skill for the labour market. In addition, students must develop a better understanding of the various steps of a research project for their master’s thesis in period 3 and 4. In this course, you will perform assignments to learn these skills.

First, students learn how to develop a research question and hypotheses. They will deal with issues like how to delineate a topic, how to develop and motivate a research question and hypotheses, and how to structure a research project.

Second, an important part of empirical research consists of data collection and transforming raw data into a dataset that can be analysed in a statistical program. Therefore, students will learn the data skills necessary to process raw data and transform it into a dataset that can be analysed.

Third, students will apply the empirical techniques that they have learned in the period-one course Empirical Economics but also learn about additional empirical techniques in Finance and how to apply them.
At the end of the course the student is able to:

column2: • Formulate a relevant research question;
• Develop and motivate hypotheses;
• Transform raw data into a dataset that can be analysed;
• Know and apply additional research methods in Finance.

column1: Weekly meetings, possibly in combination with tutorials.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/183495,2017,Research Project,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,[],,"Content

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The aim of this course is for students to formulate the research question that they will pursue in their master thesis. Students are first exposed to ongoing research projects. Researchers present work-in-progress and elaborate on their research strategy. What does the literature have to say about the research question at hand? Why is the research question relevant? What is the research about? What is the gap in the literature? And so on. If available, some preliminary research results will be presented. Each student is then challenged to formulate their own research question about a topic of their interest. For that students first have to conduct a literature review relevant for their research topic. Next, each student formulates their own research question that subsequently will be presented and discussed in class. Students are also expected to develop their research strategy: (i) theoretical, (ii) empirical, (iii) experimental, or any combination.
At the end of the course the student is able to:

column2: • Collect relevant economic data and organise them into a databank in Stata;
• Assess the contribution of pivotal research papers in their respective field of specialisation;
• Formulate a relevant research question;
• Formulate a research plan to answer the research question;
• Write a literature review;
• Give feedback to other research proposals;
• Write critical feedback on other research proposals.

column1: Weekly meetings: combination of group meetings and individual meetings with the coordinator of the course.

column2: • Research paper with a literature review and a research question (60%)
• Two presentations of the paper (5% + 20%)
• Discussion of another student's research paper, both written and oral, and participation (15%)

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/183492,2017,Research Project,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,[],,"Content

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Nowadays, knowledge of analysing (big) data sets is a very important skill for the labour market. In addition, students must develop a better understanding of the various steps of a research project for their master’s thesis in period 3 and 4. In this course, you will perform assignments to learn these skills.

First, students learn how to develop a research question and hypotheses. They will deal with issues like how to delineate a topic, how to develop and motivate a research question and hypotheses, and how to structure a research project.

Second, an important part of empirical research consists of data collection and transforming raw data into a dataset that can be analysed in a statistical program. Therefore, students will learn the data skills necessary to process raw data and transform it into a dataset that can be analysed.

Third, students will apply the empirical techniques that they have learned in the period-one course Empirical Economics but also learn about additional empirical techniques in Finance and how to apply them.
At the end of the course the student is able to:

column2: • Formulate a relevant research question;
• Develop and motivate hypotheses;
• Transform raw data into a dataset that can be analysed;
• Know and apply additional research methods in Finance.

column1: Weekly meetings, possibly in combination with tutorials.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/183493,2017,Research Project,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,[],,"Content

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The main aim of the course is to provide students with the tools to develop their master thesis from beginning to end. The course illustrates the key steps of the research process and delves into the major data collection and data analysis techniques appropriate for quantitative and qualitative information. In doing so, the course tries to answer questions such as: (1) What makes a research question interesting? (2) What is the structure of a scientific paper and, consequently, of a thesis? (3) What is the purpose of a literature review and how to make a good one? (4) When information sought is not contained in any archive, how can a survey be developed? (5) How is a case study based on qualitative information designed and implemented? (6) How do big data companies collect and analyze consumer-based data? Throughout the course, students are required to formulate an interesting research question and are coached in the development of a research proposal which constitutes the foundation of their master thesis.
At the end of the course the students is will be able to:

column2: • Formulate an interesting research question;
• Develop a research plan to answer the research question;
• Understand the mechanics of major research methods in the field of international management;
• Create meaningful associations between questions and methods.

column1: One or two weekly meetings plus presentation sessions at the end.

column2: • Research proposal around a chosen research question (65%)
• Presentations (35%)

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/182988,2017,Research Project Bijvoet,Dutch,Faculty of Science,,['dr. E. Mulder'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • The student can, in collaboration with other students, formulate a research plan and monitor progress of the project through a lab journal.
• The student is able to plan experiments and work safely and responsibly in a laboratory.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In the first year of your bachelor studies you carried out laboratory projects with student groups (e.g. Esterproject, Analyseproject). Your research training continues in the second year Research Project. In this project you can chose to practice research in one of ten different research groups in the chemistry department. It is a 7,5 EC course for groups from 2 to 4 students, in which you can set up your own research. Under guidance of a supervisor, you study literature, determine your research question or hypothesis, plan and carry out experiments, collect data and report in writing on the outcomes of your research. Thus you can learn much about how the research cycle functions and what it is like to work in a research group.
Note that there are two different course codes for this project, one for groups from the Debye Institute (SK-BREPD) and one for groups from the Bijvoet Centre (SK-BREPB).
Note that if you wish to register for projects from both institutes, you may register for both courses.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/179720,2017,Research Project Environmental Change and Ecosystems,English,Faculty of Geosciences,,['dr. ir. M. te Beest'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After successful completion of this course the student is able to:

column2: • Apply methods, techniques and skills to investigate effects of global change or land-use on ecosystem functioning
• Formulate a problem definition, research questions, hypotheses and research design
• Make a detailed time schedule for a research project, including milestones and deliverables, and be able to follow this schedule
• Make use scientific literature to identify current gaps in knowledge and to place research findings in their scientific context
• Design a strategy for data collection and collect these data
• Write a scientific report.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course aims to provide a training in organizing and executing a research project. In the next academic year, the student should write a Master Thesis. All elements of the Master thesis project are practiced in this course. Moreover, the individual character of this course allows the students to strengthen their inner motivation and pursue their specific interest in particular aspect of global change and ecosystem functioning. The research master in Sustainable Development is to educate students in undertaking professional research. This course is directly in line with this aim.

As noted before, this course is mostly organized on an individual basis; however, the set-up of this course aims to let students learn through shared experiences as well. A series of peer meetings has been scheduled to achieve this aim. The success of these peer group meetings, however, depends fully on the amount of effort put in by the peer group members. You therefore have a large responsibility for the organization and content of these peer group meetings. The course coordinator can be consulted with regard to the organization and planning of the peer group meetings.

column2: • Design and execution of research
• Analytical skills needed for data interpretation
• Presentation of research plans and findings
• Provide feedback to fellow students.

<body>

column5: to translate a Life Sciences problem into a relevant research question;
to design a suitable research plan to investigate the formulated research question, according to international methodological and scientific standards;
to perform research under limited supervision;
to apply experimental techniques relevant to the research question;
to handle, analyse, interpret and evaluate empirically derived data in a correct manner;
to discuss the outcomes of empirical research and link these with scientific theories;
to critically reflect on his/her research in Life Sciences;
to indicate the relevance of his/her research for the field of Life Sciences and for society in general;
to work effectively in a multidisciplinary team;
to comprehensibly report research results orally and in writing, to an international audience of specialists and people from outside the field.

During the whole process the student is responsible for time management, cooperation within the research group and keeping the rules of scientific integrity.
Major research projects should take place within the UU, UMCU or an affiliated institute.
Prior approval of the Board of examiners is mandatory.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • the student is able to successfully integrate the methodological requirements of an internal and / or comparative perspective in legal research.
• the student is able to formulate a clear research question involving such an internal and / or comparative perspective.
• the student is able to structure and carry out research in order to answer the research question.
• the student is able to present the outcome of his research in a clear and structured way in a paper or other written form.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
This is one of two research projects which have to be done by research students.

This research project should be linked to the insights derived from the course ‘Methodology of legal research I: internal perspectives’ and / or from the course Methodology of legal research II: comparative perspective. The research project has to show the student can successfully integrate the methodological requirements of an internal and / or comparative perspective in legal research.

The research project is carried out under the supervision of an experienced professor or associate professor. The topic can be devised at the student's initiative and the supervisor can be approached by the student.

To develop a research project, you will consult with the supervisor you have found, to formulate a research question which will then be further elaborated. Senior researchers connected with the research programmes may also suggest topics for research, a list of which will be made available during the annual research project meeting.
As a research project you can write a paper (indicatively 20 to 25 pages). But there are various manners of completing a research project. For further information, see the LRM information guide.

At least one of the Research Projects should be written in English. The thesis should also be written in English unless the supervisor agrees with a thesis in another language. In this case an English summary should be added.

column2: • Compulsory course in the master Legal Research

R.F.G. Meulenbroeks', 'dr. L.M. Doorman', 'dr. R.P. Verhoeff', 'prof. dr. W.R. van Joolingen', 'dr. M.C.P.J. Knippels', 'prof. dr. P.H.M. Drijvers']",,"Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: When having completed the project, the student is able to

column5: anchor his or her research project in the domain of research in science or mathematics education or communication;
develop appropriate research instruments or research-based instructional materials;
collect, analyze and report data in the domain of research in science or mathematics education or communication;
write a coherent empirical research paper that makes a contribution to the discipline of science or mathematics education or communication;
present research findings to an academic audience.

column2: </body>
<head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column4: A major part of the course work in research is dedicated to students’ final research projects (30 or 45 EC). In the research project, the student will demonstrate that the academic learning aims of the master’s program have been attained. The project must satisfy the following criteria:

column5: The research addresses a problem in Science or Mathematics Education or Communication;
Expertise in science, mathematics or computer science plays a necessary role in doing the project;
The project aims to answer a question by means of empirical educational research.

column4: A project mainly aiming at developing educational material or a literature review is not acceptable.

Most of these projects will take place within the context of ongoing research at FI, or in collaboration with partner institutions such as the University Museum or SLO. Each student who will start a project from the list will be assigned to a FI research staff member (PhD) who will act as supervisor.
Alternatively, students may propose their own project ideas. In addition to the criteria stated above, the conditions for the acceptance of such proposals are:

column5: The project is situated in a research-oriented environment;
The host institution provides a qualified researcher as a supervisor;
A FI staff research member (PhD) accepts the role of internal supervisor;

column4: This information has to be available to the coordinators before the formal starting date of the project;
A coordinator has approved a brief proposal (two-pager) providing motivation, background information and the research question.
The paper will be written and presented in English.

A required part of the Research Project is the accompanying student seminar that assists students in the research process: development of instruments or instructional materials, data collection, data analysis until reporting results.

This implies that drafts will be interactively discussed with peers and judged against the formal requirements. In the seminars peer feedback is used to get acquainted with other topics and types of research, to develop a critical attitude and to support each other. This is an important element in becoming a part of the FI research community. For this reason, students are also invited to assist the FI research meetings and to present their plans there.

The seminar is organized and chaired by the coordinators. During seminars on data collections and analysis, attention will be paid to the do’s and don’ts in this stage of research. Last, attention is paid to summarizing data in tables and graphical representations, style guidelines of the American Psychological Association (Sixth Edition) and time will be allocated to writing academic English. Students individually write their own paper. Students are expected to read the literature and prepare sessions with peers in which they discuss intermediary products (e.g., interview scheme, data analysis, draft paper etc). They will present their research to FI staff members near the end of the project.
Available projects can be found at the Students site, as well as the forms.

column2: </body>

<body>At the end of the course, students should have a profound understanding of:

column2: • Of the field of bioinformatics

column1: At the end of the course, students should be able to:

column2: • Able to apply this knowledge and analyse large datasets originating from high throughput
• experiments, databases or repositories.
• Able to present his/her results to a critical audience;

column1: Able to work in interdisciplinary teams.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The best way to ‘learn’ bioinformatics is to do this in practice. In a project at one of the UBC affiliated research groups you will work on a bioinformatics research project together with an experienced bioinformatician. On the website of the UBC.uu.nl there is an overview of all participating groups, and the UBC will act as ‘project-broker’ between the student and these groups.
Relevant materials will be provided by the project coordinator(s)
Mandatory for students in Master’s programme: NO.
Optional for students in other Master’s programmes GS-LS:
YES: Only in combination with the Bioinformatics Profile AND only when not opted for an 33 EC internship</body>

This is a course or seminar offered by one of the national research schools relevant for the student's research master and/or research specialisation. The contents and scheduling of these courses and seminars will be communicated by the research school.

Depending on your individual profile you are required to complete a minimum of either 5 or 10 EC selected from the courses or seminars coordinated by the research schools. Credits for courses and seminars (including special Spring/Summer/Autumn/Winter Schools) vary, but the number of credits must add up to the minimum of required total EC’s for research school courses.

After completion of a course, students receive a certificate from the research school, with which the course title, grade and credit can be registered via the Student Desk. Information about registration will be provided by the research schools.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This is a course or seminar offered by one of the national research schools relevant for the student's research master and/or research specialisation. The contents and scheduling of these courses and seminars will be communicated by the research school.

Depending on your individual profile you are required to complete a minimum of either 5 or 10 EC selected from the courses or seminars coordinated by the research schools. Credits for courses and seminars (including special Spring/Summer/Autumn/Winter Schools) vary, but the number of credits must add up to the minimum of required total EC’s for research school courses.

After completion of a course, students receive a certificate from the research school, with which the course title, grade and credit can be registered via the Student Desk. Information about registration will be provided by the research schools.</body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/178969,2017,Research Seminar,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. L. van de Grift', 'O.C. Gelderblom', 'prof. dr. I. Tames', 'prof. dr. J. van Eijnatten']",,"Course goals

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: Through a hands-on approach students learn, first of all, how to turn a general research theme into specific set of questions that can be answered with the available source material. Second, students learn how to organize the actual research, including careful planning and logging of the work they do. Third, students experiment with different forms of reporting of the results of their research, including a literature review, a research report, a poster, and a blogpost. </body>

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: In order to make an independent contribution to research that is both scholarly and socially relevant, students have to learn how to carry out academic research. In Utrecht we believe that, students have to work alongside experienced researchers in order to become a good historians. In this Research Seminar students participate in ongoing research projects of our departmental staff. They assist in the collection and analysis of data from primary and secondary sources.
Poster presentations teach students how to present the results of their highly specialized research to a broader audience.</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/178849,2017,Research Seminar & LOT School I,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['prof. dr. H.E. de Swart'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
body { font-size: 9pt; writing scripts to collect, manage and analyze text.

The aim of the research seminar (part I) (40%) is to teach students a set of academic skills they need for their individual research (term paper, internship and thesis) in their second year. The aim of the LOT school (part I) (60%) is to advance knowledge in the subdiscipline of the student's research profile and to create an embedding of their research in a national/international network.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

A substantial component involves writing scripts (simple programs) in the Python programming language.  We will learn how to use scripts to manage and analyze texts (“corpus analysis”), carry out searches that go far beyond what you can do with a standard web form, count words and constructions, create randomized experimental stimuli, etc.
Students will become familiar with different types of digital language resources, and some of their uses in theoretical or experimental research.
The skills learned in this course can be applied to employment outside academia, in the domain of natural language processing. The programming component has even broader utility.

The research seminar teaches students academic skills (participation in scientific activities, planning, research ethics,  writing skills, principles of peer review and other academic skills they need for  their individual research projects during the second year and their future career. Students will take four LOT courses ((0.75 ects each, spread out over two weeks) in the LOT summer school. Participation in the LOT school includes preparatory readings for the classes students sign up for.
Orientation on a future research oriented career in academia or outside of academia.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/183284,2017,Research Seminar & LOT School II,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. M. Marelj', 'prof. dr. H.E. de Swart', 'S. Radulescu']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The aim of the research seminar is to teach students advanced  academic skills they need for their individual research projects and future career. The aim of the term paper is to exercise academic writing in preparation for the internship/thesis.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The research seminar part II teaches students academic skills (abstract writing, presentation at conferences, publication strategies, grant acquisition) in connection to their individual research during the second year and their future career. Part II of the LOT school involves writing a paper. This paper can either be written under the supervision of the teacher of one of the LOT school classes the student participated in during the LOT summer school, or it can be written with the internship supervisor on a topic related to the LOT school. In both cases, the term paper constitutes the bridge between the knowledge acquired in the LOT school and the research questions that will be addressed in the internship and thesis.
Orientation on a future research oriented career in academia or outside of academia.</body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/179026,2017,Research Seminar AMR: Advanced Medieval History,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. F. van den Eijnde', 'dr. R.M.J. Meens']",,"Course goals
