column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: Enabling the student to write a thesis in the field of Medieval History.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

During the research seminar students are acquainted with the methods developed in the discipline of Medieval History, with attention to the uses of sources and the debates current among scholars internationally. This is accomplished by the in-depth study of a topic, decided upon in advance.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/181499,2017,Research Seminar AMR: Advanced Medieval Literature,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. E.S. de Bruijn', 'dr. F. van den Eijnde', 'dr. R.M.J. Meens']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
-              have knowledge about the medieval literary theory and criticism
-              have insight into medieval reading strategies
-              have knowledge about the major genres in the European medieval literature and have read at least one text from each genre

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course is a continuation of 'Medieval Literature'. The modern concept 'literature' did not exist in the middle ages. This implies that when modern scholars talk about medieval literature, they are using an anachronistical term. There are several ways to cope with this problem. In this course the advantages and the disadvantages of the various approaches will be discussed and demonstrated by confronting medieval texts with modern scholarship.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/182279,2017,Research Seminar AMR: Language and History II: Celtic II,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['A. Griffith', 'dr. F. van den Eijnde']",,"Course goals

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: • possess in-depth knowledge on the historical phonology of Old Irish and Middle Welsh and the absolute chronology of sound changes;
• have facility with the historical phonology from Proto-Celtic to Insular Celtic and from our earliest records in the early Middle Ages to the languages of the High Middle Ages;
• can integrate (inner-Celtic and Latin) loanwords into the established framework of historical phonology;
• can conduct research on a linguistic topic using available text corpora. </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course expands upon the topics covered in block 1. The first way in which that expansion manifests itself is in the temporal domain. While the focus in block 1 was on developments of the 1st millennium, that time-span will be expanded here to focus both on earlier, Proto- or early Celtic changes, as well as later ones found within the attested record, i.e. from Old to Middle Irish and from Old British and Old Welsh to Middle Welsh.

Secondly, this course aims to establish a more rigorous time-frame for the relative chronology of developments established in block 1 by focusing on efforts to produce absolute chronologies of changes. This topic will force us to confront linguistic evidence with evidence from other disciplines, such as epigraphy and history.

Thirdly, since loanwords, both from Latin and from amongst the Celtic languages, offer a means of testing and refining our understanding of the sound changes, we will examine work on loanwords into the early Celtic languages.

Fourthly, and finally, we will examine the ever increasing number of online corpora available for the study of the medieval Celtic languages and explore how these can be exploited for research purposes. This topic will form the basis of the assignment, which will ask students to use available corpora to address an assigned or chosen problem.

This course will help students refine their competency in data analysis as well as enhance their oral and written communicative skills. It will also teach them how to integrate resources made possible through advances in digital humanities into their research.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/182277,2017,Research Seminar AMR: Language and History: Celtic I,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['A. Griffith', 'dr. F. van den Eijnde', 'dr. M. O Flaithearta']",,"Course goals

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: • possess up-to-date knowledge on the historical phonology of Old Irish and Middle Welsh
• can reconstruct forward and backward between Insular Celtic, Middle Welsh, and Old Irish
• can conduct basic research on a linguistic topic </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

As Old Irish and Middle Welsh are the earliest well-attested Celtic languages, they form the basis of all work in Medieval Celtic Studies. This course focusses on their historical developments from roughly the beginning of the 1st century AD until the early Middle Ages (for Irish) or later Middle Ages (for Welsh), and the relative chronology of these developments.

In this course we will read articles and book chapters by a wide variety of leading scholars in Celtic Studies on the developments of the early Celtic languages of the British Isles. This reading will be supplemented by frequent exercises designed to cement the learning process through application of the readings to concrete problems.

In addition, students will pick a topic at the beginning of the block that will serve as their research topic for the class. During the course of the block, the readings and exercises will inform the students’ views on their research topic. At the end of the block, students will give an oral presentation on their chosen topic and write a short paper discussing the issues in a broader context. In addition to this assessment, there will be a take-home final that will test students’ ability to apply the concepts learned during the course to a novel problem or problems.
This course will help students refine their competency in data analysis as well as enhance their oral and written communicative skills.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>To learn the skills necessary to approach medieval Latin source texts; to translate Latin source texts and interpret them in their context; to analyse sources with the help of theoretical literature; to take part in a scholarly discussion; to report results in spoken and written English.</body>

column3: The research seminar focuses on central topics of Medieval Latin, alternately of literary or philological character.</body>

<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/179032,2017,Research Seminar in AMR: Late Antiquity,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. F. van den Eijnde', 'dr. F.L. Schuddeboom']",,"Course goals

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: This course deals with the world of Late Antiquity (third through seventh centuries CE). It seeks to familiarize students with current trends in the study of this period, with special emphasis on the transformation of the ancient world and the rise of Christianity. Special emphasis will be placed on how to work in an interdisciplinary fashion. In due course, it will allow students to develop and pursue their own research interests.

column2: </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Late Antiquity is a crucial period in European history. This was a period characterized not just by major political changes or the rise of new religious movements. There were major systemic changes as well in the way in which both state and the emerging church went about their business, with far-reaching consequences regarding the social and cultural practices that stand at the very basis, to this very day, of what it means to be a European. In this course we will look at some of the overarching developments, trying to understand their importance, meaning and even relevance for today. We will also investigate why this particular field of scholarly research has seen such major developments over the last few decades. Finally we will look into new research methodologies in an effort to determine how these affect our current understanding of the period. </body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/179082,2017,Research Seminar in International Relations in Historical Perspective,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. J. Pekelder', 'dr. M.C. Beers', 'prof. dr. B.A. de Graaf', 'S. Rimner', 'T. P. Palm']",,"Course goals

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: - Learning to gain and assess relevant empirical and theoretical knowledge on the seminar's topic, initially at a basic and later at an advanced level
- Learning to operationalise knowledge and analytical skills, a.o. by writing a research proposal at a basic level and a research paper at an advanced level
- Learning to present your research results, especially in writing, in a clear and well-structured way, initially at a basic and later at an advanced level</body>

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: The research seminar’s main objective is to strengthen your research skills and bring them on an advanced MA level. To make this effort successful the seminar is divided in two parts. Part 1 is directed at gaining in-depth knowledge  – both theoretical and empirical -  concerning 1 of the 3 central focus areas of the Utrecht International Relations Department’s research program: Conflict & Violence; European Inter-State Relations and European Integration; North-South Relations.

During the second part you will write an in-depth research paper on the basis of a research proposal written during part 1. You will write your paper within the framework of a small tutor group, supervised by your lecturer. Your paper will be assessed on the basis of the same criteria being used to asses MA theses, though they still will be applied rather flexibly.
The following topical working groups are available:
Working Group 1: Terrorism: New Perspectives on an Old Phenomenon
Working Groups II: European Integration and Trans-Atlantic Cooperation
Working Group III: The Asian Century

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/182278,2017,Research Seminar: Readings in Early Irish,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. F. van den Eijnde', 'prof. dr. P.C.H. Schrijver']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
- possess a solid understanding of Early Irish
- are capable of critically analysing and interpreting Early Irish texts
- are capable of forming an academic opinion about Early Irish texts
- are capable of presenting orally and in writing an assessement of an Early Irish text</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

A solid understanding of Early Irish is necessary for Medieval Celtic studies. Therefore, students in the course read a small selection of difficult Early Irish texts as a means of consolidating  their understanding of the language. The focus is on deep reading rather than wide coverage.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/179591,2017,Research Skills Global Sustainability Science,English,Faculty of Geosciences,,['dr. A.E.R. Helfgott', 'dr. F.S.J. van Laerhoven', 'S.C. van der Hel, MSc']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • will be familiar with the multi-disciplinary character of Global Sustainability Science and will be aware of the opportunities as well as the limitations in doing multi-disciplinary research.
• will have gained insight in the most important basic research methods to conduct empirical research in the field of Sustainability Sciences
• will be able to apply both quantitative and qualitative research methods
• will be aware of the opportunities as well as the limitations of quantitative and qualitative research methods
• will be able to design research approaches with reference to social as well as a natural sciences, and
• will have gained experience in presenting your research results through written communication

column1: During the course, you will furthermore develop the following academic skills:

column2: • Processing and analyzing information: This course will pay ample attention to the process of gathering, processing, and analyzing information or data in order to conduct academic research.

• Knowledge of research tools: This course will have the student going through a basic set of research tools, commonly used in sustainability science. S/he will work with Excel, Nvivo, SPSS, structured and semi-structures interview and questionnaires.
• Teamwork and academic discussion: All the assignments will be made in pairs, meaning that students will need to collaborate with a peer.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course deals with the methodological aspects of empirical research. Empirical research uses empirical evidence, which means that you gain knowledge through observation or experience. In this course, students will learn how to develop a good research question and how to answer this question in a structured and verifiable manner by means of observation, measurement and analyses.
This course includes an Honours component
This course is the entry requirement for

column2: • Global Integration Project (GEO2-2417)
• Bachelor’s thesis GSS (GEO3-2422)
• Full participation in this course is required for Statistics (GEO2-2217)

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/183325,2017,Research Skills for Historians,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. R. Schalk', 'M. Malinowski']",,
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/183326,2017,Research Skills for Historians (IR),English,Faculty of Humanities,,['S. Rimner'],,

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/179774,2017,Research Strategies ESG,English,Faculty of Geosciences,,"['dr. F.S.J. van Laerhoven', 'dr. H.A.C. Runhaar', 'dr. H.L.P. Mees']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>After completion of the course, the student is aware of and is able to apply a varied set of methods to analyse processes to unveil causal mechanisms regarding the emergence, performance and development of different modes and empirical manifestations of environmental governance.  He/she is able to:

column2: • Develop conceptual models to analyse and explain issues related with sustainable development from a social science perspective;
• Critically reflect on strengths and weaknesses regarding the use of (a combination of) methods;
• Communicate their research findings verbally and in writing.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The objective of this course is to analyse and evaluate environmental governance as well as policy processes and outcomes. In order to achieve this objective, students will be offered a brief introduction to:

column2: • Impact assessment
• Cost benefit analysis
• Stakeholder analysis & network analysis
• Discourse (network) analysis
• Case study analysis
• Grounded theory (nvivo)
• Institutional analysis
• Experimental analysis

column1: Students will then work with a sub-set of four out of these eight approaches to scientific analysis, that they will familiarize themselves with in more detail.
Academic skills: research methods, academic writing
This course is the entry requirement for: Master’s Thesis SD (GEO4-2321)

column3: - Independently gaining and assessing empirical and theoretical knowledge on a specific topic at an expert level
- Independently conducting self-initiated research at an expert level and:
1) on the basis of a self-developed relevant and well-marked research question
2) to be answered through an autonomous exploration of relevant sources in combination with a legitimate method of research
- to present research results in a clear and well-structured way in writing and at an expert level  </body>

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: In the Middle Ages student-craftsmen had to show their master that they were really capable of building a decent piece of furniture or forging a fine example of ironwork before they were allowed to enter the guild of their profession. Writing a final thesis is in fact a comparable exercise. Packed with the knowledge and skills you have acquired and expanded during your MA it is now time to show whether you indeed may call yourself a Master in International Relations.

As you will be writing a research thesis we expect you to offer something extra. Your 'piece of furniture or ironwork' should apart from decency also show some eloquence. In other words your research should not only be more extended, but also show a higher level of analysis including a more expanded use of sources, including primary sources. (archival material, interviews and resolutions, declarations, proceedings and policy-papers from the internet).

column4: Note: you must have at least 25 credits for the category M (Master) before starting your thesis, obtained by completing the following courses:
GKMV16010 Ges-Modern world and states system (5 EC)
GKMV16012 Ges-Research seminar MA IR/HP (5 EC)
And two of the programme's electives:
GKMV16014 Ges-Military violence in IR (5 EC)

column2: </body>

column3: - Learning to gain and assess relevant empirical and theoretical knowledge on the tutorial's topic at an expert level
- Learning to conduct primary sources research at an expert level

- Learning to operationalise knowledge and analytical skills, a.o by writing an historiografic essay and an elaborate research proposal paying specific attention to the relevance of your research(question) compared to already existing literature
- Learning to present your research in a clear and well-structured way at an expert level, also orally, for example by explaining and defending your research proposal in class </body>

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: Common European security operations often tend to be regarded as part of a development that only started with the arrival of the UN, NATO and the EU in the second half of the 20th century. Many experts are inclined to overlook that already after the Vienna Conference in 1815 serious efforts were undertaken to establish transnational European security regimes.

In this tutorial we will compare a series of underexposed but fascinating European security missions, mechanisms and institutions from the 19th century to relevant examples from the 20th and 21st centuries, ranging from military and policing missions to international courts and conventions. We will focus on their development and ask ourselves when and how security regimes started to emerge. At the same time we will use an international and historical comparative framework to determine what has actually changed since the 19th century and whether European states learned from their experiences.

This tutorial offers you the opportunity to find your way through hardly discovered territory. The underlying idea is to sharpen your analytical skills even more in order to prepare you for writing a 20 EC research thesis at an expert plus level. If you have set your eyes on a research career in the field of International Relations, this tutorial is a must.

column4: Note: students must have at least 25 credits for the category M (Master) before starting the Research Tutorial, obtained by completing the following courses:
GKMV16010 Ges-Modern world and states system (5 EC)
GKMV16012 Ges-Research seminar MA IR/HP (5 EC)
And two of the programme's electives:
GKMV16014 Ges-Military violence in IR (5 EC)

column2: </body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/183375,2017,Research and Master Thesis Track,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,"['dr. A.J. Meijer', 'dr. G.J. Brandsma', 'dr. H.J.M. Ruijer', 'dr. J.P.P.E.F. Boselie', 'dr. S.P. Overman', 'drs. N. van Amsterdam', 'Externe docent', 'prof. dr. L.G. Tummers', 'prof. dr. P.L.M. Leisink']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • develop a research question (a “puzzle”) and explain the its theoretical and policy relevance
• demonstrate a thorough theoretical knowledge of the research problem through a comprehensive selection and discussion of relevant articles and books
• account for definition and operationalization of concepts, choice of research strategy, data collection and analysis
• execute the research plan
• discuss the results and confront findings with state-of-the-art as presented in the literature review
• present the research to the scientific forum and to different types of audiences

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The Research Master Thesis Track comprises the final project and takes part in the Spring semester of Year 2. It consists of data collection and analysis, culminating in the writing of a thesis. Students will defend their final project in a public session.

The coordinators will send possible projects to the students and discuss the various options and subjects for doing a thesis. They will agree on the first supervisor and the second supervisor. These will supervise the process. Additional meetings with the coordinators will be organized by the group of students.

The grade for your final project is based on 1) the quality of the thesis (90%) and 2) the public presentation and defense of your thesis (10%). Each student must present the final thesis to a forum of supervisors. Family, friends and fellow RESMA students may be invited. The individual supervisor decides on the grading in consultation with the second assessor (who is one of the local coordinators).

There are no standard requirements with regard to the number of pages, as the type of thesis varies with the type of research. The general rule is: quality is more important than quantity. The more concise you report your theoretical and empirical findings, conclusions – and policy recommendations - the better. As a reference point it may help to know that the thesis in the academic master programmes is required to stay within the 50-75 pages range. It may be shorter and we strongly recommend students to be concise in their writing. </body>
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/176690,2017,Research and Thesis Trajectory Criminology,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,[],,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • the student has a profound knowledge and understanding of a subject of his/her choice in the master’s field.
• the student is able to formulate a clear and relevant research question independently.

• the student is able to design and conduct individual criminology research in an academically acceptable manner on a subject of his/her choice in the master’s field, by using qualitative and ethnographic research methods and connecting the results thereof with criminology theories.

• the student is able to place the acquired knowledge within a scientific debate, taking into account national, international and European developments, and to critically evaluate their data and give his/her own vision of the data.
• the student is able to present the outcome of his/her research in a clear and structured way in written form.
• the student is able to adopt his/her own substantiated point of view in the continuing public and academic debate over the field of criminology.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

During the Research and Thesis Training (RTT), students will show their ability to individually conduct a research and write a research thesis. Students choose a topic that fits the expertise and research fields of one of the teaching staff.

Students are able to conduct a research autonomously or during an internship. Every student will have one of the teachers as a supervisor during the whole process of conducting research and writing the thesis.

The RTT runs throughout the master programme, meaning that it starts in September and ends in July. It is being taught alongside the existing master courses, making use of different interactive (face-to-face as well as virtual) teaching methods, such as individual writing assignments, seminars, group work (including peer feedback), virtual discussion boards and individual supervision.

Students will submit a provisional research proposal in October and discuss the contents with their supervisor and subgroup participants. Students cannot start the research without approval of the supervisor. Every student will have multiple meetings with their subgroup and supervisor as well as individual meetings with their supervisor. During the course there will be four seminars in which difficulties and problems with conducting research and writing a thesis will be addressed. The seminars will take place in September, January, March and June.

The thesis will be graded by the supervisor in cooperation with the second reader. The supervisor will be the first reader and the second reader is appointed by the thesis coordinator (dr. Brenda Oude Breuil).
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/176970,2017,Research and Thesis Trajectory European Law,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,['L.A.J. Senden'],,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • the student has in-depth knowledge and understanding of a subject of choice in the area of law covered by the programme European Law.

• the student can independently acquire existing academic knowledge in a sound ethical and methodological manner, can value them, to critically reflect on them, and to systematically process and organise them, regardless of whether the sources of that knowledge are available in Dutch or in English.

• the student is able, independently, to critically analyse and value written or verbal arguments of others, among other things by examining the arguments in relation to the generally accepted knowledge and understanding of the issue in question.

• the student can adopt a substantiated position in the ongoing public debate about the development of a subject of choice in the area of law covered by the programme European Law and in that respect, demonstrates that he/she is aware of the effect and the limits of the law and of multidimensional and international aspects that play a role in the formation of laws and law enforcement.

• the student can communicate knowledge, ideas, solutions and conclusions, as well as the arguments, motives and considerations underlying them, to a public of specialists and non-specialists in an understandable, structured, correct and convincing manner in a written thesis.
• the student can reflect on his/her own (professional) performance.
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: The thesis crowns the master program. It is an individual legal  research project carried out under the supervision of a lecturer. The thesis is evaluated by this supervisor and a second reader.

While the actual thesis is normally written at the end of the master programme (period 4), preparatory work has to be done from the very start of the programme, so as to maximize the chances of a successful outcome. To this effect, a research-based masters thesis trajectory (OST) will be organized from period 1 onwards.  This OST involves the organization of classes on methodology and writing, and the forming of peer groups that allow students to fine-tune their problem statement, research question(s), and approach (periods 1-2). The OST is partly integrated as a module in the capita selecta course; in this  module, the student has to produce a research proposal for which (s)he receives a pass/fail grade (period 3).
The thesis must be written in English. The thesis should be between 12.500 and 20.000 words.

The thesis will be assessed and graded on the basis of its contents (research question, argumentation, structure, legal content) and lay-out (style and general presentation, including clarity of the text, language and grammar). The assessment also takes dedication and independence into consideration. The final version of the thesis will also be assessed by a second lecturer. The supervisor will determine the final grade after consulting the second lecturer.

column2: </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The thesis crowns the master program. It is an individual legal  research project carried out under the supervision of a lecturer. The thesis is evaluated by this supervisor and a second reader.

Students start preparing their thesis from the very start of the programme, so as to maximize the chances of a successful outcome. To this effect, a research-based masters thesis trajectory (OST) will be organized from period 1 onwards.  This OST involves the organization of classes on methodology and writing, and the forming of peer groups that allow students to fine-tune their problem statement, research question(s), and approach (periods 1-2). The OST is partly integrated as a module in the capita selecta course; in this  module, the student has to produce a research proposal for which (s)he receives a pass/fail grade (period 3). Building on the research proposal, students draft their master's thesis and complete it before the submission deadline prescribed in the Department's regulation.
The thesis must be written in English. The thesis should be between 12.500 and 20.000 words.

The thesis will be assessed and graded on the basis of its contents (research question, argumentation, structure, legal content) and lay-out (style and general presentation, including clarity of the text, language and grammar). The assessment also takes dedication and independence into consideration. The final version of the thesis will also be assessed by a second lecturer. The supervisor will determine the final grade after consulting the second lecturer.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After completing the course, students are able to:
2. narrow down a topic and translate concepts into concrete search terms
3. find digital and non-digital academic sources use search engines and assess and communicate the relevance of those findings
4. use appropriate referencing formats (with tools such as RefWorks)
5. plan and structure the research and writing process
6. write texts that reflect the basics of academic writing regarding structure (paragraphs, line of argument) and conventional usage (grammar, style, formatting, vocabulary)

11.reflect on ethical dilemmas in academic research (choice of subject, data<g gr_349 gr-alert gr_gramm gr_inline_cards gr_disable_anim_appear Style replaceWithoutSep"" data-gr-id=""349"" id=""349"">collection,handlin</g>g of findings, reporting conclusions, giving credits)</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Research in Context is a first-semester course that introduces students to research and writing in the Humanities, Social Sciences and Sciences. Students will learn about the main methodological approaches of the three academic traditions and the principles of what constitutes evidence and argumentation. They will also learn practical skills involved in setting up and carrying out research, and reporting results in written and oral form.
Classes meet twice a week. The course includes three plenary guest lectures and is a mixture of in-class activities, workshops and lectures.
Relation between learning objectives and assessment components:

column2: • The portfolio is related to the following learning objectives: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8
• The individual research paper is related to the following learning objectives:
• The presentation is related to the following learning objectives: 9, 10

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/185151,2017,Research in Intracellular Processes and,English,Faculty of Science,,[],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of this course students have profound knowledge on:
complex molecular mechanisms that underlie the cell biological areas of membrane traffic, cytoskeleton and cell division
At the end of the course, students should be able to:
3. Analyse and discuss the research questions & approach
4. Explain the molecular or technical background of advanced research methods in cell biology
5. Explain the suitability of a defined advanced research method for addressing a  research question in cell biology
6. Discuss the essential steps in research design
7. Prepare a consise written research proposal
8. Discuss and present the research proposal in the group</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Four teachers will describe their research and discuss 4 topics. In teams of 4 students they work in collaborative setting for one week to write a consise research proposal that will be reviewed by panel of teachers.

1) deepen knowledge on mechanistic membrane processes of cell biology (membrane traffic, cytoskeleton, signaling) in a research based manner. The students should acquire and use what they know of Cell Biology to address scientific questions experimentally.
2) expose you to in-depth theory of cutting-edge techniques like Organoid cultures and CRISPR-Cas9 gene-editing.
3) teach you to think creatively and scientifically through the writing of a research proposal.
Several research papers and reviews provided by teachers
Mandatory for students in Master’s programme: NO.
Optional for students in other Master’s programmes GS-LS:

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/182414,2017,Research in Practice: Methods and statistics for the Social Scientist,English,University College Utrecht,,['C. Geurts, MSc', 'dr. B. Struminskaya', 'dr. G. de Krom', 'dr. K.T. Namesnik, PhD', 'S. van Schie, MSc']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<div>After completing this course students are able to:

column2: • design an empirical research project in the social sciences and take relevant methodological issues into account
• report research findings in a formal format resembling a peer-reviewed journal article
• conduct basic descriptive and inferential statistical procedures using the software SPSS
• (a) interpret SPSS output and (b) report the findings following the APA format
• collaborate with other students and work in a research team
• understand, apply, and explain all methodological and statistical terminology
• explain all course related methodological and statistical concepts using everyday language
<tbody>

column4: <td>In this course, students are assessed 6 times :

column5: • Written in-class quiz: this tests the knowledge and the ability to apply the methodological and statistical terminology covered in the first 5 weeks of the course (course goal 6).

• Written in-class exam: this tests the knowledge, the ability to apply, and interpret the methodological and statistical terminology and the ability to interpret SPSS output (course goals 4(a), 6, and 7).

• Research project 1: this project encompasses all aspects of an experimental research project, starting from research question and ending with a formal report (course goals 1, 2, 3, 4(a), 4(b), and 5).

• Research project 2: this project encompasses many aspects of a research project using survey data, starting from research question and ending with a presentation (course goals 1, 3, 4(a), 4(b), and 5).
• SPSS test: this tests the ability to conduct analyses using SPSS (course goal 3).

• Portfolio: this portfolio is also known as the Personal Electronic Textbook (PET). It tests the ability to rephrase and explain by means of examples all methodological and statistical concepts using everyday language (course goal 7).

column2: </tbody>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <tbody>

column4: Research in Practice is a project based introduction to the methodology and analysis techniques used in social science research. Students are encouraged to actively acquire all relevant information and learn from each other, through in-class group discussions and projects. The topics of this course will not follow the traditional order offered in standard textbooks, but, as the title indicates, will follow the order as needed by social science research in practice. Topics covered include research design, ethics, sampling, measurement, and various analysis techniques for associations between variables and differences between groups.

This course offers a unique combination of interactive, student-based teaching methods. No traditional textbook is used. Students are required to use various resources to search for relevant information and compile their own personal electronic textbook.
The course offers the following formats:

column5: • Group activities
• Discussion groups
• Research teams
• Data collection event
• Computer labs
• Student presentations

column2: </tbody>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/182873,2017,Research internship AI,English,Faculty of Science,,['dr. J.H. Anderson', 'dr. S.M. Stuit, PhD']",,"Content

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: A research internship is a project that should be performed by a student and under the guidance of a supervisor. The topic of the research internship should directly be relevant for artificial intelligence and agreed by the supervisor. The projects can involve the development of a software, a theoretical investigation, or an experimental research (see below for some project examples). The projects can be performed either internally in our department, or externally by other departments of our university, other universities or companies. The project should always be performed under the guidance of, and in agreement with, an internal supervisor. The students can have their own concrete project ideas or they may be interested in doing a project on a specific topic. In both cases, they can contact a supervisor with the expertise in the topic of the project in order to discuss the details of the project and if and how it can be performed as a research internship. In some cases, and in agreement with the supervisor, two students can perform a project together.
- A Power-based Spectrum for Group Responsibility
- Implementation of an agent library in Unity

column2: </body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/183372,2017,Research internship and master thesis,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,"['dr. A. Hoppe', 'dr. F.A.W.J. van Esch', 'dr. G.J. Brandsma', 'dr. J.A. Jordaan', 'dr. P.W.J. de Bijl', 'dr. S.B.M. Princen', 'dr. W.E. Bakker', 'drs. L.M. Keijzer', 'E. Rashkova-Gerbrands', 'J. Ferwerda, PhD', 'J.A. den Hertog', 'L.A.J. Senden', 'mr. dr. M. van den Brink', 'mr. dr. T. van den Brink', 'mr. E.S. Lachnit', 'prof. dr. J.J. Schippers']",,"Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: After successfully passing the course, the student should:

column5: Demonstrate a thorough theoretical understanding of European governance issues through a relevant and comprehensive selection of literature;
Show the ability to apply this knowledge to new dynamics and developments in society that deal with aspects of European governance;

Develop a research question (a ‘puzzle’) that directs the theoretical orientation to a European governance issue and accounts for a European Governance problem selection in terms of the scientific, policy and organisational relevance;

Demonstrate analytical competences by presenting the results of the literature research in a consistent review that is concluded by an overview of existing gaps in scientific knowledge, hypotheses and models that guide the empirical research;
Show the ability to reflect critically on the literature by elaborating a theoretically founded position in relation to the state-of-the art literature and existing theoretical perspectives;
Account for definition and operationalization of concepts, choice of research strategy, data collection and analysis;
Carry out data collection, analyse data and report results, taking into account methodological and ethical requirements;

Analyse and discuss the characteristics and consequences of Europeanization for organizations and policy makers that deal with issues of European Governance on a local, regional, national or European level;
Discuss the results and confront findings with the state-of-the-art as presented in a literature review;
Translate the results into strategic policy choices and suggest concrete recommendations and policies for organizations and policy makers that deal with issues of European Governance;
Present the research and its recommendations to a scientific forum and to relevant international audiences;
Reflect on the progress of their individual professional repertoire that is required to enter the labour market as full academic professionals in the field of European Governance.

column2: </body>
<head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: This course follows the key elements of the master programme’s philosophy, by (1) focussing on European governance as a phenomenon that involves multiple levels, from the local to the regional, national and European and by (2) having a interdisciplinary approach to issues of European governance, which involves the study of how organisations within this complex, multilevel governance context face and deal with issues that have a European dimension.

During the research internship, you will study an issue of European governance within an organisation that deals or has to cope with that issue. This should result in a thesis that analyses the issue at hand in a way that both conforms to standards of academic research and is valuable for the organisation in which the study was conducted.

The research for the thesis will take place in an organisation that deals with issues of European governance. You will be supervised by one supervisor from Utrecht University and one supervisor from the university at which the first year was taken (Masaryk University or the University of Konstanz). One of these supervisors will act as a daily supervisor. The other will be involved in assessing the study design and grading the thesis.

During the first semester in Utrecht, you are asked to start matching your individual interest in a research topic with a research organisation from the programme’s database or with a research organisation from your own network.

A senior member from the staff of the research organisation should supervise you during the internship period. The moment a match has been made between yourself, a research topic and a supervisor within the research organisation, you have to make arrangements on the practicalities of research internship.

Also during the first semester, you start developing a research question, literature (re)search, and write a research plan that consists both of a thorough literature overview and the design for your empirical research. The research plan should be completed by the end of january.
Most of the second semester will be dedicated to data collection and analysis, writing the thesis and presenting the research.
Further details on the planning of the research internship and the content of the master thesis will be provided at the start of the first semester in Utrecht.

column2: </body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177245,2017,Research practicum 1,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. B. Martinovic', 'dr. O. Bilgili']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The aims of the course are to integrate theories with statistical methods and to write a coherent research paper within a short time span. Students also learn to reflect critically on each other’s work and to present their research in class.

There are in total 3 assignments (30%), class participation (10%), and final paper (60%). Assignment 1 (theoretical introduction) tests the knowledge of theories and formulation of hypotheses. Assignment 2 (method) tests the preparation and cleaning of the data, recoding of the variables, and creation of scales. Assignment 3 (results) evaluates the application of quantitative methods of analysis (in SPSS) to test the hypotheses. The final paper evaluates the ability to integrate the products of the first 3 assignments and write a coherent, accessible and professional paper that has the format of a journal article and that ends with a clear conclusion. In addition, students get graded for class participation, which includes presentations of their paper and oral and written feedback on the work of their classmates.

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: In this course, students integrate the theories of MERM1 and MERM2 with the methods and statistics of MERM3.This will be done by writing a theory-driven empirical paper that focuses on a topic discussed in MERM1 or MERM2. In the first week of the course, groups of two students choose a specific research question, and they get an introduction to the data set. Students start reading the literature and they write a theoretical introduction. In the second week they develop further their theory and hypothesis section, and make a start with their empirical analysis. In week 3, students elaborate on their empirical analysis, testing their hypotheses. Finally, in week 4, the results, conclusions and discussion of the paper have to be completed. Detailed instructions on the paper and the course proceedings will be given at the beginning of the course.</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177200,2017,Research practicum 1: Work-family issues, organizations, and inequality",English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,"['dr. A. Poortman', 'M. van Hek', 'prof. dr. ir. A.G. van der Lippe']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Ability to link general theory to field specific hypotheses, to analyze a complex dataset, to report on research findings in the format of a journal article. In this course students are trained to integrate theories with statistical methods in the field of work-family issues, organizations and inequality.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Insights will be combined from the preceding theory course SASR1 (Sociological theory construction and model building), SASR2 (Family and social inequality), and the course SaSR3: Methods and Statistics course 1. Students will do so by writing a research paper in the format of a journal article: they choose a relevant research question, study the literature and formulate a theoretical answer, analyze data, and report on their findings. A complex dataset (European Sustainable Workforce Survey) - allowing answers to a considerable number of research questions - will be made available to the students. The European Sustainable Workforce Survey is a multi-actor dataset in which information is gathered from firms and employees in 9 European countries. During the first week, students will work on the research question the introduction of the paper, and get acquainted with the dataset. In the second week, the theory section is written, and preliminary analyses are performed. In the subsequent two weeks, the students will further analyze the data, report the results and write the conclusion. During the course, students will work in groups on their paper using theEuropean Sustainable Workforce Survey and meet the teacher several times per week. In the fourth week students will present their (provisional) results to the other students and discuss each other's work. Using the insights and remarks of the other students, they will finish their paper.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177281,2017,Research practicum 2: Social network analysis,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. H.M. Weesie', 'prof. dr. A. van de Rijt, PhD']",,"Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column5: being able to define and operationalize network characteristics for ego-networks and complete networks.
formulating and testing hypotheses related to network characteristics.

using network characteristics as dependent as well as independent variable in advanced statistical techniques such as multilevel analysis and structural equation modeling. This course focuses on the integration of theories with statistical methods which are introduced separately in previous courses.

column2: </body>

column1: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Social networks are a key concept in numerous sociological theories and     empirical     applications.     Empirically,     analyses     related     to     social     networks     are     often     quite     complex     because     of     interdependencies     between     actors,     which     violate     the     assumptions     made     in     standard     statistical     methods.     In     the     course,     different     types     of     research     problems     that     are     central     in     recent     sociological     research     and     that     require     different     statistical     approaches     will     be     discussed.     We     introduce     important     network     characteristics     and     discuss     issues     related     to     the     collection     and     reliability     of     network     data.     We     inquire     into     problems     related     to     how     social     networks     of     actors     affect     their'     behavior     and     apply     this     to     multi-level     models.     Lastly,     causality     issues     are     addressed     in     social     network     research     and     empirically     connected     to     structural     equation     modelling.     During     the     whole     course,     students     work     on     a     poster,     representing     an     own     research     problem,     arguments     and     network     analyses.     Throughout     the     course,     students     will     be     supplied     with     recent     research     articles.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177177,2017,Research practicum 3,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. A.N. Smeekes', 'dr. T.H. Stark']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The 4-week course MERM 12 aims at integrating what students have learned in the course Ethnic conflicts (MERM 9) and the methods courses in MERM. It provides students with the opportunity to practice writing a research paper and going through the entire empirical cycle once more before working on their thesis.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Students will individually conduct empirical research, and report on this in a full research paper. In addition, they will provide detailed feedback on the work of their peers. The course will deepen students' understanding of the use of statistics and the theories discussed in MERM 9.

The assessment of the paper will be based on the way students translate theoretical ideas into empirical research, in particular the way in which they conduct and present their empirical analyses and connect them to theoretical ideas in the introduction and discussion sections of their paper.
The assessment of presentations will be based on the clarity and preparation of the presentation as well as the constructive feedback students provide to their fellow students.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177334,2017,Research practicum I,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. G.W.J.M. Stevens', 'dr. S.C.E. Thomaes']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
By the end of the course, students will have
1. basic knowledge of experimental research methods, their strengths, limitations, and applications in a developmental/socialization research context
2. basic knowledge of and experience with analyzing and reporting on experimental data
3. hands-on experience with designing and conducting experimental research involving child or adolescent participants
Assignment 1 assesses aim 1 and 2 (see above). Assignment 2 assesses aims 1-3. Assignment 3 assesses aims 1 and 3.

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: This course introduces students to experimental methods, and analysis of experimental data, in the context of developmental and socialization research. A general introduction into experimental methods is provided first. In subsequent lectures, students will be provided with illustrations of experimental work conducted in the faculty. In a brief internship, students practice their skills in designing and conducting experimental research and analyzing experimental data.</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177454,2017,Research practicum II,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. L.D. Breeman'],,Course goals

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: At the end of the course, students:
1. Are able to translate theoretical questions into empirical research questions;
2. Know which statistical analyses are most appropriate to answer these research questions;
3. Are able to explore and prepare data of existing datasets, in order to perform the statistical analyses (e.g. multilevel modeling, SEM-modeling);
4. Are able to interpret and draw conclusions from the output of these analyses;
5. And based on these analyses, can report on the method and results sections of a research article using APA style.

The course consists of weekly computer labs in which homework exercises on dataset preparation and the performing and interpreting of statistical analyses are demonstrated, explained, and discussed. Class participation is mandatory and the homework exercises of each meeting must be satisfactory completed (but these will not be graded). Halfway and at the end of the course there will be an assignment that will be graded. For these assignments, students should answer a number of research questions by performing the appropriate statistical analyses (e.g. multilevel modeling, SEM-modeling) on existing datasets and write the “Method” and “Results” section of an imaginary paper dealing with these research questions.</body>

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: In this course, the statistical analyses introduced in DASCA7 will be applied to real datasets using the statistical software packages  SPSS, HLM, and Mplus. Starting with theoretical research questions derived from the literature of DASCA5 (e.g., the quality of relationship with parents and adolescent problem behavior), students will apply the statistical analyses necessary for answering these research questions. More specifically, the following statistical procedures will be applied: Two-level and multiple-level regression modeling including the analysis of longitudinal data, confirmatory factor analysis, growth analysis, and structural equation modeling, including multiple group analysis. The data sets will be statistically explored and prepared before the required statistical analyses will be performed. Students will exercise their writing skills by writing two scientific reports (using APA style) of both the research method and the research findings.</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177493,2017,Research project in social neuroscience,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['Docenten van de afdeling/departement(en)'],,Course goals

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: In this course, a small-scale empirical study is performed under supervision of staff members.
Students write a bachelor’s thesis which tests research skills, knowledge and the use of statistics and methods employed in the field of social neuroscience.

column2: </body>
<head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: The research project in Social Neuroscience requires students to apply their skills and knowledge that they obtained in the Minor programme in Social Neuroscience, but also to relate their skills and knowledge to their own specific field of science (e.g., Psychology, Economy or Medicine). Apart from general research skills and knowledge, students will also learn to use statistics and methodology to examine research questions that are developed in the research seminar course.
Note: This course is the fourth out of four courses in all to make up the minor Social Neuroscience.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/183001,2017,Research Project Science Education and Communication,English,Faculty of Science,,['dr. A. Bakker', 'dr. G.T. Prins', 'dr. ir. R.F.G. Meulenbroeks', 'dr. M.C.P.J. Knippels', 'prof. dr. E.L. van den Broek', 'prof. dr. W.R. van Joolingen', 'dr. E.R. Savelsbergh', 'dr. H.E.K. Matimba', 'dr. R.P. Verhoeff']",,"Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: When having completed the project, the student is able to:

column5: anchor his or her research project in the domain of research in science or mathematics education or communication;
develop appropriate research instruments or research-based instructional materials;
collect, analyze and report data in the domain of research in science or mathematics education or communication;
write a coherent empirical research paper that makes a contribution to the discipline of science or mathematics education or communication;
present research findings to an academic audience.

column2: </body>
<head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column4: A major part of the course work in research is dedicated to students’ final research projects (30 or 45 EC). In the research project, the student will demonstrate that the academic learning aims of the master’s program have been attained. The project must satisfy the following criteria:

column5: The research addresses a problem in Science or Mathematics Education or Communication;
Expertise in science, mathematics or computer science plays a necessary role in doing the project;
The project aims to answer a question by means of empirical educational research.

column4: A project mainly aiming at developing educational material or a literature review is not acceptable.

Most of these projects will take place within the context of ongoing research at FI, or in collaboration with partner institutions such as the University Museum or SLO. Each student who will start a project from the list will be assigned to a FI research staff member (PhD) who will act as supervisor.
Alternatively, students may propose their own project ideas. In addition to the criteria stated above, the conditions for the acceptance of such proposals are:

column5: The project is situated in a research-oriented environment;
The host institution provides a qualified researcher as a supervisor;
A FI staff research member (PhD) accepts the role of internal supervisor;

column4: This information has to be available to the coordinators before the formal starting date of the project;
A coordinator has approved a brief proposal (two-pager) providing motivation, background information and the research question.
The paper will be written and presented in English.

A required part of the Research Project is the accompanying student seminar that assists students in the research process: development of instruments or instructional materials, data collection, data analysis until reporting results.

This implies that drafts will be interactively discussed with peers and judged against the formal requirements. In the seminars peer feedback is used to get acquainted with other topics and types of research, to develop a critical attitude and to support each other. This is an important element in becoming a part of the FI research community. For this reason, students are also invited to assist the FI research meetings and to present their plans there.

The seminar is organized and chaired by the coordinators. During seminars on data collections and analysis, attention will be paid to the do’s and don’ts in this stage of research. Last, attention is paid to summarizing data in tables and graphical representations, style guidelines of the American Psychological Association (Sixth Edition) and time will be allocated to writing academic English. Students individually write their own paper. Students are expected to read the literature and prepare sessions with peers in which they discuss intermediary products (e.g., interview scheme, data analysis, draft paper etc). They will present their research to FI staff members near the end of the project.
Available projects can be found at the Students site, as well as the forms.

column2: </body>

Bos', 'prof. dr. J.M. van Ophuijsen', 'dr. F.D.A. Wegener', 'dr. G. Bacciagaluppi', 'dr. I. van der Tuin', 'dr. J.H. Anderson', 'prof. dr. L.T.G. Theunissen', 'prof. dr. M.J. Teeuwen', 'prof. dr. P.G. Ziche']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The thesis should demonstrate that you are able to produce new scholarly knowledge and insights according to the rules and methods current in the field of HPS, and that you can share your results with fellow researchers in a coherent way. It is based on independent research, refers to relevant litera­ture, assesses earlier work on a chosen topic and contributes to scholarly debate.

Once the topic and research question are defined and initial research has been done, the supervisor will assess whether the research project should proceed (‘go/no go decision’). This assessment is the foundation for the V/ONV grade for FI-MHPSRPP.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
- relevance of the research topic within the field of HPS
- chances of success of finishing the thesis within the required time frame
- availability of sufficient literature, sources or other required material
- a critical overview of the existing scholarly literature
At the start, students will be provided with extensive guidelines about the research, the thesis and the procedures.</body>

I. van der Tuin', 'dr. J.H. Anderson', 'dr. P.A. Huistra', 'prof. dr. M.J. Teeuwen', 'R.H. Vermij']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The thesis should demonstrate that you are able to produce new scholarly knowledge and insights according to the rules and methods current in the field of HPS, and that you can share your results with fellow researchers in a coherent way. It is based on independent research, refers to relevant litera­ture, assesses earlier work on a chosen topic and contributes to scholarly debate.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
A research master thesis should consist of:
- the formulation of a problem or research question, clearly delimited thematically and (in the case of a historical thesis) in time and place;
- a critical discussion of the existing scholarly literature;
- a critical evaluation of the sources used;
- a description and justification of the research methods used;
- a discourse in which your present your own analysis on the research problem or question, presented according to the logic suggested by the formulation of the problem;
- a conclusion and a consideration of the value of the research;
- references in the form of footnotes;
- a bibliography of the sources and literature used.
At the start, students will be provided with extensive guidelines about the research, the thesis and the procedures.
The thesis can be 22.5, 37.5 or (for TWIN programs) 45 EC, excluding the Research Proposal (FI-MHPSRPP, 15 EC).
Students are expected to present their findings at a colloquium for their fellow students and staff members.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>At the end of a master project, the student is able to

column2: • Study relevant literature and gain in-depth knowledge in a certain mathematical topic;
• Conduct research in the field of mathematical sciences and report on it in a manner that meets customary standards of the discipline;
• Work together on a research team (e.g., in a hierarchical team of supervisor and junior member(s), together with peers or as a trainee in a company's research team or unit);

• Communicate conclusions both written and orally as well as the underlying knowledge, grounds and considerations to various audiences in English (e.g. the research team, fellow researchers in the same area and master students in the same general area of mathematics);
• Judge and evaluate mathematical research and publications;
• Independently perform literature searches;
• Enroll in a Ph.D. programme in mathematics or begin a career as a professional mathematician.

column1: The final mark for a master project is built out of three marks which measure how well the student performed at achieving the learning goals. A detailed document with guidelines for the evaluation of the master project is published on the students website.

column2: <tbody>

column4: is able to study relevant literature and gain in-depth knowledge in a certain mathematical topic
is able to conduct research in the field of mathematical sciences and report on it in a manner that meets customary standards of the discipline
can work together on a research team (e.g., in a hierarchical team of supervisor and junior member(s), together with peers or as a trainee in a company's research team or unit)

can communicate conclusions both written and orally as well as the underlying knowledge, grounds and considerations to various audiences in English (e.g. the research team, fellow researchers in the same area and master students in the same general area of mathematics)
is able to judge and evaluate mathematical research and publications
can enroll in a Ph.D. programme in mathematics or begin a career as a professional mathematician

column2: </tbody>

column1: The average mark is the weighted average of the three marks for process, thesis and defence. The final mark is the minimum of the average mark and the mark for the thesis. Accordingly, in order for the student to pass, both the mark for the thesis and the average mark should be at least six.
