column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: The aim of the course is to guide the second-year SaSR students through designing the research for their master's thesis project, with a focus on problem background and theory of the project.

column2: </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
a) discuss core elements of a master's thesis project and of the master's thesis itself ;
b) provide and discuss examples of previous research that can help students in designing and executing their own research;
c) offer a forum where students can regularly present and discuss their own project and draft versions of (selected parts of) the thesis;

d) provide systematic feedback on the progress of each student's project and thesis. This research seminar focuses on the problem background of the projects, on theories (including theoretical models), and on hypotheses, but students are expected to explore the data as well.
Students are trained in the following academic skills:
- Formulation of research questions- Reconstruction of theories
- Deduction of hypotheses- Search and selection of relevant scientific literature
- Synthesize and structure relevant scientific literature
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177464,2017,Research seminar 1: Theory and hypotheses,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['prof. dr. M.J.A.M. Verkuyten'],,Course goals

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: Students are instructed and monitored in the design and writing of the theoretical part of their thesis: theories, models and hypotheses.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Weekly meetings of three hours are planned in which students present and review their progress, and comment on and review the work of fellow students.

Providing constructive peer feedback is an intrinsic and important part of the research seminar. It allow students to develop experiences and skills in the review process which is an important element of being a qualified researcher.</body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177448,2017,Research seminar 2: Analysing, reporting and discussing your findings",English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['prof. dr. I. Maas'],,"Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: The aim of the course is to guide the second-year SaSR students through designing and reporting the research for their MSc thesis.

column2: </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Students are instructed and supervised in preparing the empirical part of their thesis: data collection, methods and analysis, reporting on the results. Students present and review their progress in weekly meetings. Students learn (academic skills):

column2: • to report on their data collection, data manipulation, variable construction, and method in a clear and precise way
• to present their results, showing understanding of their findings, and reacting to criticism.
• to report on their results in a correct and clear way.
• to write a conclusion and discussion
• to critically review the work of their fellow students and propose improvements.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177229,2017,Research seminar 2: Analysis, results, report",English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,"['dr. F. Fleischmann', 'dr. H.M. Weesie', 'prof. dr. M.J.A.M. Verkuyten']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The aim of the course is to guide the second-year MERM students through timely executing the empirical part of their Thesis. Students and lecturers will weekly discuss and assist the progress of the thesis.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The weekly meetings are used to support measurement construction, hypotheses testing and writing the empirical parts (data and methods, results) and discussion and conclusion part of the thesis. An open atmosphere is demanded to discuss problems students face in their research. There are four roles students have to take in this course; 1. Presenter of their work; 2. Reviewer/discussant of another student's work; 3. Collector of comments during a meeting; 4. Chair of the meeting. With these roles, students learn to reflect on the progress they make in their thesis, to discuss problems they face frankly, to discuss others' work critically, and to formulate and organize constructive feedback. Next to these class meetings, students can made (weekly) appointments with J. Weesie (statistics teachers of MERM03 and MERM07) for more technical assistance.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/182625,2017,Research seminar HPS,English,Faculty of Science,,['dr. D.M. Baneke', 'dr. G. Bacciagaluppi', 'prof. dr. F.A. Muller']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
- to be introduced into the main ongoing methodological discussions in the field
- to become familiar with the main developments in the research field
- to become aware of issues of scientific integrity, both in your own research practice and in the general field
- to be able to critically discuss all these issues with fellow students and colleagues

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

1.Attendance of colloquiums: students are required to attend at least 20 HPS colloquiums during their study. These can include HPS thesis colloquiums, Descartes colloquiums and other lectures, colloquiums or symposiums.

2.Participation in a reading group: each student should attend one of the three reading groups (history of science, philosophy of science, or philosophy of physics). These reading groups meet regularly to analyze and discuss research books or papers from the research field. Each of the reading groups has its own set of requirements, including the minimum number of meetings to attend and a small research paper or review.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177167,2017,Research seminar I,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. J. Huijding'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>During this course each student will write a research proposal for his/her master’s thesis project under supervision of one of the senior researchers involved in DaSCA. During four group meetings the context of writing the proposal is be used to inform and train second-year DASCA students regarding developing and presenting research ideas and hypotheses. In general the course will consist of  4 elements:

column2: • Individual meetings with the thesis supervisor.
• Instruction on and practicing with writing scientific and popular English and provide peer feedback on the proposal.

• Presenting and discussing (the progress on writing) the thesis proposal. Each student will orally present his/her research plans and give and receive feedback on both the content and the presentation itself.
• Intervision on what is going well, and what students are struggling with in designing their study and writing their thesis proposal.

column1: After this course, students should have practiced the following research abilities:

column2: • Searching and reviewing literature
• Using knowledge of former research to formulate research questions and hypotheses
• Designing a method to examine research questions
• Selecting data to study the research question, if necessary after collecting and processing the data (data entry, scale construction, development of codebook)
• Preparing to archive data according to the relevant protocol (see also DaSCA 13 manual)
• Choosing analytic strategies
• Presenting the research plans (orally and written) to an academic audience
• Presenting the research plans (written) to a non-academic audience

column1: At the end of Research Seminar I students should have completed a proposal for their MSc thesis that will be submitted for approval to the Board of Studies.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177114,2017,Research seminar I: Theory and hypotheses,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. T.G.E. Damen'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The aims of Research Seminar 1 are threefold:

First, to guide second-year SHP students through the complex tasks of coming up with a good research question and the operationalization thereof. Second, to guide students in writing up their research proposal. And third, to have the students develop those skills and engage in activities that are associated as important to being part of the academic community.

All the aims of Research Seminar 1 described above are dimensions of evaluation. The development of the research question and methodology are evaluated in the beginning of the course in the form of graded presentations. The research proposal is evaluated both in terms of conceptual and methodological clarity, as well as on writing ability. And students' engagement to the academic community is graded through reports of a symposium visit.
Grading is therefore fully connected to the learning goals of the course.

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: The research seminars are interactive, with a strong focus on students' presentations and discussions of their project and progress. In research seminar 1, the emphasis is on instructing, supporting and supervising students in writing their research proposal, which has to be submitted to the Board of Studies. Furthermore, the theoretical part of their thesis (background, problem definition, overview of research and theories (including theoretical models), research question(s) and hypotheses), and the design and preparation of their empirical study will be of core interest. Both written products will be written in close collaboration with the supervisor and conform to the format of a high impact journal article in the domain. As a general rule, papers are expected to follow the guidelines outlined in the Publication Manual of the American Psychological Association (6th edition).

The course will take a ""learning by doing"" and ""learn from each other"" approach. Students will quickly write a first draft of their proposal, evaluate each other's proposal in small groups and continue to fine-tune their proposals until they are suitable for submission to the Board of Studies. Students will also act as each other's reviewer throughout the whole course: they learn how to give critical yet constructive comments to other students, and deal with other students' criticism. As is the case when dealing with funding agencies such as NWO, European Union and NIH, students will also learn how to make a case for why their proposals are better, more relevant or will have more impact than that of their peers.

By the end of research seminar 1, students will have (1) completed and turned in their research proposal to the board of studies (2) completed the introduction section of their thesis (including list of references), and (3) prepared the study procedures, developed materials and planned the recruitment of participants.</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177611,2017,Research seminar II,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. J. Huijding', 'prof. dr. J.J.S. Dubas']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>In this course the context of conducting the MSc thesis research and writing the thesis is used to inform and train second-year DASCA students about the dissemination of research findings. In general, the course consists of three elements:

column2: • Discussion and feedback regarding the progress on analysing data and writing the MSc thesis. Students will discuss all aspects of completing their research and writing their MSc thesis, ranging from implementing their research proposal, monitoring the analysis of the data and the empirical progress of their thesis project, to writing their article (thesis) and defending their thesis. During the meetings, students give and receive feedback on their progress and learn to review others’ work.

• Instruction and training on disseminating research findings. During short lectures and group discussions students will learn about reviewing the work of others, the reviewing process after submitting an article, submitting work for a conference, and presenting results via oral and poster presentations.
• Intervision on what is going well and what students are struggling with in completing their research and writing their MSc thesis.

column1: This course is the second part of the research seminar (DaSCA 9b), and constitutes a logical follow up on the first part (DaSCA 9a) during which students wrote their research proposal. Now that the data for the MSc research have (mostly) been gathered, during this course students have to analyse their data and write their MSc thesis. After this part of the research seminar, students should have practiced the following research abilities:

column2: • Writing the methods section of a research paper (thesis)
• Designing a plan for analysing the data
• Analysing the data and reporting them according to standard guidelines (e.g., APA)
• Interpreting data in relation to research questions, existing research, and theory
• Writing the discussion and conclusions section of a research paper (thesis)
• Providing detailed feedback on other student’s work in the form of a review
• Orally presenting about ones research
• Writing a research summary for a conference
• Writing newsletters about the progress and outcomes of the project in laymen’s terms

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177202,2017,Research seminar II: Data analysis and writing up research,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. H. Marien'],,Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: The aim of the consecutive research seminars 1 and 2 is to guide second-year SHP students through the complex tasks of designing, conducting and reporting the empirical research for their MSc thesis.

By the end of research seminar 2, students will have (1) conducted their empirical research, (2) analyzed and reported the data, and (3) completed the thesis, including a discussion of the findings and an abstract of the study. Furthermore, students will have trained to present their work orally, also with respect to their defense in front of the Board of Studies.
The second aim of research seminar 2 is to prepare students for the activities that will be expected from them when they have become active in the scientific community.

column4: Relationship between assessments and aims of the course

Besides offering hands-on help in interpreting and writing up data, it is the central aim of Research Seminar II to help students develop skills in presenting their research. To optimally prepare students for their active role in the scientific community, the examination will include three written assignments (a discussion paper, a review, and an symposium abstract) and their oral presentation of the thesis defense.

column2: </body>

column1: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The research seminars are     interactive,     with     a     strong     focus     on     students'     presentations     and     discussions     of     their     project     and     progress.     In     research     seminar     2     the     emphasis     is     on     instructing,     supporting     and     supervising     students     in     conducting     their     empirical     study,     managing,     analyzing     and     reporting     data,     and     discussing     the     findings.     Students     present     and     review     their     progress     in     weekly     meetings.     The     thesis     will     be     written     in     close     collaboration     with     the     supervisor     and     conform     to     the     format     of     a     high     impact     journal     article     in     the     domain.     As     a     general     rule,     papers     are     expected     to     follow     the     guidelines     as     outlined     in     the     Publication     Manual     of     the     American     Psychological     Association     (6th     edition).

The second aim of research seminar 2 is to prepare students for the activities that will be expected from them when they have become active in the scientific community. For that purpose, students will organize the SHP research symposium in which first year SHP students will orally present their work done during the research training SHP8. By doing this, SHP12 students will get a first experience with being a reviewer. Furthermore, they will gain experience in setting up a symposium by writing a symposium abstract based on a selection of submissions and they will also take on the role of a scientific committee by selecting the best symposium contribution.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177625,2017,Research seminar educational sciences I,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['prof. dr. P.P.M. Leseman'],,Course goals
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The Research Seminar aims to stimulate the development of a researcher’s mind, which includes knowledge of doing research (e.g., about different research phases), research skills (e.g., systematic way working), as well as an academic attitude (e.g., curiosity, open mindedness, self-critical). In addition, specific skills aimed at in this course are:

·               Detecting,       discussing       and       solving       problems       encountered       during       the       preparation,       data       gathering,       analysis,       and       reporting       stage       of       a       research       project
·               Listening       and       giving       feedback       to       others
·               Following       formal       academic       guidelines,       including       research       ethics       and       APA       style       (6<sup>th</sup>       edition)

The Research Seminar (7.5 ECTS) takes place during the second year of the Research Master programme. It runs parallel to the Research Master Thesis (Edsci13) and is set up to help the student – through readings, discussions and debate – develop those academic skills and solve actual research problems encountered while doing the Master’s Thesis research.

The course will follow a flexible schedule of of meeting every three weeks. In a meeting, the course coordinator or a guest speaker presents a subject, show pointers to resources and sets assignments. In addition, time in the meetings will be used to let the students present and discuss their problems and progress in the research. In this way the Edsci students form a small research group under the supervision of the coordinator of the Research Seminar, to support each other in their research tasks.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177569,2017,Research seminar in social neuroscience,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['prof. dr. B. Derks', 'prof. dr. H. Aarts', 'R. Dotsch']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this course, the link between techniques, research methods and the theoretical themes in the field of social neuroscience are analysed more in-depth. Additionally, students work on improving their programming skills in preparation of carrying out social neuroscience experiments. In the seminars students train skills necessary to develop a research proposal in smaller subgroups for the subsequent research project.

Students complete assignments during the workshops that require integrating the theoretical themes of social neuroscience on one hand and research methods and techniques on the other hand by means of writing research proposals and programming the proposed experiments.

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: The course will basically focus on a number of key themes, which can change each year. Within each theme, the students will be introduced to setting up and programming experimental tasks, which later can be adapted for a Social Neuroscience research project. Additionally, one of the themes will be further developed to create a research proposal in which a combination is used of one or more Social Neuroscience techniques.
Note: This course is the third out of four courses in all to make up the minor Social Neuroscience.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/179430,2017,Research skills 2 (literature study and academic writing),English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,[],,"Content

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<div>In this course, each students gathers literature on a specific topic in which he/she wants to specialize, in accordance with a member of the TKI research institute. Based on this, the student writes an introduction and literature survey, in the course of which attention is given to writing skills and research culture in economics. In principle, the literature study and research questions serve as a basis for the research proposal and thesis the student writes in year 2. The course will consist of the following parts:

column2: • Instructions, exercises and feedback on writing style and structure;
• Instructions, exercises and feedback on writing in economics in general, and on writing an introduction and literature survey in particular.
• Web-browsing skills for finding appropriate literature, and LaTeX writing skills;
• Presentations of literature surveys and discussions of economic writing;
• Written and verbal feedbacks by students;
• Complementary overview and discussion of different research methods in economics, including their structure of argument, criteria of assessment, and nature of evidence.

column1: At the end of the course the student is able to:

column2: • Write an attractive and clear introduction to research;
• Compose a substantiated literature list;
• Write a well-written and well-argued survey of this literature;
• Give a clear presentation of such a survey;
• Reflect on importance and criteria of writing style and structure;
• Reflect on different research methods and cultures in economics.

• Being capable of independently performing domain-specific research with the purpose of generating new knowledge for the further development of the domain of Economics and/or the domain where Economics and the combined discipline intersect;
• Communicating in English at an academic level.
• Presentation of literature survey (10%)
• Peer review report (20%)
• Written introduction and literature survey (70%)

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/179429,2017,Research skills 3 (research proposal and presentation skills),English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,['M. Goos'],,"Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course pays attention to two important research skills: the writing of research proposals and the presentation of academic research. During the course, students are trained to write and to present a research proposal for external funding, in the format of a research proposal for PhD funding with NWO Research Talent. This goes beyond writing an outline of a research project. The students will participate in seminars in which (successful and unsuccessful) submitted research proposals are discussed. Furthermore, students will write a research proposal that they will present during a U.S.E. seminar. The aim of this course is to improve the students' skills in formulating and defending proposals for submission to national and international funding agencies. The deadline of the proposal will be before the NWO Research Talent deadline, so students will have the opportunity (if eligible) to submit the proposal that they have written during the course. Students can also use this proposal to apply for internal U.S.E. funding.

Furthermore, students are expected to attend regularly seminars from the external and internal U.S.E. seminar series in the first semester of the second year. By participating in these seminars, students will learn more about how to present academic research. Assessment of this part is based on three reports about the internal or external seminars: one (critical) referee report; one short article for a more general audience; and one report on the presentation of the study. Referee reports discuss the contributions to the field and provide several comments. Short articles should  explain and discuss the implications of the research to a more general public (e.g. policy makers). One report should discuss more explicitly the form and style of the presentation: what aspects of the presentation went well and could you use in your own presentations? What can be improved? Thus, students learn to evaluate a research seminar, focusing on the content of the study, the implications of the findings and the way the study is presented.
At the end of the course the student is able to:

column2: • Write an effective research proposal;
• Effectively present a research proposal;
• Communicating in English at an academic level
• Being capable of autonomous self-development
• Write and present a research proposal for external funding (70% of the final grade)
• Write three seminar reviews (3x10% of the final grade)

M.P.J. Cole', 'dr. R.W.F. Nouwen', 'J.M. van Koppen', 'M.C. Michel', 'prof. dr. A. Chen', 'prof. dr. F.N.K. Wijnen', 'prof. dr. H.E. de Swart', 'prof. dr. M.B.H. Everaert', 'prof. dr. N.F.M. Corver', 'prof. dr. P.H.A. Coopmans', 'prof. dr. R.W.J. Kager', 'prof. dr. S. Avrutin', 'prof. dr. T.J.M. Sanders', 'prof. dr. Y. Winter']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
body { font-size: 9pt; writing scripts to collect, manage and analyze text.

The aim of the thesis is to independently write a report of  research driven by the student's own questions, conducted under the supervision of a senior researcher. The thesis shows how the knowledge and skills acquired during the RMA programme has equipped the students with the research, academic and communicative skills to carry out original research.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Together with the internship, the thesis constitutes the individual trajectory of the student. During the internship, the focus is on research questions defined by the project the student is participating in. For the thesis, emphasis is placed on original research driven by the student's own questions. The exact activities/tasks, mode of working, schedule and expected outcomes may vary across thesis research projects, but they are all always agreed upon at the beginning of the thesis project. Students are responsible for finding their own supervisor, and for bringing up their own creative ideas and research questions. In all cases student must have an internal supervisor affiliated with UiL OTS. A student may have an additional internal or external supervisor. An external supervisor is a senior researcher affiliated with an institution other than UiL OTS. The responsibility for the final grade and its entering in Osiris lies always on the internal supervisor. The output of the thesis research is a report that meets the standards of a scientific publication in the subdiscipline of linguistics at hand. The thesis should be structured around a central research question to which it provides an answer. The central research question should be clearly formulated at the beginning and its relevance to scholarly discussions within the discipline set out. The body of the text should show how the question was answered, why the approach chosen is adequate, and what the final outcomes are. The conclusion should contain an analysis of the findings in the light of the original question, and explain the broader implications of the research carried out. There are no strict guidelines as to length, but most theses are between 40 and 70 pages long (including notes, bibliography and appendices).Most students write the thesis in the second semester of the second year. A thesis seminar is run in that semester for group and individual support.

Thesis seminar. The thesis seminar aims at supporting students during the process of thesis research and writing, and at students offering each other help during this process. Students do not earn dcu with the thesis seminar, yet participation is obligatory. Thesis seminar topics include: planning the last semester, getting started on thesis research, making progress on thesis research, what does an MA thesis look like, MA thesis structure and writing, publishing in linguistics, how to prepare for a job interview, and any other topics that students would like to discuss. There will be seven triweekly meetings in blocks 3 and 4.
Orientation on a future research oriented career in academia or outside of academia</body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177415,2017,Research training I,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. C. Evers', 'dr. E.K. Papies', 'dr. E.S. Kluwer', 'dr. H. Marien', 'dr. M. Häfner', 'dr. M.A. Adriaanse', 'E.W.M.L. de Vet', 'M.A. Strick', 'prof. dr. D.T.D. de Ridder', 'prof. dr. H. Aarts', 'prof. dr. K. van den Bos']",,"Course goals
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Aim of the course is to obtain,     improve,     and     effectively     use     academic     research     skills     at     a     junior     level,     such     as     deduction     of     research     questions     and     hypotheses;     operationalization;     data-collection;     statistical     data-processing,     interpretation     of     findings;     and     academic     writing.

Students will receive a grade for their performance during the research training. As the projects all require an idiosyncratic set of skills (e.g., theoretical skills, experimental design skills, measurement skills, data analysis skills, writing skills), their grade will be based on their progress towards acquiring the specific skill set relevant for their own project.
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this course the issues     addressed     theoretically     in     previous     courses     will     be     approached     from     a     practical     research     point     of     view.     Students     will     actively     participate     hands-on     in     ongoing     research     in     social     and/or     health     psychology,     by     working     on     research     assignments     and     assisting     in     (PhD)     research     projects.

The course starts with a plenary session introducing students to research projects they may choose to participate in. Students are then assigned to projects of their choice (depending on available places) and individual supervisors. From then on each student participates individually or in a small group in his/her research project, and receives individual training in the research group. Supervisors will provide opportunities for students to participate in multiple aspects of doing research, such as operationalization, data-collection, statistical data-processing, interpretation of findings, and academic writing. Students will participate in discussions about the progress of the research with other members of the research group.

Due to the practical character of the course a lot of informal (and individual) feedback will be given during active participation in ongoing research. Planning & evaluation meetings will be held with the supervisor at the start, 1/3, 2/3, and at the end of the course. In these meetings student and supervisor detail the plans and tasks for the upcoming period and evaluate the students progress with respect to the appointments made in the previous meeting. For these meetings students are to prepare progress reports as a basis for their evaluation.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177627,2017,Research training II,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['Various teachers'],,Course goals
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The aim of the course is to     further     improve     and     effectively     use     academic     research     skills     that     were     addressed     in     SHP08.     In     addition,     students     will     have     the     opportunity     to     gain     experience     in     a     different     area     of     research     and     to     prepare     for     their     research     to     be     conducted     in     the     master     thesis.
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Each student will actively     participate     in     ongoing     research     by     means     of     an     internship     under     supervision     of     a     supervisor     in     the     domain     of     social     and     health     psychological     research.     By     assisting     in     ongoing     (Ph.D.)     research     projects,     students     will     get     'hands-on'     experience     with     a     variety     of     steps     in     doing     research.     The     specific     activities     of     the     research     training     will     be     determined     together     with     the     daily     supervisor     of     each     student.     In     addition     to     participating     in     these     activities,     the     student     participates     as     much     as     possible     in     the     routines     of     the     research     group,     for     example     by     attending     research     meetings,     colloquia,     and     lectures.

At the end of the first year, students are introduced to a list of available research projects that they may choose to participate in. Ideally and most efficiently, this project should be linked to the master thesis project that the student will perform in the second half of this year. Students are assigned to projects of their choice (depending on available places) and individual supervisors. From September to the end of December, each student participates individually in his/her research project for 20 hours a week and receives individual training in the research group. Students will participate in discussions about the progress of the research with other members of the research group.

Due to the practical character of the course, much informal (and individual) feedback will be given during active participation in ongoing research by the supervisor, with whom planning and evaluation meetings will be held on a regular basis. In these meetings, student and supervisor detail the plans and tasks for the upcoming period and evaluate the students' progress with respect to the appointments made in the previous meeting. For these meetings, students are to prepare progress reports as a basis for their evaluation. During three 2-hour meetings at the beginning, middle and end of the internship, students will discuss their learning goals and activities that are part of the research training under the supervision of the internship coordinator. The internship report is graded by the supervisor, together with the performance during the internship.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/180214,2017,Researching Arts and Society I: Design,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. E.A. Hubbard'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Gain advanced knowledge of empirical research methods.
Develop the ability to apply empirical research methods in field work within the domain of arts and society.
Learn how to prepare a comprehensive proposal for empirical research.
Students gain a thorough theoretical understanding of core theories and concepts and the discourse surrounding these concepts.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

With a foundation in theories of culture, expressivity, alterity, representation and creative economy, this laboratory course trains students in empirical research methods and research design as they engage in fieldwork in various sites. The course culminates in a draft MA thesis research proposal to be submitted upon completion.
During the course the students engage in fieldwork, dealing with current issues in the domain of arts and society.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: Thorough knowledge of ethnographic research methods in the domain of arts and society.
Ability to conduct ethnographic research using arts-based methodologies of data gathering and presentation.
Ability to collaborate on research and/or creative projects.

column2: </body>
<head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: How might ethnographic practice be enriched by artistic practice and vice versa?  What kinds of texts could be produced from a combination of ethnographic research and artistic experimentalism? In this laboratory course, students develop experimental modes of conducting ethnographic research and producing ethnographic accounts of their field experiences. Students will engage with the theoretical perspectives on this emerging intersection while conducting field-based projects that transcend the traditional boundaries of ethnographic practice, using innovative modes of data gathering, encoding and representation – e.g., photography, digital video, audio recording, exposition, music, prose poetry, visual Arts and performance.</body>

column3: After completing this course, the student:
A) has formulated a research question that will form the basis of a research proposal

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: This research seminar has the aim of building a student body that engages in a dialogical way with the study curriculum and with individual research interests. The course offers a supportive environment in which students can reflect on potential research topics and methodological directions at a meta-discursive level. Throughout the block, focus is placed on working in small groups organized around students’ potential research projects and on presenting this early-stage research to the class. Alongside these academic goals, this seminar also serves as a productive discussion space in which students can connect with one another around academic issues or challenges.

The seminar trains students in formulating research questions and projects, in both oral and written form. This training will aid students in their future careers by learning communication and presentation skills in academic and non-academic contexts, thereby allowing them to increase the impact of their research.</body>

column3: After completing this course, the student:

B) has finalized a research question that will be taken up in the second year of the study programme
C) has learned how to write an academic research proposal
D) has been familiarized with academic conventions for the research and writing of a substantive project (i.e., RMA thesis).

<head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: This research seminar has the aim of (1) building a student body that engages in a dialogical way with the study curriculum and individual research interests, and (2) forming research projects for students to pursue in year 2 of the study trajectory. The seminar offers a research environment in which students can refine their research topic, with special emphasis placed on epistemological questions, methodological issues, and theoretical perspectives. Whereas in Researching Intersectionally I emphasis is placed on exploring possible research interests, in this course the primary focus is on the development of an individual research project and on learning how to write a comprehensive thesis proposal. Throughout this process, students will slowly narrow down broad research interests into a coherent research project. This seminar also serves as a productive discussion space in which students can connect with one another on academic issues or challenges and also meet with alumni.

The seminar trains students in writing a research proposal that shows sophisticated methodological grounding and socio-political relevance. This training helps students in their future careers by learning to communicate their research projects in academic and non-academic contexts and to increase the societal significance of their research. The seminar will also organise a workshop with alumni of the RMA program and will thereby enable networking for future professional possibilities.</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/184097,2017,Research Project XL,Dutch,Faculty of Medicine,,['dr. J.A. Post'],,Content

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Examiner:              A.A.M. Thomas, PhD                        Timeslot:     BC/AD  in one period,
E-mail address:  a.a.m.thomas@uu.nl                                               ABCD in the other period
The Research Project Plus is identical to the Research Project (BMW30105), except that:

column2: • it entails approximately seven weeks of practical work instead of two;
• it can only be done after approval by the coordinator, after a motivation, CV, and the study results have been sent.

• The final product is an essay, written in English, with the outline of a scientific article. The essay needs to have a theoretical introduction which gives an overview of current relevant literature.
• Performing a research cycle: study literature, formulate a hypothesis, design and conduct an experiment, analyze results, draw conclusions, report in writing;

column1: The student will choose a laboratory or research group, where he/she will perform the research and write a report. The practical work may be done together with a fellow student; if so, this part of the Research Project and of the essay will be the same.

The report  gives a literature review of 15-25 primary articles, in approximately 15-25 pages. The introduction (literature overview) is written as a scientific review and is similar to a Research Project thesis. The literature overview is unique, and therefore cannot be similar to that  of a fellow student.

The end product usually is a scientific article, with an adjustment for this course: the introduction is extended to a literature overview, which places the research in a context. The last part of the thesis describes the research that is conducted and analyzed. This may be as a separate chapter, or integrated in the literature overview.

Considering the nature of the course, this course should be taken as late as possible during the Bachelor’s programme of a student. This course can only be taken after permission of the coordinator, after a motivation letter, a CV and a copy of study results have been sent to the coordinator.

column2: • argue at an academic level;
• analyze information, formulate a hypothesis and design a research plan;
• carry out medical-biological techniques, analyze and process research data;
• correctly and clearly summarize research results;
• produce a written report in English;
• deal with the gained knowledge in a scientific context.

column1: There is an introductory lecture in December that is repeated in February/March about aims and approach of the Research Project Plus. Handouts of these lectures are on the BMW/Research project site. A tutorial is held early in period 3, which deal with planning and writing, and on finding and defining a research subject. Early in period 4 a lecture is given on scientific writing. A computer module (RefWorks) will be offered to students who want to manage their references electronically. Supervision takes approximately 50% during the practical phase; during the preparatory and writing phases the contact time will be less.
Six to eight weeks before the start of the course, the student needs to find a supervisor and laboratory.
Week 1:            Read necessary literature. Make a working plan, including agreements with your supervisor and a well-defined aim of your literature study;
Weeks 2-3:      Read and make a plan for the writing phase;
Weeks 9-16:   Practical phase. In consultation with your supervisor, this may be done at a different stage. Total approximately 7 weeks;
Weeks 17-18: Finish draft version and send it to supervisor.
Week 19:         Supervisor reads and corrects draft.
Week 20:         Make final version; discuss final version with your supervisor.

Student and supervisor are allowed to decide a different time schedule. The aim of the Research Project is that the assignment is executed correctly, rather than that the student writes a long article or reads a huge amount of scientific articles.

The final grade is determined by the direct supervisor and one other lecturer, most often another researcher from the same group. The final grade is the average of  two grades: 50% of the final grade is assessment of the practical work, and 50% is assessment of the literature part. The final product has to be uploaded by the student in Ephorus (via the Blackboard-site of the Research Project), in order to check for plagiarism.

column2: • The final product is an essay,  with the outline of a scientific article. The essay needs to have a theoretical introduction which gives an overview of current relevant literature.
• Performing a research cycle: study literature, formulate a hypothesis, design and conduct an experiment, analyze results, draw conclusions, report in writing;

column1: The student will choose a laboratory or research group, where he/she will perform the research and write a report. This may be done together with a fellow student; if so, this part of the Research Project and the essay will be the same.
Please note: The student is responsible for finding a lab or research group! You can find possible groups via www.uu.nl/lifesciences or www.umcutrecht.nl/research.

The report has to be in English and has to give a literature overview of 15-25 primary articles, in approximately 15-25 pages. The introduction (literature overview) is similar to a Bachelor thesis or review. The literature overview is unique, and therefore cannot be similar to the review of a fellow student.

The final product is usually a scientific article, with an adjustment for this course: the introduction is extended to a literature overview, which places the research in a context. The last part of the end product describes the research that is conducted and analyzed. This may be as a separate chapter, or integrated in the literature overview.

Considering the nature of the course, this course should be taken as late as possible during the Bachelor’s programme of a student. The student should have 150 ECTS and have attended two courses, for which the results are not yet known at the start of the Research Project.

column2: • argue at an academic level;
• analyze information, formulate a hypothesis and design a research plan;
• carry out medical-biological techniques, analyze and process research data;
• clearly summarize research results;
• produce a written report in English;
• deal with the gained knowledge in a scientific context.

column1: There is an introductory lecture in December and one in February/March about the aims and approach of the Research Project. In period 4 a tutorial and lecture will be given, which deal with how to make a working plan and writing tips. Handouts of these lectures are on the BMW/Research project site. A computer module (RefWorks) will be offered to students who want to manage their references electronically. Supervision time is approximately 20%. During the practical phase this is 50% for two weeks; during the preparatory and writing phases the contact time will be less.
A few weeks before the start of the course, the student needs to find a supervisor and laboratory.
Week 1:         Read necessary literature. Make a working plan, including agreements with your supervisor and a well-defined aim of your literature study;
Weeks 2-3:   Practical phase. In consultation with your supervisor, this may be done at a later stage;
Weeks 4-5:   Read and make a plan for the writing phase; write first draft;
Weeks 8-9:   Supervisor reads and corrects draft;
Week 10:      Make final version; discuss final version with your supervisor.

Student and supervisor are allowed to decide on a different time schedule. The aim of the Research Project is that the assignment is executed correctly, rather than that the student writes a long article or reads many scientific articles.

The final grade is determined by the direct supervisor ánd one other lecturer. The final grade consist of two grades: 20% of the final grade is assessment of the practical work, and 80% is assessment of the writing of an article. The final product has to be uploaded by the student in Ephorus via the Blackboard-site of the Research Project, in order to be able to exclude plagiarism.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/179909,2017,Residential Mobility and Segregation,English,Faculty of Geosciences,,['dr. G.S. Bolt', 'dr. G.W. Mollenhorst', 'dr. I.C. van Liempt', 'dr. K. Visser', 'prof. dr. P. Hooimeijer']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>On completing the course, students are able to:

column2: • Recognize, describe, compare and discuss the most important perspectives on the interactions between housing markets, labour markets and individual life-paths.
• Identify the competing theories on migration and residential mobility and reflect on how these theories can contribute to a better understanding of residential segregation
• Explain the mechanisms behind neighbourhood effects and understand the link between (theories on) neighbourhood effects, neighbourhood change and spatial segregation.
• Apply and critically reflect on policies and planning approaches to cities and neighbourhoods.
• indicate both theoretical and policy implications, based on the outcome of a quantitative analysis of secondary data.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course focuses on migration and residential mobility and its physical, economic as well as social impacts on cites and neighborhoods. Both types of mobility change the physical outlook and urban design of the city as well as the population structure including social networks. They also have an impact on social cohesion and identification in neighbourhoods. In this course students learn to unravel the interactions between the changing physical, economic and social structure of the city and (relocation) behaviour of city residents.

Sociological (socialisation, social desorganisation, social capital) and psychological theory (stigmatization and identification) will be combined with life course theory to come up with a solid geographical understanding of city evolution and life time mobility. This understanding can be applied in practice to improve the relation between quality of place and quality of life

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: After completing this course students are able to:

column5: describe the geological and human drivers affecting natural resource availability .
develop models that provide insight in natural ecosystem dynamics and can be used to design ecosystem conservation and restoration strategies.
explain which natural strategies exist to cope with change forced upon an environmental system
discuss how ecology and earth science relate to societal issues.

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: Perhaps the most important question in the field of Sustainability is how to prudently manage natural resources in their broadest sense in a time dominated by human activity, the Anthropocene. How long the impact of current human activities on planet Earth will last will largely depend on how societies choose to manage natural resources in the coming century. In this course, we identify the driving geological and anthropogenic forces determining the availability of natural resources. We will apply this knowledge when learning to develop predictive models for ecosystem dynamics, strategies to combat current societal problems arising from inappropriate resource management, and use classical economic geology obtain insight in technological solutions assisting sustainable resource management.

We develop predictive ecosystem models, starting with relatively simple interactions between species and their resources. We will also use these models to explore the consequences of recent findings in the literature that species actively modify the availability of their required resources. Also, we use modelling tools in order to understand recent observations showing that even when environmental changes are very smooth and gradual, ecosystem responses may occur very rapidly and suddenly, a phenomenon called catastrophic shifts. We will also study ore bodies, which are the result of very special geological conditions and formation processes that are rare events. In class we discuss how fossils fuels are formed and compare natural formation rates with current extraction rates. Various options how to mitigate atmospheric CO2 rise including underground CO2 storage and enhanced silicate weathering are being examined along with how rock weathering leads to mineral water with distinct and quite variable compositions. Magma composition is associated with volcanic risk. In class you will examine thin sections of a pertinent rock collection with a light microscope to discover minerals and rock properties by yourself.

Students learn from class lectures, and from scrutinizing primary literature. Web-based support is available for part of the course material. After a general course overview, the team of instructors teaches topics related to ecology and earth science in equal weight. Ecological topics include population dynamics, ecosystem engineers and catastrophic shifts in ecosystems. Earth science topics include the finiteness of resources, underground storage and stockage, hydrogeochemistry and mineral waters, and volcanic hazards.

column2: </body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • To build on existing knowledge of respiratory physiology to gain insight into the pathophysiological changes at the root of respiratory conditions (the upper and lower airways and the lungs).
• To learn to diagnose and properly address common respiratory and ear, nose and throat conditions.
• To learn to differentiate between life-threatening and chronic diseases of the respiratory system.
• To recognize less common clinical pictures of the respiratory system in order to avoid therapeutic delays.

column1: The course consists of weekly interactive work sessions Students are expected to devote a significant amount of time to independent self-study. The course handbook lists the material required to be studied prior to each meeting. Students' understanding of the material is further developed and expanded on during each session.
A pathology laboratory session corresponding to the material covered and a spirometry course are embedded into the course. The radiology education also continues parallel to the course.
Respiratory System takes place during weeks 26 through 30 of year 1 (weeks 9-13 of the year).
The course is based on the following sources:

column2: • Clinical Respiratory Medicine. Stephan G. Spiro, Gerard A. Silvestri, Alvar Agusti. Fourth edition. Elsevier Saunders, 2012. ISBN 978-1-4557-0792-8
• Pathologic Basis of Disease. Robbins, 9th edition.
• Leerboek keel-, neus- en oorheelkunde en hoofd-hals chirurgie. Huizing & Snow, most recent edition.

column1: Please also refer to the general textbook list.
A written/digital test takes place twice a year (one regular test and a repeat).
Mw. Dr. I. Bronsveld, e-mail i.bronsveld@umcutrecht.nl</body>
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177871,2017,Rhetoric: The Art of Persuasion from Perikles to Obama,Dutch,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. S.P. van Bommel'],,Course goals
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
- Kennis van de hoofdlijnen van de klassieke retorica en van       sleutelredevoeringen       uit       de       West-Europese       geschiedenis.
- Vermogen tot herkenning van retorische structuren en       stijlmiddelen       in       diverse       soorten       geschreven       en       gesproken       tekst.
-     Praktische     oefening     in     de     retorica     d.m.v.     geschreven     werk     en     mondelinge     presentaties.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: De term ‘retoriek’ is tegenwoordig sterk negatief gekleurd. Wie een ‘retorisch’ betoog houdt geldt als onoprecht en bedrieglijk, als ‘manipulator’ die de feiten verdraait voor persoonlijke doeleinden. Toch zijn we allemaal overgeleverd aan de kracht van het gesproken woord: in de politiek, in de media, in het onderwijs en zelfs in ons privé-leven. En willen we andere mensen van ons standpunt overtuigen, dan zullen we ons betoog pakkend en effectief moeten maken.

Bij de cursus Retorica wordt de retorische traditie van de Oudheid tot op heden intensief bestudeerd. Op de hoorcolleges staat de klassieke retoricaleer centraal, die bij de hoor-werkcolleges wordt toegepast op historische sleutelredevoeringen, alsmede op actuele toespraken: van de lijkrede van Perikles in 431 v. Chr. tot Barack Obama’s ‘Victory Speech’ op 4 november 2008. Gastdocenten bespreken de rol van de retorica in speciale beroepspraktijken, zoals de advocatuur en de politiek. Ook wordt de rol van de retorica in moderne mediasituaties besproken, zoals blogs, opinie en reclames.

Tijdens  de werkcolleges werken studenten onder leiding van een geschoold acteur aan hun eigen welsprekendheid. Gelet wordt op argumentatie en stijlmiddelen, maar ook op houding, stemgebruik en interactie met het publiek.

column2: </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Aan het einde van het keuzeblok Revalidatie & Sport in staat om

column2: • de revalidatiediagnose te stellen
• uitgaand van een hulpvraag en de functionele prognose, een behandelplan te formuleren bij veelvoorkomende aandoeningen in de  revalidatie
• onderzoek van veel voorkomende klachten van het houdings- en bewegingsapparaat uit te voeren
• aandachtspunten te formuleren voor de preventie van blessures, deconditionering en functionele beperkingen bij een gezonde populatie.
• de verschillende domeinen te benoemen van het International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health (ICF-model) van de Wereldgezondheidsorganisatie
• zich in te leven in wat aangepast sporten behelst.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Introductie in de revalidatie- en sportgeneeskunde, met het accent op de lange termijn gevolgen van chronische aandoeningen en preventiemogelijkheden.
• Kennis en vaardigheden noodzakelijk voor diagnostiek en interventies aangaande acute en chronische letsels van het houdings- en bewegingsapparaat.
• Multidisciplinaire samenwerking binnen de revalidatie.
• Functionele prognose stellen en behandelplan formuleren.
• Inhoudelijke thema’s: fysieke fitheid, zelfstandigheid in het dagelijks functioneren, hulpmiddelen, voedingsadviezen, orthese en prothese, blessurediagnostiek, blessurepreventie, trainingsschema.
• Diagnosegroepen: dwarslaesie, CVA, cerebrale parese, amputatie, chronische pijn, blessures houdings- en bewegingsapparaat (acute en chronische overbelasting).
• Zelfstudie, de andere studievormen worden geacht te worden voorbereid.
• Hoorcolleges (beperkt); werkgroepen.
• Meet-the-expertbijeenkomsten met tevens patiëntdemonstraties waar mogelijk.
• Revalidatie domein practica bij diverse disciplines in de revalidatie over functioneren met een handicap (mobiliteit, communicatie, persoonlijke verzorging, dagbesteding, relaties).
• Practica in lichamelijk onderzoek (o.a. functionele anatomie in vivo).
• Ervaringspractica in aangepast sporten en mobiliteit.
• Rondleiding en practicum bij Orthopedietechniek De Hoogstraat (spalken, orthesen & prothesen).
• Basiskennis Blok Zintuigen, Hersenen en Beweging (ZHB-I en II).
• Praktisch lijnonderwijs (PLO).

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/181171,2017,Revolutions, Coups and Regime Change","Dutch, English",Faculty of Humanities,,"['dr. L. Behrisch', 'dr. P. Corduwener']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In deze casuscursus staan verklaringen voor revoluties en andere vormen van politieke omwenteling over een langere historische periode centraal. De cursus richt zich specifiek op vier verschillende wetenschappelijke verklaringen voor oorzaak, verloop, en gevolg van revoluties, staatsgrepen en regime changes, waarbij we kijken naar sociale klassen, de rol van de staat, ideologie, en democratische transities. We passen deze verklaringen toe op concrete voorbeelden van politieke omwentelingen vanaf de Franse Revolutie aan het eind van de achttiende eeuw tot en met de Arabische Lente in de wereld van nu. Zo wegen studenten verschillende verklaringen tegen elkaar af en krijgen ze inzicht in de verschillende dynamische processen die het verloop en de uitkomst van revoluties bepalen. In hun paper passen studenten deze verschillende historiografische verklaringen zelf toe op een concrete revolutionaire casus in heden of verleden.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Dit is cursus 3 uit Verdiepingspakket 2: Politieke strijd in modern Europa (NL track Geschiedenis).
Let op: de hoorcolleges van deze cursus worden in het Engels verzorgd.
Voor studenten LAS en TCS die deze cursus  volgen als deel van het kernpakket van hun hoofdrichting geldt een verplichte voorbereiding.

De Arabische Revolutie in het Midden-Oosten, de Oranje Revolutie in Oekraïne, en de Rozenrevolutie in Georgië: het zijn slechts enkele voorbeelden van massale volksopstanden in de laatste jaren. Revoluties zijn politiek actueel, steken gemakkelijk landsgrenzen over, en hebben een grote invloed op de wereld waarin wij leven. Tegelijk zijn revoluties ook onderwerp van scherpe discussie. Brengen ze chaos, burgeroorlog, en onvrede? Of monden ze juist uit in democratische samenlevingen gebaseerd op de rule of law? Maar ook: hoe komen ze eigenlijk tot stand? En waarom slagen sommige revoluties wel en andere niet?

In deze casuscursus staan verklaringen voor revoluties en andere vormen van politieke omwenteling over een langere historische periode centraal. De cursus richt zich specifiek op vier verschillende wetenschappelijke verklaringen voor oorzaak, verloop, en gevolg van revoluties, staatsgrepen en regime changes, waarbij we kijken naar sociale klassen, de rol van de staat, ideologie, en democratische transities. We passen deze verklaringen toe op concrete voorbeelden van politieke omwentelingen vanaf de Franse Revolutie aan het eind van de achttiende eeuw tot en met de Arabische Lente in de wereld van nu. Zo wegen studenten verschillende verklaringen tegen elkaar af en krijgen ze inzicht in de verschillende dynamische processen die het verloop en de uitkomst van revoluties bepalen. In hun paper passen studenten deze verschillende historiografische verklaringen zelf toe op een concrete revolutionaire casus in heden of verleden.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/181176,2017,Revolutions, Coups and Regime Change",English,Faculty of Humanities,,"['dr. L. Behrisch', 'dr. P. Corduwener']",,"Content

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
This is the third course of Specialisation 2: Political Conflict in Modern Europe

The Arabic Revolution in the Middle East, the Orange Revolution in Ukraine and the Rose Revolution in Georgia are only some of the most prominent examples of widespread revolutionary revolt in recent years. Revolutions are politically charged, easily cross national borders, and have a major impact on the world we live in. At the same time, revolutions are the topic of fierce discussion. Do they produce chaos, civil war and unrest? Or, are they, instead a catalyst for democratic societies that are founded on the rule of law? Furthermore, how and why do they start? And why do some revolutions succeed while others fail?

This case-study course focuses on the explanations for revolutions and other forms of political upheaval in a long-term historical perspective. The course investigates four different academic theories which claim to explain the causes, developments, and consequences of revolutions, coups and regime changes, and focus on social class, the actions of the state, ideology, and transitions to democracy.

We apply these different explanations to concrete historical and recent instances of political upheaval, ranging from the French Revolution at the end of the eighteenth century right up to the Arab Spring in the world of today. In so doing, students weigh up different explanations and develop an understanding of the various dynamic processes that determine the course and consequences of revolutions. In their own paper, students finally apply these various explanations to understand a concrete revolutionary case in past or present.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Through reading and discussion of primary and theoretical works, students acquire critical awareness of the variety of roles played by literary prizes in the contemporary literary field and the contestation over the definition of a canon of literary works; familiarity with key concepts regarding the canon, and literary prizes ; insight into the critical debates regarding literary prizes and the canon; they hone their abilities to conduct independent research, to report on this research in writing, and to present their text in academic format.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this course, we shall address the circuit of literary prizes of various kinds, the inclusive and exclusive effects they may have had, and the repercussions prizes may have for canon formation. What criteria have led the judges to come to these decisions? Can we account for differences in this respect between prizes for different genres? What approaches can we use to analyse the role of literary prizes in the contemporary literary field?

The course studies literary prizes and canon formation, both important  aspects of the workings of the literary marketplace. The research and writing skills taught in this course are also relevant to the work field. Guest speakers in the parallel lecture seminar.

column3: After completing the course, students will be able to:

column5: Explain how rhetoric developed in the ancient Athenian and Roman worlds and how it initially became codified
Explain who the main figures were in classical rhetoric and be able to explain how their views essentially differed
Explain the differing persuasive powers of logos, ethos and pathos
Explain the five canons of rhetoric and how they relate to each other
Explain why rhetoric has been seen as a force for both good and evil over the centuries
Apply a variety of heuristics (e.g. cubing exercises) to generate material for a paper or speech, thus overcoming inertia/writer’s block
Set up and take part in dialogic debates that will increase critical thinking
Imitate the underlying syntactic structure of any given text (style/production)
Generate doable research questions/thesis statements that fit into  appropriate research designs (including selecting an appropriate methodology)
Paraphrase, recognize and produce unique examples of a designated number of style figures (schemes and tropes)
Command a broad vocabulary by means of practicing with copiousness exercises

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: This rhetoric module is primarily intended for humanities students with an interest in linguistics, literary studies, media studies or communication studies. It is also of interest to philosophy and (ancient) history majors. The module will also be relevant for social science students taking tracks in either: law, political sciences or (social) psychology.

Rhetoric has been, for hundreds of years, one of three core elements that make up the so called ‘trivium’; the academic core of an undergraduate university education. The trivium is made up of grammar, logic and rhetoric, three skills for both learning and life that are to be encountered and acquired in this grammar-logic-rhetoric order. This introduction to the field of rhetoric (and composition) is organized in terms of the five canons of rhetoric. It follows an idealized process of writing a paper or giving a speech. This includes inventing material / ideas / arguments (and constructing sound arguments), arranging them, stylizing them, memorizing what has to be said (if a speech), and then delivering that speech (or writing that paper). In reality, and depending on the context, this process is not always as staged and linear as is suggested here. When studied with due care and attention, a good working knowledge of rhetoric will almost certainly make you a better writer, speaker and thinker.

This course is a workshop-style, practice-intensive, interactive course for which a high level of qualitative participation is required (learning by doing). Students must therefore be vocal during all sessions: debating, critiquing, analysing and discussing. The following factors are also considered when determining the overall participation grade. The course will be graded based on (a) the end of term exam, which will be worth 75%, and on (b) active participation, what might be termed a combination of attendance, preparation and participation (APP), which will constitute the remaining 25% of the course grade. Students will be expected to have prepared well for the class; this includes completing all assigned reading and any assigned homework exercises/assignments.

column6: This course is taught during the last five weeks of the semester. It uses the same timeslot as the UCACCMET25 group did during the first ten weeks.
Please note: this module is taught during five consecutive Wednesdays 11:00-13:45.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<div>Het eerste deel van dit college bestaat uit de theorie van de ringen. Voorbeelden van ringen zijn de gehele getallen en de veeltermen, maar er zijn nog vele anderen. Het ringbegrip omvat alle gemeenschappelijke eigenschappen van systemen waarop we een optelling en vermenigvuldiging hebben. Daarom is het een basisvak in de algebra. De volgende begrippen komen ter sprake: ringhomomorfismen, idealen, polynomen, priemidealen, maximale idealen, en veel voorbeelden.

Het tweede deel, Galoistheorie, komt voort uit klassieke problemen in de wiskunde. Bijvoorbeeld klassieke constructie problemen met passer en liniaal (trisectie van de hoek, quadratuur van de cirkel) en het probleem van de oplossing van hogere graadsvergelijkingen. Door studie van de achterliggende symmetrieën (Galoisgroepen) kunnen we vaak komen tot een oplossing van deze problemen. Belangrijk hierbij is de theorie van de lichamen (systemen met optelling, vermenigvuldiging en deling). De volgende begrippen komen ter sprake: lichaamsuitbreidingen, constructies, normaal/separabel, Galoiscorrespondentie, oplosbaarheid, eindige lichamen
Kennis en inzicht. Na afronding van de cursus kent de student:
• het begrip ring en voorbeelden van ringen
• de begrippen: ringhomomorfisme, ideaal, priemideaal en maximaal ideaal, domein, lichaam,
• verschillende toetsen voor irreducibiliteit van polynomen
Vaardigheden: Na afronding van de cursus kan de student:
• bepalen of de wortels van een polynoom algebraïsch gevonden kunnen worden
Onderwijsvormen: Er is 2 keer per week hoorcollege van 2 uur en 2
keer per week werkcollege van 2 uur.
Toetsvormen:Elke twee weken wordt er een huiswerkopgave gegeven.
Het eindcijfer bestaat voor 20% uit het totaalresultaat van de
huiswerkopgaven en voor 80% uit het tentamen,
met als voorwaarde dat het totaalresultaat voor het tentamen
Het herkansingstentamen wordt als een geheel afgenomen.
Eerdere resultaten voor huiswerk worden niet meegerekend.
