column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column4: In de cursus “Structuur van de Materie” komen die onderwerpen uit de natuurkunde aan de orde die te maken hebben met een beschrijving van de natuur vanuit een “deeltjes” beschrijving. Die beschrijving is begonnen na de realisatie, die begon in de negentiende eeuw, dat materie is opgebouwd uit atomen en moleculen. Deze deeltjes vormen de bouwstenen waaruit alle gecondenseerde materie is opgebouwd. In de eerste helft van de twintigste eeuw realiseerde men zich echter dat atomen en moleculen zelf zijn opgebouwd uit kleinere deeltjes. De cursus bouwt voort op de cursussen QM1 en TF1. Doel is deze kennis te verdiepen en toe te passen op een beschrijving van fundamentele processen in de gecondenseerde materie fysica en de subatomaire fysica. Tevens zal aandacht worden besteed aan experimentele technieken waarmee men deze processen kan bestuderen en worden links gelegd naar het huidige onderzoek in ons departement.
De opbouw van de cursus is als volgt:

column5: <li>
<li>

column6: Week 1+2: Subatomaire fysica: opbouw van de kernen, grondtoestand van de kernen (druppelmodel), schillen-model, radioactief verval, kernkracht (meson-theorie).

column5: <li>

column6: Week 3+4: Deeltjesfysica: inleiding tot de elementaire deeltjes, interacties en krachtdragers, quarks, leptonen, symmetrieen en behoudswetten.

column5: <li>

column6: Week 5+6: Atoom en molecuul fysica. Meer-elektron atomen, Aufbau principe, periodiek systeem Quantum mechanische beschrijving van covalente bindingen tussen atomen (tight binding, variatietheorema). Andere bindingen (ionogeen, van der Waals)

column5: <li>

column6: Week 6+7+8: Harde gecondenseerde materie. Kristal structuur, reciprook rooster, elektronische structuur van de vaste-stof: vrije elektronen in een metaal, banden-structuur, geleiders, isolatoren, halfgeleiders, grafeen

column5: <li>

column6: Week 9: Zachte gecondenseerde materie (polymeren, surfactants, colloïden)

column4: De leerstof wordt onderwezen in een hoorcollege en toegepast in een werkcollege; er worden middels korte ‘gastcolleges’ links gelegd met toepassing van de concepten en technieken uit deze cursus in huidig onderzoek in het departement.

column2: </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Je kunt in kaart brengen hoe onderwijsontwikkelingen zijn ontstaan, wat ze inhouden en omvatten, wat hun gevolgen zijn en hoe ze verschillend worden benaderd en gewaardeerd vanuit verschillende perspectieven en disciplines.

• Je kunt analyseren hoe deze verschillende elementen/aspecten van onderwijsontwikkelingen zich tot elkaar verhouden en hoe deze ontwikkelingen zich verhouden tot algemene ontwikkelingen in de maatschappij.
• Je kunt onderwijsontwikkelingen evalueren met de focus op het succes, de manier van aanpak en toepassing van relevante onderzoeksresultaten in deze aanpak.
• Je kunt al het bovenstaande overbrengen door middel van verschillende argumentatie methoden met behulp van wetenschappelijke theorie en kennis uit de praktijk.

column1: Aan het eind van de cursus kun jij functioneren als onderwijs-criticus door voor één zelfgekozen thema de cyclus van het in kaart brengen, analyseren, evalueren en beargumenteren succesvol te doorlopen.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Deze cursus zal gaan over ontwikkelingen in het basisonderwijs, middelbaar onderwijs en het hoger- en beroepsonderwijs.

– In het basisonderwijs zal de focus liggen op zorg in het onderwijs, leerlingen met speciale behoeften in het regulier onderwijs. Wat zegt de theorie over zorg in het onderwijs en hoe pakt dit uit in de praktijk?

– In het middelbaar onderwijs verdiepen we ons in het actuele debat: zouden leerlingen hun vakken op verschillende niveaus mogen volgen? Wat zijn de implicaties als een leerling bijvoorbeeld wiskunde en engels op havo niveau en de rest op VWO niveau volgt? En waarom zouden we dit überhaupt willen?
– In het hoger- en beroepsonderwijs zoomen we in op de internationalisering van het onderwijs. Waarom is internationalisering zo’n belangrijk onderwerp en wat zijn de gevolgen daarvan?

Dit zijn enkel een paar voorbeelden van onderwerpen die aan bod gaan komen binnen de drie hoofdthema’s. Je gaat je namelijk inleven in de rol van onderwijsexpert en -criticus en je leert hoe je actuele onderwijsontwikkelingen en beleidsmaatregelen kunt benaderen, analyseren en evalueren. Naast theorie speelt ook praktijk een belangrijke rol: verschillende gastsprekers komen vertellen over hun ervaringen met de ontwikkelingen, zoals een directeur van een basisschool. Zo kun jij nog beter je mening vormen, en leer je welke rol theorie nu eigenlijk speelt en je deze zou kunnen laten spelen.
De cursus is vormgegeven op basis van flipping the classroom. Hierdoor neem je thuis het gros van de kennis tot je op en pas je dit actief toe in de werkgroepen.
Voor overige vragen kun je altijd nog contact opnemen met a.spierenburg2@students.uu.nl.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Na het volgen van dit vak kan de student:

a. De basisprincipes (waaronder vraag & aanbod, market failure, principaal-agenttheorie) van gezondheidseconomie uitleggen en deze principes gebruiken om het gedrag van actoren in de zorgsector te verklaren
b. De structuur en kenmerken van het Nederlandse Zorgstelsel beschrijven op macroniveau.
c. Beredeneren welke voor- en nadelen verschillende zorgstelsels kenmerken en op basis hiervan een beargumenteerde keuze maken voor een zorgstelsel.

d. De uitdagingen (waaronder stijgende zorgkosten, kosten-effectiviteits analyses en financiering van zorgprofessionals) binnen de financiering van de zorg en potentiële oplossingen benoemen en uitleggen.
Na het volgen van dit vak kan de student:

a. De belangrijkste innovaties in de zorgsector die waarschijnlijk in het komende decennium impact zullen hebben op de dagelijkse praktijk kunnen benoemen en beschrijven (waaronder Internet of Things, Big Data, Kunstmatige Intelligentie, Wearables, organoïden, CRISPR-cas9 en IBM Watson).
b. Uitleggen welke menselijke taken binnen de zorgsector de genoemde innovaties onder leerdoel 2a naar verwachting kunnen overnemen.

c. Op basis van leerdoel 2b beargumenteren wat de verwachte meerwaarde van een menselijke component in de uitoefening van beroepen in de zorgsector zal zijn en welke competenties vermoedelijk belangrijk zullen zijn.
d. Ethische aspecten van technologische en organisatorische innovaties analyseren en vanuit hier deze innovaties goed onderbouwd kunnen becommentariëren. 5
3. Omgaan met innovatie en ontwikkelen van softskills
Na het volgen van dit vak:
a. Weet de student wat ‘institutional theory’ globaal inhoudt doordat hij de aangeboden literatuur heeft gelezen en heeft begrepen.

b. Kan de student op basis van ‘institutional theory’ aan de hand van een praktijkvoorbeeld uit de zorgsector de implementatie van innovatie of beleid analyseren en mogelijke verbeteringen in het implementatieproces aandragen.

c. Is de student aantoonbaar vooruitgegaan in de competenties die kenmerkend zijn voor een professionele houding (denk daarbij aan het geven en ontvangen van feedback, plannen, ontwikkelen van flexibiliteit en vakoverstijgend communiceren, in het kader van projectwerk).

d. Kan de student op microniveau organisaties binnen de zorgsector (zorg-, onderwijs- en bestuurlijke instellingen) globaal beschrijven om zo kennis te maken met het werven van fondsen of beurzen en het opbouwen van een netwerk voor (academische) samenwerking.
Na het volgen van dit vak:
a. Kan de student in een multidisciplinair verband de opgedane kennis m.b.t. bekostiging, innovaties en samenwerking toepassen in een casus.
b. De student kan de uitkomsten van zijn/haar case op een overtuigende manier pitchen toegespitst op de belangen van de doelgroep.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Innovatie & Bekostiging van de Zorgsector is hét vak voor de toekomstige zorgprofessional met interesse in interdisciplinaire samenwerking en het volgen van kleinschalig onderwijs. Het vak biedt academische verbreding en verdieping binnen drie pijlers allen toegespitst op de zorgsector:

1) Economie en Bekostiging – Basistheorieën binnen de gezondheidseconomie worden behandeld (o.a. perverse motieven en asymmetrische informatie binnen de gezondheidszorg). Maar ook: wat zijn de voor- & nadelen van verschillende soorten zorgstelsel? En wat is het nut van een zorgverzekeraar?

2) Technologische Innovaties – Toekomstige innovaties worden belicht. Daarbij wordt ingegaan op hoe deze innovaties de gezondheidszorg gaan veranderen. Wat wordt straks de rol van de zorgprofessional in de toekomst en wat kunnen wij als mens nog bijdragen?

3) Governance & Soft skills – Governance spitst zich toe op hoe veranderingen ontstaan binnen organisaties. Daarnaast worden gedurende dit vak ‘soft skills’ belicht: wat heb je nodig om interdisciplinair samen te kunnen werken en hoe pitch jij jouw idee overtuigend?

There may be one or more topics proposed for the course, and all students in the course, regardless of the topic on which they focus, are required to work together as a multidisciplinary seminar group.

GPA

column4: Students who indicate an interest in this course but who do not obviously meet the criteria will be interviewed by the course co-ordinator and the intended supervisor.

The Medical Clerkship Surgery builds upon the material of year 1 and 2.
The goals of the clerkship include:
- supervised and increasingly independent involvement in the of assessment and management of patients within the surgical specialty.
- familiarization with the treatment options within surgical subspecialties
- involvement in the management of patients requiring prompt medical attention in the
- partaking in correspondence with the referring physician and medical history taking
Refer to student manual Medical Clerkship Surgery and WebCT .
The clerkship takes place in year 3
The clerkship is based on the following sources:
- Kleine verrichtingen (""Small Procedures""), H. Keeman, uitgeverij Bohn en Scheltema
Please also refer to the general textbook list for
Clerkship guidelines, portfolio, and student's manual Medical Clerkship Surgery.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The Medical Clerkship Obstetrics and Gynaecology builds upon the material of year 1 and 2.
During this Medical Clerkship, an emphasis is placed on disciplined learning of professional competencies associated with the specialty.
The Medical Clerkship Obstetrics and Gynaecology is associated with the following goals:

column2: • involvement in the assessment and management of the patient with increasing independence
• consolidation and further in-depth learning of the knowledge gained in the course and student clinic Obstetrics and Gynaecology during years 1 and 2.
• gaining the skills outlined in Framework 2009
• experience irregular working hours
• setting up differential diagnoses
• composing  diagnostic and management plans
• concisely summarize patient status
• learn efficient medical history taking and reporting
• write discharge notes

column1: For more details refer to the student manual Medical Clerkship Obstetrics and Gynaecology
During the five week medical clerkship, different facets of the specialty will be covered.
The Medical Clerkship Obstetrics and Gynaecology takes place in year 3
Magowan, Owen and Thomson: Clinical Obstetrics and Gynaecology, 3rd edition 2014
Please also refer to the general textbook list.
Portfolio jaar 3 SUMMA, and student manual Medical Clerkship Obstetrics and Gynaecology.
Coordinator teaching hospital:  Dr.  A.J.M. Huisjes, mail: a.huisjes@gelre.nl

Medical Clerkship Internal Medicine builds upon the material of year 1 and 2.
Goals and expectations of the students include:
- supervised and increasingly independent involvement in the of assessment and management of
important problems seen in Internal Medicine
- familiarization with the treatment options within internal medicine subspecialties
- gaining experience by co-operate in the triage process and reanimation
- involvement in the management of patients requiring prompt medical attention in the
- partaking in correspondence with the referring physician and medical history taking
Please refer to the student manual Medical Clerkship Internal Medicine
The Clerkship Internal Medicine takes place in year 3.
•           A number of relevant textbooks are referred to in the general textbook list.
•           “Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine,” is recommended literature.
Clerkship guidelines, portfolio, and student's manual Medical Clerkship Internal Medicine.
Coordinator teaching hospital:  Dr.  A.J.M. Huisjes, mail: a.huisjes@gelre.nl

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/183952,2017,Medical Clerkship Pediatrics,Dutch,Faculty of Medicine,,['dr. S.C. Bakker'],,Content

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Medical Clerkship Pediatrics builds upon the material of year 1 and 2.
The goals and expectations of the clerkship include:
- to gain knowledge of the issues and objectives associated with Pediatric Medicine, as described in Framework 2009
- the application of said knowledge of pediatric medicine while adapting an attitude conducive to a profession in pediatrics.
- to learn a number of skills, diagnostic methods, and treatment options specific for pediatrics.
- supervised and increasingly independent involvement in the of assessment and management of pediatric patients.
- involvement in the medical treatment of pediatric patients in the Emergency Department
- partaking in correspondence with the referring physician and medical history taking

The five week medical clerkship Pediatrics takes place in the Gelre Hospitals in Apeldoorn. After the first introduction day, the medical student is expected to participate in the activities of the department and/or outpatient clinic and as independently as possible. The student consults patients, takes medical histories, performs and interprets physical examinations, and documents in the patient records. Furthermore, the student attends multidisciplinary conferences, follows regular instruction, works after-hours shifts, and witnesses procedures whereby (s)he is instructed in medical technical skills.
The clerkship takes place in year 3.
Please refer to the general textbook list.
Clerkship guidelines, portfolio, and student manual Medical Clerkship Pediatrics
Dr. A.J.M. Huisjes, coordinator Teaching Hospital, mail: a.huisjes@gelre.nl

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The objectives of the Clerkship Social Medicine are to bring the social-medical way of thinking into practice and to obtain social-medical skills and practical knowledge. More information about the clerkship locations can be found in the clerkship manual.
The duration of the internship is two weeks, during which the student will be present at the clerkship location.
The Medical Clerkship Social Medicine takes place in year 3 (and for some students in year 4) and is preceded by the Line “Medicine and Society” in years 1 and 2.

Books relevant for the clerkship are listed in the general textbook list. The main textbook used during Medicine and Society and the clerkship is the latest version of Mackenbach & Stronks, Volksgezondheid en gezondheidszorg.
The student will be assessed by the supervisor at the clerkship location.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Medical Clerkship Family Medicine builds upon the material of year 1 and 2.
The goals of the clerkship Family Medicine have been formulated by the Interdepartmental Conference of Family Medicine as follows :

Via the clerkship Family Medicine the student becomes capable of - under supervision - to experience, think about, and gain insight into the attitudes a family practitioner needs in order to deal with the patients, patients' problems and ailments, and how these outcomes relate to living environments. Furthermore, students learn what it means to deal with the uncertainties encountered in family medicine. ""
In practical terms, this means the following objectives can be distinguished:

column2: • to gain insight into the problems, and patterns of morbidity seen in a family practice
• to skillfully and systematically conduct a patient consultation as a general practitioner; and to in particular learn systematical differentiation between medical problems and the chief complaint.
• to gain insight into interpersonal factors influencing  the nature of the doctor-patient relationship
• to gain insight into other forms of primary healthcare
• to learn the nature of cooperation and of referral possibilities within primary healthcare and between primary and secondary medical professionals.
• to place the upcoming physician in a position to make appropriate career choices
• to gain sufficient knowledge and insight into family medicine necessary for future cooperation with general practitioners
• to become increasingly and independently involved in the of assessment and management of patients

column1: The five week Medical Clerkship Family Medicine takes place in a general practitioner's office. Twice a month a ""Return Morning"" is scheduled for the family medicine clerks. The program consists of: exchanging experiences, student presentations, and the choosing of a chairman by the Family Medicine instructor.
The clerkship takes place in year 3, after all other clerkships have been completed.
Refer to the general textbook list.
Refer to student manual Medical Clerkship Family Practice.
Refer to student manual Medical Clerkship Family Practice.
The SUMMA clerkship is organized in the area of Apeldoorn.

An informative meeting concerning the content and placing procedure takes place at the end of year 2. For further information place contact  F.E.A. van der Burg (a.vanderburg@umcutrecht.nl), secretary Family Practice Education.
Dr. D.L.M. Zwart mail: H. Breheler (Utrecht) and A. van Empel (Apeldoorn) via: onderwijs-huisartsgeneeskunde@umcutrecht.nl

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
- To learn to recognize dermatological disorders based on the morphological aspects of the skin.
- To be introduced to the most common dermatological disorders seen in the offices of general practitioners and dermatologists.
During a period of 5 weeks, each group has one half day per week allocated to the dermatology out-patient clinic. Students learn under supervision in the student clinic.
The Student Clinic dermatology takes place in year 2.

The relevant books for the student clinic are referred to on the general textbook list.  Furthermore, a number of handbooks are available in the dermatology department. E-modules are available at Blackboard.

In order to participate in the student outpatient clinics the student needs to possess a stethoscope, a penlight and a reflex hammer. White coats are on tenure in the UMC Utrecht against payment of a bond.
There is no private study room available. Students can use the “studielandschap” or the medical library.

Two assessments take place during the five-week period. The first assessment takes place after two weeks and consists of an interview in which the gaps in the student’s knowledge and skills are defined. The final assessment is a concluding evaluation of the practical functioning of the student.
Drs. C.J.G. Sanders, mail: c.sanders@umcutrecht.nl of via onderwijs-dermatologie@umcutrecht.nl

- To learn to take a gynecologic and reproductive medical history and to perform a gynecological physical examination in a clinical setting.
- to learn to take an obstetric medical history, to perform a physical examination of the pregnant patient, and to apply what is learned in a clinical setting.
- To gain knowledge of the most common pregnancy complications, and of the Dutch obstetrics system and risk-stratified care-management.

During a period of 5 weeks, each group has one half day per week allocated to the student clinic for each subject.. Students learn by conducting role-play exercises, practicing on phantoms, receiving training from  specialized gynecological examination instructors,  and by practicing - under supervision- on patients in an out-patient setting. Furthermore, students participate in meetings where patients are discussed.
The Student Clinic obstetrics and gynecology takes place in year 2.
The relevant books for the student clinic are referred to on the general textbook list.

In order to participate in the student outpatient clinics the student needs to possess a stethoscope, a penlight and a reflex hammer. White coats are on tenure in the UMC Utrecht against payment of a bond.
At the end of the five-week period, a final assessment addressing the practical functioning of the student is conducted.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/180136,2017,Student outpatient clinic in internal medicine,Dutch,Faculty of Medicine,,['dr. S.C. Bakker'],,Content

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
An introduction to Internal Medicine through the practical application of internal medicine under specialist supervision in an out-patient setting.

Students learn to develop and use patient examination skills, psycho-social communication skills, the ability to apply acquired knowledge of pathophysiological processes, and the rationale necessary to formulate treatment objectives and methods common to the specialty. The gradual development of these skills allows the autonomy of the student to increase with each outpatient clinic.

In SUMMA year 1 (curriculum 2006) Mondays and Fridays are reserved for the student outpatient clinics. In 2 periods of 8 weeks students participate in the student outpatient clinics at the following wards:

column2: • Internal Medicine
• Surgery

column1: The order in which the student participates on both wards varies. The schedule will be announced in advance. Students also keep a record of the medical procedures they witnessed or conducted themselves.
The student outpatient clinic Internal Medicine takes place in year 1

The books relevant for the student outpatient clinics are listed in the general textbook list. Furthermore, a number of standard reference works is available at the wards. Students are encouraged to consult scientific articles (obtained from for instance PubMed) for extra information about the cases encountered.

In order to participate in the student outpatient clinics the student needs to possess a stethoscope, a penlight and a reflex hammer. White coats are on tenure in the UMC Utrecht against payment of a bond.

Two assessments take place per ward in the period of eight weeks (curriculum 2006). The first assessment moment after two weeks consists of an interview in which the gaps in the student’s knowledge and skills are defined. The final assessment is a concluding assessment of the practical functioning of the student through the completion of the Brief Clinical Assessment Score (‘Korte Klinische Beoordelings Score’, KKBS) by the teacher.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/180156,2017,Student outpatient clinic in pediatrics,Dutch,Faculty of Medicine,,['dr. S.C. Bakker'],,Content

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
An introduction to Pediatrics through the practical application of Pediatrics under specialist supervision in an out-patient setting.

Students learn to develop and use patient examination skills, psycho-social communication skills, the ability to apply acquired knowledge of pathophysiological processes, and the rationale necessary to formulate treatment objectives, and decision-making methods common to the specialty. The gradual development of these skills allows the autonomy of the student to increase with each outpatient clinic.
During a period of 5 weeks, each group has one day per week allocated to the pediatric out-patient clinic.

The student initially observes the pediatrician perform the medical consultation and interact with the patient and the family. The students gradually take over parts of the medical consultation from the pediatrician (taking the medical history, performing and explaining the physical examination, diagnosing the patient, proposing a treatment course, and charting. The student remains under the supervision of the specialist, who provides feedback after every consult. Students subsequently chart in the patient’s health record and compose a letter to the provider who requested a consult.
Students also keep a record of the medical procedures they witnessed or conducted themselves.
The student outpatient clinic Internal Medicine takes place in year 2 (curriculum 2006).
E-module History and Physical Examination Child
Illustrated textbook of paediatrics  [ed. By] Tom Lissauer, GrahamClayden. – 3rd ed., - Edinburgh [etc.] : Mosby, 2003; ISBN: 0723431787
In order to participate in the student outpatient clinics the student needs to possess a stethoscope, a penlight and a reflex hammer.

Two assessments take place per ward in the period of eight weeks (curriculum 2006). The first assessment moment after two weeks consists of an interview in which the gaps in the student’s knowledge and skills are defined. The final assessment is a concluding assessment of the practical functioning of the student.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/180157,2017,Student outpatient clinic in neurology,Dutch,Faculty of Medicine,,['dr. S.C. Bakker'],,Content

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The student clinic neurology serves as an introduction to Neurology through the practical application of medical knowledge under specialist supervision.

Special attention is given to taking the neurological medical history and performing the physical examination in order to localize the neurologic disease, and perform a differential diagnostic procedure.

During a period of 5 weeks, students spend one day per week practicing the clinical skills necessary to perform a neurological medical consult; this entails taking a medical history, performing a physical examination, and combining the findings to localize the neurological problem.
The medical history taking and physical examination is practiced in the first and second half of each neurology session, respectively.

The physical examination is first demonstrated by the neurologist, and students subsequently practice the examination in vivo. The medical history taking is practiced by roll-playing, in which students play both the role of physician and interviewing doctor. A total of 12 different clinical scenarios are played out. During the final session, the students perform a medical consult on a patient admitted to the neurology department under the supervision of a medical specialist.
The student outpatient clinic Neurology takes place in year 2 (curriculum 2006).
The student clinic neurology is based on the following medical textbooks.

column2: • Hijdra A, Koudstaal PJ, Roos RAC. `Neurologie’. Chapters are assigned weekly.
• Aids to the Examination of the Peripheral Nervous System, Ballière Tindall.

column1: Please also refer to the general textbook list.

All course materials (stethoscope, reflex hammer, etc.)  necessary will be made available to the students. White coats are on tenure in the UMC Utrecht against payment of a bond, and are expected to be worn when accompanying the specialist on rounds, or during any other patient contact moments.
Attendance is mandatory. Only if the attendance requirement has been fulfilled sufficiently the student can participate in the final assessment.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Je studeert Geneeskunde aan de universiteit. Een kenmerk van een academische studie is dat je zelfsturend bent in je ontwikkeling. Dat betekent dat je zelf initiatief neemt om te leren.

Daarmee bedoelen we niet alleen het zelfmanagement en de zelfdiscipline om je leven goed in te delen en op tijd je studieboeken te lezen en je zelfstudies te maken, maar ook om bewuste keuzes te maken om van bepaalde zaken meer te leren dan strikt noodzakelijk is of om bijvoorbeeld bij jezelf te signaleren dat bepaalde vaardigheden of kennis nog niet optimaal zijn en je daar meer aandacht aan moet besteden.

Om zelfsturend te kunnen werken, is het belangrijk dat je goed overziet wat je studie inhoudt, wat jij tot nu toe gedaan hebt, wat je nog zou willen/kunnen/moeten doen en welke extra dingen je kunt doen. Daarnaast moet je je ook bewust zijn van welke andere zaken in je leven, naast je studie, van belang zijn of je misschien zelfs kunnen belemmeren in je studie.

Alles bij elkaar betekent het dat je goed moet kunnen reflecteren. Reflecteren is echter niet altijd gemakkelijk, en is iets dat je moet leren. Het Studiereflectieprogramma zal je daarbij helpen, evenals je tutor (begeleidend docent).
1. Leren om het maximale uit je studie te halen
3. Zicht krijgen op en waar mogelijk verbeteren van je studievoortgang in het algemeen.
4. Zicht krijgen op en waar mogelijk verbeteren (ontwikkelen) van de competenties:
Het portfolio wordt ingezet als instrument om bovenstaande doelstellingen te realiseren.
Voor studiereflectie is het volgende gepland:
Acht groepsbijeenkomsten waarvan vier in jaar 1, drie in jaar 2 en één in jaar 3.
Vier maal een individueel gesprek met de tutor, waarbij de portfolio als uitgangspunt voor het gesprek wordt genomen.
Plaats van het onderdeel in het programma CRU+
Studiereflectie is een lijn binnen de jaren 1 t/m 3 van de bachelor.
Voldoende: het portfolio moet compleet zijn, de groepsbijeenkomsten moeten bijgewoond zijn en individuele gesprekken met de tutor moeten serieus gevoerd zijn.

Toetsing eind jaar 1 (1 studiepunt) en in jaar 3 (0,5 studiepunt). (Dit houdt in dat jaar 1 één studieonderdeel vormt en jaar 2 en 3 tezamen ook één studieonderdeel vormt in termen van de Onderwijs- en Examenregeling (OER).)
Contactpersonen: mw. drs. M.B. Berk, (tel 088-7568191, e-mail: en m.b.berk@umcutrecht.nl), mw drs. C.A.E. Reuchlin-Rietveld (tel 088-7551421, e-mail: C.A.E. Reuchlin-Rietveld@umcutrecht.nl).

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/176382,2017,Study Design in Etiologic Research,English,Faculty of Medicine,,['dr. P.H.M. Peeters', 'R.H.H. Groenwold, PhD']",,"Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: At the end of this course, the student:

column5: has insight in the principles and design of a cohort study, a case control study and a cross-sectional study;
has insight in the advantages and disadvantages of cohort, case-control and cross-sectional studies;
has insight in the differences between a cohort, case-control and cross-sectional study;
has insight in the measures of frequency and association that can be calculated from cohort, case-control and cross-sectional studies;
has insight in the validity aspects of cohort, case-control and cross-sectional studies;
has insight in modern designs used instead of the classical case-control study (e.g. case-cohort study, case-cross-over study);
has insight in the methods for data collection in the different study designs;

has insight in the specific aspects of study design in veterinary epidemiology as compared to ‘human’ epidemiology (e.g. clustering of animals and the effects this has on study design, measurement of exposure status, disease status and confounders, and the selection of the study population);
is able to choose an appropriate study design to be used in a specific situation or to answer a specific study question.

column2: </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Dr. C. van Gils - UMC Utrecht, Julius Center for Health Sciences and Primary Care
Dr . R. Groenwold, PhD - UMC Utrecht, Julius Center for Health Sciences and Primary Care

In this course the principles and practice of cohort, case-control and cross-sectional studies are taught. Design, data collection and outcome measures are discussed, as well as the major advantages and disadvantages of the different study designs. Emphasis is on the application of study design in etiologic research. The course focuses on the more classical approach but also addresses modern concepts and design options, such as case-cohort designs. Various study designs are discussed, with emphasis on issues of validity.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: At the end of this course, the student:

column5: has insight in the basic terminology and principles used in epidemiology;
has an overview of important historical developments in health sciences in general, and epidemiology in particular;
has insight in the different measures of frequency, association and impact that are commonly used in epidemiological research;
is able to calculate these measures using simple numerical examples;
has insight in the different aspects of epidemiological research (etiologic / diagnostic / prognostic / therapeutic, causal / descriptive);
has knowledge of the different study designs used in epidemiological research;
is able to read and understand (simple) epidemiological scientific papers and recognize, in these papers, which study design was used;
is able to apply the correct measures of frequency and association belonging with the different epidemiological study designs;
understands the meaning of the terms bias and confounding;
has insight in the different fields of epidemiological research as covered at UMC Utrecht and Utrecht University.

column2: </body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: After completing the course, students will be able to:

column5: Describe how stylistics emerged out of the classical world of rhetoric and poetics
Explain the role Russian Formalism has played in the development of modern stylistics
Reflect on foregrounding effects and on the necessary comprehension, processing and retention procedures experienced by readers

Conduct various short stylistic analyses of literary texts using (a) the foregrounding model of levels of linguistics units (both within and beyond the sentence), and (b) some discourse models/theories
Separate and classify schemes and tropes within the foregrounding framework

column2: </body>
<head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: This stylistics module is primarily intended for humanities students with an interest in linguistics, literary studies or media studies. The module may also be relevant for some social science students (especially psychologists) with an interest in cognitive text processing strategies and reception strategies.

Stylistics, sometimes known as ‘literary linguistics’ or ‘literary stylistics’ is a linguistics-based method of literary criticism that emerged in the early twentieth century with the advent of Russian Formalism with its inherent notion of foregrounding/estrangement. Its real roots, however, are in the world of classical rhetoric and poetics. Stylistics is also a pedagogical tool for the learning of grammatical categories and parts of speech that occur in a semi-natural discourse environment. In addition, stylistic analysis also employs a number of text and discourse theories as methods of analysis including, relevance theory, conversation analysis, speech act theory, etc. Stylistics does not just analyse literary texts, but also looks at everyday texts and the text-image interface that can be found in the discourse of comics, hypertext fiction, multimodal texts, etc.

This course is a workshop-style, practice-intensive, interactive course for which a high level of qualitative participation is required (learning by doing). Students must therefore be vocal during all sessions: debating, critiquing, analysing and discussing. The following factors are also considered when determining the overall participation grade. The course will be graded based on (a) the end of term exam, which will be worth 75%, and on (b) active participation, what might be termed a combination of attendance, preparation and participation (APP), which will constitute the remaining 25% of the course grade. Students will be expected to have prepared well for the class; this includes completing all assigned reading and any assigned homework exercises/assignments.

column4: This course is taught during the last five weeks of the semester. It uses the same timeslot as the UCACCMET25 group did during the first ten weeks.

column2: </body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/182886,2017,Subatomic physics,English,Faculty of Science,,['dr. P. Christakoglou'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • The student understands how to work with covariant and contravariant vectors
• The student learns how to perform transformations between different inertial systems and to make calculations for decays and collisions between particles using relativistic mechanics
• The student can identify the building blocks of the Standard Model, the leptons, the quarks, the gauge bosons and their quantum numbers
• The student is able to explain how different particles interact with matter
• The student is able to explain how modern particle detectors work
• The student can distinguish the three different interactions of the Standard Model, the electromagnetic, the weak and the strong and their force carriers
• The student can draw and interpret Feynman diagrams for basic interactions between subatomic particles
• The student can identify the main symmetries of the Standard Model and the notion of symmetry breaking

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The lectures start with an introduction of the mathematical tools needed to study the underlying theory of particle physics. We will look at the Lagrangian formalism and at transformations between different inertial systems. We introduce the 4-vector notation and we will get a chance to make calculations for decays and collisions between particles using relativistic mechanics. We will then get to know about symmetries and conservation laws and we will get familiar with the building blocks of the Standard Model, the leptons, the quarks, the gauge bosons and their quantum numbers.

The second part of the lectures focuses on introducing the theoretical framework of the three pillars of the Standard Model: the electromagnetic, the weak and the strong interactions. For each of the three topics, we make the connection between theory and the latest experimental results from state-of-the-art accelerators (e.g. the Large Hadron Collider at CERN) and detector systems. Finally, we conclude with the latest developments in the field of particle physics, including the discovery of the Higgs particle and its importance but also with a discussion about physics beyond the Standard Model.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/178444,2017,Subcultures: Music, Identity, Media",English,Faculty of Humanities,,"['dr. E.T.F. Jas', 'L. Rusch']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>In this course (which forms part of the deepening package Music and Media) we gain advanced insight into (the development of) subculture theories from CCCS to club cultures and active audiences, advanced insight into the diverse analytical approaches towards subcultures, as well as advanced insight into the role media play within the process of creating subcultures. We learn to analyze subcultures with the use of various theoretical approaches</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

“Video killed the radio star”—internet killed the video star: media play an important role in our perception of popular culture. Pop(ular) music, television series as well as computer games have generated all kinds of subcultures. This course discusses the subject of subculture theory starting with the semiotic method of Hebdige and the Cultural Studies approach of the CCCS, up and including the ethnographic angle of incidence suggested by Maffesoli as well as theories concerning online fanship.

The manner media and mediation contribute to the foundation of subcultures will be studied. The ways in which magazines, music, radio, TV, film and the internet (as well as media such as gamesound tracks and ring tones) create processes of affective signification and identification will be examined. The human body will be studied as a significant factor within this context: in which ways for instance, do the online World of Warcraft-communities differ from Gothic cultures, wherein the body functions as mediation of subcultural solidarity?

This course is the third course in specialization Muziek en media and elaborates on themes taught in the first year courses of the BA programme in Musicology. To succeed in this course, students will need intermediate to advanced knowledge of Western music history, basic knowledge of Popular music history, elementary to intermediate knowledge of music theory, and ­– preferably – knowledge of musical intermediality

column2: • heeft de student kennis van en inzicht in de inhoud en de systematiek van de Successiewet 1956.
• kan de student de verworven kennis toepassen op concrete casus.
• is de student in staat om de schenk- en erfbelasting geïntegreerd te benaderen vanuit civielrechtelijke en fiscaalrechtelijke achtergrond.
• kan de student een schriftelijke probleemanalyse op het gebied van de schenk- en erfbelasting maken en een mogelijke oplossingsrichting aangeven en uitwerken.

• heeft de student inzicht in het maatschappelijk kader waarbinnen de schenk- en erfbelasting aan de orde komt en weet de student binnen dit kader te handelen op de wijze en met de kennistechnische en ethische normen die van hem mogen worden verwacht.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In deze cursus staat de Successiewet 1956 en de daaruit voortvloeiende verschuldigdheid van schenk- en erfbelasting centraal. Hierbij wordt tevens een verband gelegd met de civielrechtelijke aspecten van het relatievermogensrecht, het erfrecht, het schenkingsrecht en het levensverzekeringsrecht zodat een geïntegreerde behandeling van deze verschillende rechtsgebieden plaatsvindt. Na een algemene inleiding op de Successiewet en de behandeling van de fiscale gevolgen van schenken en erven, wordt aandacht besteed aan de fictiebepalingen die de Successiewet bevat. Door deze fictiebepalingen, die bijvoorbeeld zien op renteafspraken en overnamebedingen, kan eveneens sprake zijn van een verkrijging waarover schenk- en erfbelasting is verschuldigd. Vervolgens komen de vrijstellingen en tarieven, alsmede de waardering van krachtens schenking of vererving verkregen vermogen aan de orde. Tot slot wordt aandacht besteed aan enkele bijzondere verkrijgingen, zoals de verkrijging van bedrijfsvermogen en landgoederen.

Om het vak goed te kunnen doorgronden is het van belang een gedegen kennis te hebben van de daarmee verband houdende civielrechtelijke regelingen. In het bijzonder het huwelijksvermogensrecht (Boek 1 Burgerlijk Wetboek), het erfrecht (Boek 4 Burgerlijk Wetboek) en het schenkingsrecht (Boek 7 Burgerlijk Wetboek) vormen bij dit vak het uitgangspunt. Zonder deze kennis kan niet worden bepaald wie krachtens erfrecht of schenking verkrijgt.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course is part of the master program L&E of the Utrecht University School of Economics and School of Law. It is offered in period 2 and is mandatory for both the LL.M-students and the Msc-students.

The course Supervision of Markets aims to provide thorough insight and knowledge into the basic legal principles, institutions and instruments of market supervision.  In the first period  the students have obtained a better understanding of  the context of  EU law and national law and the  regulation of  competition and consumer protection in specific markets. The focus of this course is on the institutional context and supervision by Supervisory Agencies of market sectors that are subject to liberalization, such as the energy sector, the banking sector,  and the electronic communications sector. What is the position and the role of supervisory agencies and what instruments do they have to supervise competition in the market as well as address market failures and consumer protection? Central topics of the course are:  the basic legal principles and legal instruments of the relevant European directives; modalities for the introduction of competition, good agency principles and market governance, the role of national supervisory agencies and  European regulators, regulatory processes and practices.
Place of this course within the curriculum:

column2: • Compulsory course in Law and Economics

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: After completing the course, students are able to:

column5: Discuss the concept of sustainability as it appears in various contexts.
Distinguish facts & scientific theories from ethics & opinions.
Debate the relevance of sustainability to the future of life on earth.
Present in a coherent and considered way their views on the topic.
Analyze sustainability aspects of a self-chosen system, man-made or natural

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: This course aims to explore the principles, problems and methods of sustainability.

In 1987, the Brundtland commission defined sustainable development as development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs. Living sustainably may well be the greatest challenge we face: either we survive together or none of us will. Some do not see the urgency and ask What's posterity ever done for me? They want to see money spent on present rather than future problems. Clearly, sustainability involves deep ethical issues. As a truly interdisciplinary topic, it is ideally suited for the Liberal Arts & Sciences integrative approach.

After a critical historical introduction we study what the natural sciences tell us about processes and cycles on our planet from a systems point of view. Ecology, the end of fossil fuels, alternative energy sources, environmental pollution, loss of biodiversity and climate change will be reviewed. Besides relevant facts, the sciences provide also interpretive theories with important, but often uncertain, implications for the future.

Facts and predictions do not suffice. In the end, the debate about sustainability is about values. What do we care about and why? What is worth sustaining? This will carry us into environmental ethics and a critical analysis of the relationship of humans to nature.

Having heard the facts and discussed our values, we turn to the social, economic and political aspects of sustainability. Here one often sees a clash between competing interests and different cultures. Is “sustainable growth” an oxymoron? Possible solutions to such problems will be explored, including environmental economics. Which agents, government, NGOs or grass-roots groups can best achieve the desired changes?

Finally, we try to integrate the different approaches and points of view in an attempt to arrive at policy recommendations. We will also examine our own behavior and discuss what type of changes we might make in our personal lives.

Besides listening to lectures by various instructors, students will read and discuss chapters of the textbook and recent (news) articles on issues related to sustainability.  Small groups of students will give presentations and write integrative essays with a focus on a particular aspect of the field.

column2: </body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/179526,2017,Sustainability Challenges,English,Faculty of Geosciences,,['dr. M.C. Bootsma'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After completion of the course the student is able to:

column2: • Give a good overview of the concept of sustainable development, its history and complexity, and examples of various ways to operationalize it.
• Understand the people, planet profit concepts and how they apply to various real life sustainability challenges.
• Provide possible strategies for solutions to current global sustainability challenges.
• Understand that achieving sustainability solutions needs contributions from different perspectives, stakeholders and worldviews.
• Can gather relevant scientific information and use it to develop an end product while upholding scientific integrity.
• Analyze a current sustainable development challenge and present possible solutions in a scientific manner by writing a paper and giving a presentation.
• Collaborate and contribute as a group member, reflect on project process and personal contribution to produce final products.
• Write texts for academic purposes in correct English, being aware of the appropriate academic style and structure to be used in such texts.
• Give an engaging presentation in English, being aware of an appropriate and effective presentation structure.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course aims at providing students a comprehensive overview to the concept of sustainable development and global sustainability challenges from the economic, environmental and social perspectives. Current sustainability challenges are explored through international case studies.

The contributions of relevant disciplines as demography, social and political science, ecology, energy and innovation, environmental science, agricultural science and economy are explained. The core topics include energy and society, consumption and consumerism, risks and resilience, waste, water and land.  But also concepts as food security, environmental health, planetary boundaries, Climate change, worldviews and ethics will be addressed.

The course consists of lectures, mandatory tutorials (including a serious game), workshops Academic English, an exam and a large group project. Students will spend 4 weeks on the Sustainability Challenge project, which consists of a current global sustainability issue that will be analyzed by the group members from the different sustainability perspectives. The group will come up with a new innovative possible solution to the sustainability challenge. The project will result in a paper and a scientific presentation which will be given at a public symposium at the end of the course.
Academic skills: academic writing, presenting, peer feedback, groupwork
This course is the entry requirement for (if applicable and not mentioned above):

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/179598,2017,Sustainability Modelling and Indicators,English,Faculty of Geosciences,,['Docenten onderwijsinstituut SD', 'dr. H.J. de Boer']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this course, we expose the students to a portfolio of modelling techniques and indicators that are used to get a more in-depth understanding of the scientific underpinnings of achieving sustainable development across a wide range of themes.
After completion of this course, the student is able to:

column2: • Explain how the theories and concepts taught in the course Perspectives on Sustainable Development (PSD) (GEO4-2301) relate to sustainable development indicators, models, and the development of projections and scenarios.
• Apply diverse mathematical models and software tools used in sustainability research.
• Understand the properties of models and indicators with and without feedbacks, specifically those that describe interactions and dynamics of social-ecological systems.
• Develop and evaluate sustainable development indicators and the methods most frequently used to quantify them.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course is organized around four hands-on assignments and one exam. We will start with the analysis of dynamic systems and introduce the concepts behind this methodological approach through the use of mathematical models in the modelling environment of Stella. Then we will use the spreadsheet Microsoft Excel to develop models and projections that allow answering the question whether we can sustainably feed a growing population. After that, students will work with the Netlogo software to learn about agent-based modelling, that is, understand the effects of individual behavioural choices in collective outcomes. The exam will cover the theoretical concepts discussed during the lectures, guest-lectures, assigned readings and assignments. Finally, students conduct their own research project that involves a scientific analysis of a self-selected sustainability issue via different sustainable development indicators, such as: Environmental Performance Index, Human Development Index, Ecological Footprint, Happy Planet Index, etc.
The course is a sequel to the course SUSD-Perspectives on Sustainable Development (GEO4-2301) and its content is assumed to be known.
This course is an entry requirement for: Master Thesis SD (GEO4-2321).</body>
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177327,2017,Sustainability and Social Contestation,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,[],,Course goals

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column5: To learn, understand and apply new theoretical approaches and concepts around the themes of social sustainability, social contestation, active citizenship, societal participation in environmental and economic sustainability. To be able to elaborate on them in exam questions.

To analyze both academic and societal debates about social sustainability (such as food sovereignty, food justice, de-growth, solidarity economy, etc.), developing an understanding of the arguments at hand and one’s own critical and scientifically sound position. To exercise such skills in a group moderating task.

To learn to report on the theoretical and ethnographic findings presented in the course in a scientific way (using argumentation, organization, and analysis). To Learn to present research findings and literature analysis in a written paper.

column2: </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Sustainability is an increasingly contested terrain. The very meaning of the term ranges from environmental stewardship to the search for technological fixes to the multiple challenges of climate change, demographic pressure, and our current inefficient and wasteful provisioning of energy, food, and natural resources. However, such interpretation of sustainability is limited and it is often contested. A ‘triple bottom line’ is increasingly invoked to point out that sustainability has not only an environmental and economic meaning (by which an enterprise cannot be polluting or running business in the red) but also a social one: our livelihoods and models of development must be not only economically viable and environment-friendly but also socially equitable. Around the world, a variety of citizens’ initiatives express a felt need for sovereignty over matters of sustainability. Alternative food networks, alternative currencies, and models for transition to renewable resources and societal resilience characterize such initiatives.

Anthropologists can describe and contextualize such grassroots understandings of societal innovation and contestation. They do so on the basis of a fine-grained comprehension of the cultural diversity of such understandings, whether due to ethnic, class, gender differences, or age, health, and status. This course offers a theoretical vocabulary to interpret and analyze such social phenomena.</body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/179797,2017,Sustainability, Health and Medical Technology",English,Faculty of Geosciences,,"['prof. dr. E.H.M. Moors', 'prof. dr. H. Schellekens']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After completion of the course, the student is able to:

column2: • describe,  interpret, and critically reflect the mutual relation between sustainability and health, focusing on present-day sustainable healthcare topics;
• analyze the current deficits in the innovation system of medicines and medical technology development;
• analyze potential solution directions to the weaknesses in the current health innovation system;
• evaluate  conditions for  sustainable drug development.
• integrate reforms of various sub-systems in drug/medical technology development;
• design an alternative business model for sustainable drug/medical technology development.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Health and sustainability, health and climate change, health and development, international health policy;
• Rise and fall of the pharmaceutical industry;
• Marketing of drugs and medical technology (marketing to professionals, direct and indirect marketing to consumers);

• Regulation of drugs, diagnostics and medical technology, e.g. market authorization,  reimbursement, pharmacovigilance, professional guidelines, specific regulation for e.g. orphan drugs and WHO essential drugs;
• Patents, IP issues and drugs/diagnostics/medical technology; patents and innovation, patents as strategic tool, patents and ethics, equal access to medicines;
• The role of the academic world in drugs/medical technology development: commercialization of science, open access developments;
• The relevance of animal studies in drugs/medical technology development;
• Access to drugs, vaccines and diagnostics;
• Health & equity; health & ethics aspects.

column1: The students write individual essays in which they critically reflect on these various subthemes of the course,  developing their own substantiated argumentation line about the topic.  Groups of 2 students pick a paper theme which they will study in depth. In week 2 students start reading about the problem area, the possible  technological solutions and the relation to sustainability and health in general, and they develop a brief work plan for their paper. This workplan will be discussed with their supervisors. During week 4-8 students transform their work plan in a draft paper based on insights from literature and guest-lectures. During weekly  tutorials parts of the paper will be discussed and students will give peer-feedback on each other’s draft. Results of the paper project will be presented in an expert workshop in week 8.  By the end of week 9 the final paper has to be finished, based on comments from the expert panel and the supervisor on the draft version.

column2: • Written skills in individual essays and paper;
• Verbal skills in presentations in expert workshop;
• Professional skills in cooperating in joint paper, peer feedback tutorials and in expert workshop

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of the course, students should have a profound understanding of:
The contribution of their research topic to the Sustainable Development Goals
The contribution of other research topics (of other tracks within the master program)  to the Sustainable Development Goals
At the end of the course, students should be able to:
Discuss their research topic with other students

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Being involved in research, MSc students should be aware of the potential role their results could play to build a sustainable future. Moreover, students should be able to constructively discuss and connect with other students of the master's program. As such, this inter-track course will encourage the participants to determine and discuss how their research topic may contribute to solving questions related to sustainability. In particular, participants will put their research in relation with one or more of the 17 Sustainable Development Goals set by the United Nations (https://sustainabledevelopment.un.org/?menu=1300). Groups of ten students belonging to the five different tracks will be composed. Based on the project proposal that the students wrote at the start of their major internship, participants will write in no more than 500 words a report containing a clear description of their potential contribution. Each participant will read the reports of two fellow peers and gives peer review. Based on group meetings and discussion of the reviews, each group will choose one report which will be presented in plenary in no more than two slides at the end of the course.
17 Sustainable Development Goals set by the United Nations (https://sustainabledevelopment.un.org/?menu=1300)
Research proposal of student’s major internship.
Mandatory for students in Master’s programme: NO.
Optional for students in other Master’s programmes GS-LS:
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/179801,2017,Sustainable Energy Supply,English,Faculty of Geosciences,,['dr. ir. W.H.J. Crijns-Graus, MSc']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
This course will provide an understanding of the energy supply system (with a focus on the electricity system), including generation and distribution of electricity.
After completion of the course, the student is able to:

column2: • understand the physical and chemical principles underlying energy conversion technologies (renewables, fossil and nuclear power generation) and the way these impact energy output and costs;
• discuss the integration of renewable electricity in the grid in terms of balancing requirements and possible solutions (electricty storage, demand response);
• be able to understand and assess the occurrence of losses in electricity transmission and distribution systems;
• use relevant energy statistics and apply scenario analysis to assess (future) developments of electricity supply on a country level.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The energy supply system is currently not sustainable. Energy use is to a large extent based on fossil fuels, which have limited reserves and are a key source of greenhouse gas emissions. This course will deepen the knowledge on energy supply systems, including fossil-fired power generation, renewable energy technologies (solar, wind, biomass, hydro), nuclear energy and transmission and distribution of electric power.

In the assignment international energy statistics are used to analyze past trends in electricity generation on a country level. These, together with relevant literature, form the basis for the development of several scenarios which will be assessed and compared.
This course is an entry requirement for: Master’s Thesis SD (GEO4-2321)
Academic skills: data gathering and analysis, writing a paper

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/179465,2017,Sustainable Entrepreneurship,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,"['dr. N.S. Bosma', 'drs. H.S. Toxopeus']",,"Content

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Note: this course is only for U.S.E. students. For non-U.S.E. students, see ECMSE (7.5 ECTS).

It is a required elective of the Business Development and Entrepreneurship master, but it also fits well in the International Management master. If you are a student of BF, FM or EP and you consider choosing this course, please contact the coordinator.
Entrepreneurship focuses on identifying new opportunities for creating value for customers or users and commercially developing those opportunities to establish a profitable business.

Sustainable entrepreneurship combines the traditional focus of entrepreneurship with an emphasis on opportunities to alleviate social or environmental conditions. Sustainable entrepreneurship is about entrepreneurs striving simultaneously for profit and for improving local and global environmental and social conditions.

This course is addressed to students interested in exploring the challenges of sustainable entrepreneurship. The course will provide academic and practical insights into the entrepreneurial process and in particular:

column2: • The opportunities and challenges of developing a new venture, given characteristics of the market and the institutional context;
• The challenges of aligning profits with social and environmental value;

column1: The overall objective of this course is to make the students aware of the opportunities offered by an entrepreneurial career, the skills needed for and academic knowledge about entrepreneurial processes, in the context of sustainability. The course emphasizes the business & management perspectives to entrepreneurship.

This course is designed to provide academic knowledge related to idea development, value proposition, market introduction and management of new sustainable business and to put these into practice. The major learning objectives include:

column2: • To provide understanding of (sustainable) entrepreneurship (what entrepreneurship is, cognitive foundations of entrepreneurship, and entrepreneurial opportunities, distinctive characteristics of entrepreneurs);
• To analyse and evaluate the economic sources of social and environmental problems and to identify opportunities to alleviate or eliminate these problems and the underlying conditions;
• To apply the accumulated knowledge by either developing a business model from scratch or by introducing an initially developed plan to the market by means of bootstrapping methods.

column1: This necessitates that students understand the concepts of sustainability and sustainable entrepreneurship, and that students learn about the economic, environmental and social problems facing local and global communities and recognise the opportunities that arise from this. Finally, students should be able to evaluate the risks and rewards of undertaking sustainable entrepreneurship, which involves finding ways to measure the economic as well as social and environmental risks and rewards of a new venture.

This course is an interactive and participatory course that teaches students the key concepts from theory to practice. It adopts a mix of lectures, tutorial sessions, workshops and activities related to the business model assignment. Students are expected to attend and participate in all lectures and take part in all tutorial sessions. The students will be allocated into groups (4 or 5 students) for the business model assignment. The aim is to establish a mix of students from various disciplines (this course coincides with ECMSE for master students Geosciences and other disciplines).
The elements that constitute the final grade are the following:

Groups will either develop a business model from scratch, or introduce developed ideas to the market. This will be achieved in several steps throughout the course. The evaluation will be based on the quality of the final work, the presentation and the process towards the final document(s). Ideas developed in earlier courses (for instance in the track Business Development & Entrepreneurship: Research Project & Entrepreneurial Marketing) may be used as a starting point, as long as they fit with the contents of the course.
There will be a midterm exam that consists of open-ended questions. The questions are based on the key course concepts that are taught and discussed during the course.

column2: • Written midterm exam with open-ended questions (40%); Individual
• Evaluation of business model assignment (60%). Group grade, with a group component (45%) and an individual component (15%).

column1: None. Course is eligible to all students.
